column10:
Grounded is one of those games where you have to block and hit your enemy, in this case bugs, 800 times to kill them and if you mess up one time you are dead.

The game also has massive clipping issues which means you lose half of your arrows and spears due to them glitching into the terrain which is why you should never upgrade spears. Unfortunately spears and bows are among my favourite weapon types. Too bad.

Other than that is a fun game which unfortunately has too many cheese mechanics like wasps that aoe outheal your damage (yes they heal their whole group) or buffgear being made ineffective because you enter combat since the devs don´t like you to have a speed advantage so they artificially slow you down ect. 

If you can live with the cheese mechanics it´s a fun game though.

One of my favorite games ever, genuinely such a fun time, especially if you can do multiplayer. It isn't perfect, since there are some glitches (nothing too bad or frequent, but they do exist) and 100 percent completion is a bit of a pain (requires RNG and 1 achievement was a bit wonky and didn't trigger initially), but I personally didn't mind them at all while playing. I would personally not use guides until absolutely necessary, since I played knowing almost nothing about the game and it greatly increased my enjoyment. If I were to give this game an arbitrary number score, I would give it a 9 or a 9.5 out of 10.

Played over a year ago and semi enjoyed it, not a great game but good game that i enjoyed enough to want to try again today but game won't progress past first loading screen and never makes it to main menu, tried several things to fix and emailed support who are convinced the problem is my PC and can only suggest things for me to try like clean boot and new user but i don't like the game enough to jump through hoops just to play so i can't recommend the game if it isn't ready to just play like 99.9% of the games i can play. i can still enjoy a game with bugs but not a bug that prevents even loading the game after a fresh install.

This game's endgame is the worst grindy bullshit I've ever seen. It's worse than a Free2Play MMO. You have to collect golden cards that supposedly have a 1% droprate by killing the various enemies from the game. This includes the extra bosses. 

That droprate is a lie by the developers. There are numerous topics of people having to kill over 600 bugs to get a card to drop. My own experience hasn't been any better.  On top of that there are certain enemies like the "Termite King" (feel free to look it up) that only respawn once every 3 days. Now the game has a raid mechanic to "offset" this problem, by allowing you to summon certain enemies for parts they drop. The termite king doesn't drop enough parts from a single kill to summon the appropriate raid though and to make it worse; the raid has a 50% chance of just being a bunch of regular enemies. It's the same for enemies like the wasp drone, you can summon a whole bunch of wasps and have to hope against hope that maybe... just maybe one of them is a drone and not a regular wasp. (usually 1 in 10-15 wasps ends up being a drone) 

Then there's a boss that was added in a recent patch (the infected Broodmother, 5% supposed dropchance) that requires the parts of other bosses from the game to summon it. Be ready to grind those bosses to have more attempts at farming this boss, or grind quests to get science points to duplicate the bait used to summon the boss. But no matter the option, you're gonna be grinding.

All the other progress in the game up until the endgame was story-based or just plain logical follow-up unlocks. But the entire endgame is just RNG on top of more RNG. 

The final insult is that anyone who played the game before these patches got the 100% achievement without having to do any of this. Getting the gold cards didn't used to be a requirement. Soon they'll release patch 1.4 for the game which will introduce another additional boss increasing the grind even further.

It's the laziest way possible to extend the gameplay time, don't support these developers.

Possibly the survival the I hold dearest to my heart, A Classic must have of the genre and countless hours of fun with friend, from Early access to full launch it was always a blast.

%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%
Pros:
- A pretty solid building system that lets you explore extensive hours of building were not only you will be motivated to build something that looks awesome but also something practical due to the raids.
-The combat is really fun and there is a bunch of variety of builds and weapons, its simple but it just works
-Lots and Lots of traits to explore and make a build
-Super appealing cosmetics, armors and weapons
-Enthralling story and amazing mob design
-Exceptional Bosses
-Fun movement with the ziplines
-The theme has to be one of the coolest things ever for those of you growing up with Ants Life, Ant Boy and Honey i shrinked the kids

%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%
Cons:
-there should be more creative ways to get by like domesticating some of the bigger insects like a rideable ant or a rideable bee
-the lack of some units make the environment feel a bit incomplete like the ant queen not existing.
-the lack of a beehive, a walkable beehive dungeon would be awesome
-the house being accessible 
-the lack of character creation, sadly even doe I like the characters present I would love to have at least an option to instead use a created character with my own customization
-4 player only lobbies, I feel most survival games with this much content allow players to playy with lots of friends which is one of the biggest appeals in the survival game genre and such a restricting lobby created situations were the odd friend out most often stopped playing altogether.

%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%

This said most of my cons are stuff I feel they are planning on adding later on with the exception of char creation, which i feel if we at least had customization for the existing chars it would already go a long way or at least more kids to choose from

Final Rating: Absolute Classic and a must have, 10/10

A very fun survival game! Basically the movie Honey, I Shrunk the Kids that you can experience for yourself. There's a wide array of bugs you can encounter and a whole backyard that feels like an entire country at your tiny size. The game is very flexible in how you can play to suit your level and style of gameplay, as well as a nice arachnophobia mode that you can adjust to make the spiders less terrifying. 
The only problem that I see with this game is when you try to play in multiplayer mode. There are times when the game will run slower, or flat out not allow you to join a friend's game. Other times it takes multiple tries to finally join, and it can vary from player to player. Some friends can join with little to no issue while others simply can't no matter what they try. It can be very frustrating, so take that with a bit of caution. When it DOES work, the game is a lot more fun when you have others to share the work load and combat aggro. 
All in all, a very good game.

A Tier 1 mix of survival/action-rpg genres. Never expected Obsidian to make this kind of game, but here we are.
Pros:
-Combat. You need to check enemies' weaknesses, resistances and block just in time. Simple, but satisfying.
-Exploration is rewarding. Some docs about lore and story of the game, skill points, new items, new UI flavors, new craft ingredients, new interesting locations. It's really great here.
-OST. It's great, but gets repetetive after a long time. There's basically one track per biome.
-Story. It's simple and isn't a focus of the game, but I quite liked. It goes for 80's vibe, which is pretty interesing, also characters(few of them) are pretty memorable. Main villain is basically a walking meme and I like it.
-Action-RPG side. You have lots of buffs/debuffs, special abilities from items/equipment/"potions"/food. Also the game has mutations(basically skills) which allow for a good variety of builds and some of them are pretty interesting. 
-Artstyle. It's cartoonish and pretty, yeah. Also sometimes quite creepy(spiders and undershed, brrrrr...). I love it, artists did a very good job here.
-Building. To be honest I didn't build castles here, so I can't say anything about building on that scale. We just had a 3-floor house with "tower" on the roof. All I can say, it was fun and wasn't a pain in the ass to engage with. Also there are a lot of furniture options and they all have an interesting design. Koi Scale chair is literally a Koi Scale chair, yeap. Also I really like the idea of ziplines, because they make traversing the map ease, if you are ready to put an effort into it and build them. We did exactly this and it was actually fun.
QOL. Crafring from the storage and hot deposit(no more spending 5 minutes on sorting all the garbage you collected). 
Cons:
-Party members and NPC characters have some phrases, that they say from time to time, which is cool, but the problem is, that there are only few of them. It just gets repetetive after some time.
-I was stuck in endless falling mode several times. I escaped eventually, but it's not good nevertheless.
-AI sometimes doesn't know what to do and it shows.
-Minor performance issues in several places.

9.5/10, buy for the full price, it's worth it.

Stay Grounded

Did a 50 hr playthrough in July 2023, and not much more than 6 months I am back at it on a 2nd playthrough.
Grounded makes it easy, because it has by far the most amount of QoL in any survival crafting game I've played (out of about 20). Crafting is easy because of craft from storage, banking is easy because of global hot deposit, inventory space is adequate, and with a little bit of work, traversing the map is easy too with ziplines.

It also has by far the best story out of all survival games I've played, though that's not saying much as they typically have little to no story. But it's pretty good in this one, regardless of genre. Combat also feels good, but punishing as there is no dodge roll, just blocking and parrying.

All in all, well worth whatever price tag is applicable at the time of purchase.

This game has a lot of fun elements. Building is easy and not too grindish. The graphics are sharp and pretty. Though the field of view makes me feel like i'm going blind and keep trying to clear my eyes. Getting around the yard is incredibly slow. And if you die  you have to start all over. And this brings me to why I hate this game. You.Will.Die. Over and over and over. Repeatedly. I'm sure in 4 player mode this combat is not so bad since you have 4 people and can be revived. But if you play in single player, which is the first option in the main menu, the game does not scale in any way shape or form to make it 1 player. Doesn't really matter what difficulty. I have never been more frustrated with a video game than this one. Great graphics, amazing idea, fun base building, but the combat and the billion + spawns completely ruin the single player experience for those who can't stand playing with other people.

Edit2: There's a lot of issues, but there are some systems in place to alleviate a lot of the annoying parts of the game. So as long as you're willing to change world options you'll enjoy the game. But probably not until you're halfway through the story if you're following it and not jumping to certain places to get the best gear early. If you do that you'll probably get bored easily by it because it'll be too easy. Maybe on "Woah?" 

Update: Tried the game again recently since they've added a lot to it. I changed some world settings so it wouldn't be such a dreadful grind solo. 
About 19 hours in I got jumped by a large spider while I was killing a stinkbug. I spawned into my base to find another large spider inside of it. Bugs will also randomly stop doing their walking animation, so they glide around like plastic toys. They added this neat Gnat to make solo base building less of a chore, but instead of making it a part of the game it's hidden off inside the world settings. There's actually some semblance of a story and progression now.

It's still in Early Access. Don't let them fool you. It's a shame too, it's a very cool concept.

Another Update. I logged back in and the spider was gone so I've been able to actually progress through the game somewhat. A lot of places don't have any bugs, some of them are places you'd expect to find a bug IRL. Like under a picnic table, there's pretty much zero bugs under it outside of an occasionally ant. Spiders wander the yard ignoring every single other bug, I've only seen them fight other aggressive bugs that probably started the fight. But as soon as you run past they're awake and on you with a jump.
The sad part is that the game isn't hard. It's just tedious. Once you unlock the flavored weapons the combat gets extremely stale. You can stay alive simply with a mosquito sword and some damage resistance. I was swarmed by at least 10 termites, but I kept spamming my mosquito sword stab, and it heals you based on all the damage it deals. So if it hits 5 termites, you get the heal from all 5 hits. Making you a nearly unkillable god against bugs that swarm. You also get a mace that makes shelled bugs a joke and a fire sword that makes spiders a joke.
The majority of the armor and weapons are useless though. And you're pigeonholed into using an entire 3 piece set for it's bonus. Making a lot of the fun pieces of gear without a full set feeling like a waste to wear. The majority of the trinkets are garbage too.

The game seems to want to do everything in it's power to be as annoying and tedious as possible.

So I turned off most of the annoying stuff and it's a lot better of a game when you play it like a regular RPG, similar to older Zelda games.

This game is a masterpiece.

I've beaten it several times, and keep coming back to it for another play through after finishing a game.

It does so many things right, including the ability to send items to chests automatically with a single keypress and being able to craft items and it pull from chests automatically, to a polished combat that enables you improve and see that improvement quickly.

It takes a while to remember that your a tiny human and so you can jump on grass blades and clovers and climb them,but once you start climbing, you gain an entirely new world to explore. There is so much variety in the game that you'll enjoy constantly striving to do more.

I will recommend this to everyone, don't let your fear of spiders cause you to miss out on a true treasure of a game.

:EDIT:  2/15/2024

Originally I gave this game a thumbs down as it had/has a lot of multiplayer issues due to the Xbox server / account requirements.  

Most of those issues are Microsoft related, so I think it's only fair to review the game itself, assuming you're able to play it without multiplayer issues.

With that being said, the game is great.  Very polished and enjoyable survival crafting experience, with co-op that mostly works.  This is one of those "play it for a long weekend or two and beat it with your friends" type games.   I don't see much reason to keep playing after you've progressed and unlocked everything.
Great game to play with friends or by yourself

I first started playing this game back when it wasn't even completed yet on my Xbox, and when there was no bosses and it only had part of the lower yard, even before the pond was added. Even when it only had that, this game was amazing, and I love everything they added to the game since then. 

All the different items they added to make the base look better is amazing, and you can pretty much make your base unique each time. I also love fighting the bosses, each one is difficult and unique. And the boss fights in the story line is amazing, my favorite boss fights are unfortunately the ones you only get to fight once in the game, being the Assistant Manager and the Mant boss fight. I do also like fighting the Orchid Mantis too though. Each insect is unique and amazing. I like all the armors. I like how messy the backyard is XD. I love all the "biomes" of the backyard as well.

The only problem I see some people complain about is that a lot of the insects in the upper yard are just reskined lower yard insects, but more aggressive. But honestly, I am glad they did this because its nice to see the same insect again, but different variations of them, because in real life there are many variations of certain insects too, like the ant. 

Overall, I'd rate this game a 10/10, and I wish games like this became more popularized because I love this genre, and I feel like it doesn't get as much love as it deserves. I'd play an open-world game any day of the week over the popular shooter or battle royales genres.

Best game I have played in years. Props to Obsidian Entertainment.

Combat is mostly just smacking bugs with a specific tool, but there are light RPG elements allowing you to play ranged, melee or tank. You're really buying this game for the world though. The whole "honey I shrunk the kids" thing works so well for a game. The backyard is an awesome worldspace and the level designers have added lots of interesting details, collectables and upgrades everywhere. Really fun to explore.

The base-building system is awesome. We built a starter base out of grass and weed stems and then moved onto a big castle made out of mushroom bricks, and we connected both bases with a zipline. Big fan of the armour stands! This game has the best, most intuitive UI system I have ever played with.

The whole game just feels so well put-together and polished. 10/10 - I want more.

Totally brilliant little game at 10gb. Really punches above its weight with great graphics, depth and story, some of which elements have been typically found lacking in survival sandbox games.

Everything about the game is cute and cozy. You're shrunk down to the size of a small ant, a la "Honey I Shrunk The Kids", and have to navigate your way around some science professor's backyard, fighting or fleeing (mostly fleeing) from insects that far outsize you, and find ways to stay fed and hydrated. You craft weapons, armor and tools from the natural resources around you, and can make little bases to hold your loot and use workshops at while you search for a way to make yourself normal-sized again.

10/10 - loving the microcosmos adventures!

It's an average survival game. TL;DR devs don't like players to have fun.

Whenever someone comes up with a non-intended strategy for the hardest boss in the game, the devs will nerf it in a blink of an eye. It almost feels like they are constantly sniping on reddit/youtube/twitch, which is kind of disgusting. Most of the strategies don't even utilize any kind of glitches.

Because of this and only because of this reason, the devs constantly nerf low tier builds into completely trash. Yes you read it right, they nerf the already low tier builds. Just because these low tier builds have a very specific usage in that boss fight. Those builds were only okayish outside of the boss fight, which some people may still enjoy, but the devs still made them completely unplayable. Yes it's that one reason again which makes studios go down hill: When devs desperately trying to teach their players to play their game.

The only way they want us to beat that boss is to go Sekiro style: perfect parrying every attack. They don't want us to be creative and make our own builds, despite (seemingly) having so many options. Apparently they don't know what kind of game they are making. They made their game with 0 diversity in terms of the last boss fight.

I DO have a cheese for the last boss and nobody on the internet talks about it. But unfortunately I don't want to share it publicly. It's the only game I have ever played that I don't want to share exciting new findings, I am super sorry. It's a PvE survival craft game, you are supposed to be able to do what ever the f you want. Look at Palworld, their official account even retweet players cheesing a mid-end game boss. Go play that game instead.

I am going to get a refund for it. It forces you to log in using a microsoft account and when you finally do manage to get that to work, it gives you some random screen name that you can't change. Don't even want to play it at that point lol. Uninstalling.

Very wholesome concept however tailored to suit no-one, the difficulty even on easy makes an accidentally interaction with a small orb weave spider a near always fatal happening. No chance for single players, even with others can be the over-saturation issue, their is too much going on and that boils down to the games theme, rather than a poor execution of the story telling elements that may have been interesting if it wasnt a hard lock on need other players to survive with you. It just aint worth it for the game it currently is, might as well not even have a single player option considering how much different dynamics are going on.

You'd think the devs would make this game more forgiving for what appears (on the surface) to be a game for a younger audience. maybe it's just my reflexes but even some of the environments seems counter intuitive, yes I guess it must be a sandpit idea, but the "cross pollination" and co mingling of creatures was an over-saturation. I guess that's how it is with a miniature insect scaled game, perhaps the devs would have made more lasting response going in a different theme,, I mean I applaud the effort on a theme so diverse and intricate. However the systems I can see utilised in this game possibly would have suited a farming sim, or heck maybe even a single player survival "prehistoric" game or even the "Castaway" games like "plane crash into island.  

The game is impressively detailed, with lots of interactivity with the environment! (except no land reshaping "shovelling" but is probably why this game runs soo well considering how much is going on in the game, it really did give that wow factor of how did they make this?)

I am NOT recommending this game, although it looks flash and appropriate. It fails to keep me coming back, its not even about worrying about having friends to play, the fact that you can die by one small spider on day one ironically is a scaling issue and balance between enemies, especially on the "easiest mode" for single player, their is probably soo much story and creatures to kill that could be fun, that it seems like it just a challenge at a theme that is heartbreaking. No matter how much I give this game a go in single player theres just too much going on, and then with other players its like so now I can kill more creatures all for what really exactly, a few tidbits and bits & bobs that would be a real pain to grind, player base down, not fun at all.

Great game, farmed every boss multiple times over. Building is a little clunky but it does make it more satisfying when you finally finish a giant project. It is especially fitting in the case of ziplines as it really makes you realize how large and small the game feels when you finally setup a network across the entire yard. The progression and crafting is fantastic, and anyone complaining that something needs to be nerfed is wrong, because nothing in the game is doesn't require at least a little skill to the point where having the sour battle axe makes it too easy (definitely not trying to keep the axe from getting nerfed). Being able to embody the movie honey I shrunk the kids or ant man is very unique and done in the best way possible, as parrying is an extremely satisfying game mechanic because it rewards game knowledge and reaction time. It is nice that the waft emitter exists as it provides for an extremely easy way to farm raw science in the endgame in order to unlock all upgrades and dupe boss items, black widow farming especially. 11/10 game

Genuinely a fun game, the start is confusing, but in a sense of wonder kind of way. As you play, you understand far more about the game and how you should go about taking down each of the different challenges tossed at you. I started this game with a huge fear of spiders, and most bugs for that matter, but have grown to find them not as terrifying through playing this. The wolf spiders jump scares kind of get me from time to time still though but that is to be expected. I think overall if you enjoy playing survival games, or enjoyed the "Honey I Shrunk the Kids" movie you will really get a kick out of playing this and all of the challenging things you will have to overcome throughout the journey. The story is gripping and fun with some comedy sprinkled throughout. This is my first game like this, and know that I will definitely play more as it has been a wonderful break from the stale nature that I sometimes find gaming to be. Give it a shot, and be ready to fight some bugs I really think you'll end up enjoying it way more than you think. I have not played this with friends, but I think that would be an incredibly fun time from some of the videos I've watched.

Not sure if this counts as a spoiler, but I'll talk about the game mechanics mostly.

For those who are interested in the min/maxing and meta gameplay, this game kinda forces you to play a variety within a melee/parry style, since the other combat forms comparatively lack DPS. Also, the bug's melee attacks are mostly "targeting" skills, so even if it doesn't hit your character's hitbox visibly, it will still damage. Thus, blocking/parrying becomes a necessity. You can of course dodge projectile stuffs though.

Other than that, I enjoyed the game overall. It's fairly difficult. There's a balanced mix of story, puzzles, combat and non-combat elements, so you're never occupied on one thing tediously long.

"Grounded" is an engaging and incredibly interesting game that I wholeheartedly recommend. The game offers a captivating world where players shrink down to the size of ants and explore an incredible microcosm. The graphics and design are of high quality, the atmosphere captivates from the first moments, and interesting tasks make the gameplay dynamic and exciting.

One of the main advantages of "Grounded" is the ability to play cooperatively with friends, providing numerous fun moments and shared adventures. The game successfully combines elements of survival, exploration, and building, making it exciting for a variety of players.

The development team has demonstrated an impressive level of attention to detail and listened to player feedback to continually improve the game. "Grounded" is an excellent choice for those who enjoy dynamic gameplay, an intriguing storyline, and the opportunity to interact with other players. I definitely recommend trying this game and enjoying the unique experience of exploring the world revealed during adventures in the microcosm.

Great game.

Honey, I Shrunk the Game!

OK, now that's out of the way... [i]Grounded[/i] is an interesting take on the survival-sandbox genre.  Don't be fooled by the cheesy presentation, this game is brutal, especially when you're playing solo.  This isn't some PG kids' movie.  The Backyard is an incredibly dangerous place when you're the size of an ant; even the cute little ladybugs are roughly the size of a truck, and they hit like one too.  And then there are the spiders, it says something that the game has an "arachnophobia" setting to make them less scary.

I thought the design of the game was done very well. You've got most of the standard biomes -- forest, swamp, caves, desert, underwater, etc. -- re-imagined as giant-size versions of a typical backyard landscape, and the enemies are mostly the various critters that a normal-sized person would barely even notice.   Regarding difficulty, the game is for the most part challenging but not frustrating.  Advancing through the game means building new tools and weapons, but building them usually requires parts from tougher bugs that you need those weapons to defeat. E.g. a gas mask requires stinkbug parts, but you need a gas mask to fight the stinkbugs.  So there's a bit of a difficulty spike when you're ready to move up to the next tier, but it's not insurmountable.  (Pro-tip: sometimes you can find the parts you need in spider web sacs, so you only have to fight some tiny spiders instead of the big bugs.)

I thought the Mutation system was really cool. As you play through the game, you'll get Mutations that can alter your character in various ways, usually related to your playstyle.  Say, favor a sword-type weapon and get a bonus to swords, run around a lot and get better stamina, kill a lot of spiders and get poison resistance, etc.  You can have only a few active at a time, but they're hot-swappable with four presets. I found that it worked well setting up the presets for exploring, fighting, swimming, and building.

My biggest complaint is that the game is very obviously built with multiplayer in mind.  It's not really noticeable at the beginning, but later there are many sections that are extremely challenging for a solo player.  Nearly every boss is a summoner type, so you can be easily overwhelmed if you don't deal with the minions quickly.  And the final challenge is a hold-the-line fight where you have to defend three different points simultaneously.  It's possible (I did it) but not without a ton of preparation and probably several attempts, leading to a fair bit of ending-fatigue.  Even when I took the trouble to find and fight a different boss first, which was hinted to negate the need for that battle, it didn't.

In summary: a difficult but fun survival game that lasts just a little longer than it should, probably more fun if you have somebody to play it with.

My wife and I specifically bought this game to play together but could not get the multiplayer to work no matter how many fixes we tried. "Error hosting lobby, Error finding lobbies, Error logging into XBOX account, ETC..." No excuse for a game that we paid for to be giving us grief over something so simple. Microsoft is where games go to die.

Horrible optimization, rdr2 runs better than this. Multiplayer movement is janky and full of rubberbanding. You are forced into one area, completely ruining the chance of exploration. The characters are annoying but you are forced to listen to them in order to know what to do. Research is time based, so you just sit there doing nothing while you wait for the researcher to charge because you can't craft anything.

This game scratched a very similar itch that Subnautica gave me. Survival crafting where you can go about as deep as you want with that or simply get the necessary upgrades to progress the story/mystery. Combat is quite simple and relies a lot on rock/paper/scissors style weaknesses and resistances which doesn't do enough to make the combat complex or interesting, but it is serviceable.

The setting is about as interesting/novel as Subnautica's is (although I still think Subnautica's is a tad better) and the mystery is a little more simple/obvious, but it's still got a similar style of progression, albeit with actual map markers most fo the time instead of clues you have to puzzle out yourself.

Don't try to 100% the game unless you're seriously in love with it, like "I'm gonna put 500 hours into this if I can find a reason to". The requirement to 100% the game relies on luck or hours and hours spent waiting for the right enemies to respawn. (Green shield bug and moths are the main reason I gave up)

it was winter sale and I was looking for a game to play with my brother & cousin during the holidays. so I decided to buy a random game that was on sale

we blindly played the game with no guides and tips or whatsoever on the hardest difficulty with my family on a 3-4 man multiplayer. and we may have died alot but it was a great experience for sure, after trying different builds and battle strategies to overcome certain areas

we finished the game - got rank A rating in our world with a total playtime of +100hrs and probably +50hrs of grinding/building our bases)

the story is very nice since it gave us an objective on what to do but i was hoping they could make it longer or do more contents cus we got the late game items but we are almost finished with the story which makes it kinda useless because we were expecting to use more of our late game items into the story.

anyway there are also optional bosses to kill if you want more adventure which we really liked doing.

I also would like to see different biomes or perhaps some weather changes - rain or drizzle, snow, fog that could perhaps add some status debuff/effects to the players/insects. or some random event in the world to add more life into it

but overall, it was a great adventure and enjoyed it 9/10

Should name the game GRINDING instead. Game wants you to grind, but also don't wants you to grind. 

So you want to craft an item?
You need to have these.
To get these, you need to do those.
To do those, you need this item and that.
And repeat.

But wait!
If you're looking for bug's part, there's a chance that bug won't drop its' part?
Bro, it was using its' part trying to kill me and still has it when died.

So I just need to kill it again right?

You guys took this game in the entirely wrong direction. If I could request my funds back, I would.

An excellent take on the Survival genre, unexpectedly scratching the same kind of itch as Unknown World's Subnautica.

The combat & parrying system is fun & satisfying, there's lots of perk/mutation customization to make flexible playstyles as well. Base building is incredibly intuitive with lots of ways to decorate & fortify. It's got multiplayer so that's another great plus. Another massive bonus is that there's an entire mode devoted to creating your own custom maps when the base game isn't enough for you; build & share your own backyards to your hearts content.

I was also impressed by the amount of really nice quality-of-life features, like being able to easily move fully constructed building parts without having to deconstruct & rebuild them. Using resources from nearby chests & containers instead of needing them in your inventory for crafting & building is another nice feature. You can also name chests & set them to receive resources from your inventory automatically at the push of a hotkey for easy sorting. Arrows that don't break after a single use, as well as being able to automatically pick them up by walking over them outside of combat instead of having to manually pick them all up, & markers for shot arrows + thrown spears to help you locate them. You also get 3 hotbars to cycle through for being able too quickly swap between tools, weapons, food, water, consumables, & even armor sets. I'm sure I've missed a couple of things while listing them off, but again very impressed by the number of quality-of-life features Grounded boasts.

One of the only critical critiques I have of the game is how *very* late-game, trying to complete absolutely everything, including entirely optional content, can become quite a grind for rare resources, especially if you're trying to kit out multiple people in multiplayer.

I'll say that Grounded has definitely earned its price-tag ($39.99 as of writing), but if you ever see it on sale, definitely consider grabbing it while you can. It has a patchy history of having fairly infrequent discounts, so don't miss out if you can nab a bargain on this excellent survival game.

This game is really enjoyable for most Co-op situations and has a calm relaxing play-thought. The game isn't so hard on the eyes and the graphics and design in faunas and floras. It has it's tiny world where everything so small are a whole new world to see throught the eyes of a smallest spec of individual.

The game has some good ideas, but the execution is lacking. Completing this game felt like a chore, but had some interesting moments. Had two playthroughs, 76h48m not completed and 56h39m completed. Did not get 100% because requirements are insanely difficult. Played solo. Rated 6/10.
Pros:
+ The world and setting. The idea of surviving in a miniature world is quite appealing, and is a break from typical fantasy worlds, that this genre has abundance of. Surviving in a backyard of the regular (not really) house that also manages to have different biomes is a very interesting idea on paper, and this implementation of the world was done quite good.
+ Enemy types and locations. They have also managed to do quite a good job of making regular boring insects like ants and spiders into varying enemies with different types, making  them diverse and interesting.
Cons: 
- Combat and game balance. Even with Tier 3 weapons, mutations and buffs applied, the game is quite difficult. You are forced to carry several weapons with different types in order to even be able to handle most of enemies. Ranged weapons are very inefficient, and you are forced to have a mixed build to survive. Armor bonuses are mostly miserable, and even with all molars applied, you are very squishy and vulnerable to enemies in the upper yard.
 - Game optimization and graphics. The game runs quite poorly, and on a system with 5800x and 6600XT, the CPU and GPU are struggling and overheating, which they don't in most modern AAA games that are more graphically impressive. But even with poor optimization, the graphics look quite bland. They did not implement the most modern version of FSR2, only having outdated FSR, which shows their negligence and laziness, given how long ago FSR2 came out.
- Progression system. Most Tier 1 and Tier 2 weapons and armor suck. Most mutations are useless. The actual useful resources are immensely hard to obtain, and the difficulty slope goes high very fast after obtaining Tier 1 equipment, and the jump to Tier 3 is much harder than that. The only somewhat useful weapons are obtained at the endgame, which doesn't make any sense. Molars are they only way to increase your stats in the classic RPG sense, and finding them is a chore, not something you like to do.

I'd play this game through multiple times and look forward to a sequel someday.

[h1]One of the best co-op experience you can get[/h1]

From the art direction to the gameplay, everything is absolutely amazing in this game. I strongly recommend this game with friend, considering some fights are extremely hard alone. 
With Grounded, you get:
- an amazing open-world where the exploration is key: you don't have a map full of ? to guide the player. You see something in the distance, you go there and see for yourself what's there.
- A good base-building game: it's a joy to gather resource and build your camp in this game. You start with a small campfire and end up with a huge base.
- Gigantism: you feel very small in this garden and it's well done. (Beware of the spiders)
- Gorgeous game: beautiful art direction and amazing music

Thanks Obsidian for this gem

TL:DR These developers are the lowest scum at the bottom of a septic tank and definitely don't deserve your money.

Grounded is a game famously notorious for its absolute garbage net code, making multiplayer a profoundly frustrating experience, as well as the developers doing everything in their power to push anyone and everyone off of their game. From the very beginning to post release Grounded is a frustrating experience filled with every bug, glitch, and crash you can imagine. The netcode is so god awful it will have your friends ripping their hair out and uninstalling before you can make it halfway. 

The bosses are hyped up more than Jesus Christ himself and then turn out to be an extremely mediocre fight with absolutely no substance. In almost every case, the bosses aren't even something you want to set out to fight as nothing they drop is anywhere close to endgame gear. [spoiler] In fact, the Infected Broodmother fight which was made impossibly soul crushing on purpose as the developer was told by the team "Do your worst" is the gift that keeps on giving. Spend weeks trying to min max your way through this fight while learning to perfect parry attacks faster than your parry animation is. After you beat her realize you didnt get enough materials for literally anything because "Do your worst" and do it again. Finally, unlock the boss armor and weapon (The final gear of Grounded) and see that it is literally laughably awful as the developers made it complete garbage.  [/spoiler] Just one more nice middle finger to their entire fan base as they headed out the door. 

Every step of Grounded fills you with the realization that this buggy piece of trash was rushed out the door by the worlds biggest a-hole developers who wanted nothing more than to flip off the community they were striving to build. It's honestly anyone's guess as to why these monsters would intentionally self-sabotage themselves to get back at everyone else but here we are. 

This game isn't worth your hard earned cash. Don't even play it for a laugh or as a joke. It plain out sucks.

This is probably the most annoying game I've ever played, but I keep playing it. Your character CONSTANTLY gets stuck on everything because you are so small. You have to keep backing up and readjusting your path over and over and over. Also, the game progression will have you running all over the yard, back and forth and back and forth. It is quite grindy at times and when in third person view you can't seem to hit anything you aim at unless you get right on top of it and aim straight down, which is weird and... annoying. Yet, I still keep playing. Call me a masochist.
Multiplayer in this game was really good, had lots of fun playing it with friends. Would recommend.

I have followed and played this game since the early days of the early access version. I have watched it grow and develop into a wonderful game, filled with quests and an engaging story. 

However, sadly that which I admired most of the game (it's true visual beauty and design) has gone down in quality. The updates are focused on bug fixes and adding more content, yet there isn't much done to fix the visual environmental issues. The graphics lowered in quality, because of (I think) an update. I used to sit back and stare in wonder at the sights the game gave me, such as gorgeous sunsets on the branch of a massive acorn tree. Now I glance in sadness as most of the game seems like my life without my glasses, blurry. Even the baseball at the beginning doesn't show any detail. 

I'd suggest waiting till it is on sale before buying it. I hope the devs fix the visual aesthetic and bring back the beauty of the yard they created.

Game Completion: ✅

(My Input: I rarely finish Survival games but this one I felt the need to. Absolutely brilliant game, super fun and intriguing story. I managed to complete all optional bosses excluding one [spoiler] the infected broodmother [/spoiler]. The game is very player friendly too. A lot of the game you are guided along and don't really feel the need for using guides or such as a lot of information about certain enemies state their weaknesses and resistances, allowing the player to much more easily decide the weapons and tools you may need for a certain fight or objective. Another thing I felt kept me going was (as I was playing on Medium difficulty) that dying didn't feel like too much of a loss. When you die, all of your loot doesn't just scatter around the ground, potentially losing everything. You still kept weapons, tools, armour, etc and only dropping resources gathered. This is a lot more friendly to a generic player who wants to enjoy the game without the unnecessary need to consistently return to their death point as all you may have dropped on death was a single piece of uncooked bug meat. Progression feels surprisingly fun as well. Not all games feel like this to be completely fair. The main thing I have with survival games that makes me not finish them as often as I should, is simply for the fact that I feel like I am doing all this hardwork and grinding to - in the end - achieve nothing out of the story. Now don't get me wrong, this game does have a bit of grinding too it, but in comparison to any other game in this genre, it is a lot more enjoyable in the sense that you feel like you have made a difference being able to... [Spoiler] For Example, get the required resources needed to craft a better shovel that allows you to farm a single resource to change the way a biome reacts in the world (Plugging the haze with chewing gum) [/Spoiler]. Every resource you scan unlocks new recipes, new recipes unlocks new resources, new resources allows you to craft those recipes to access new zones and so on. Each zone has a unique feel to it as well. This game is brilliant and is so enjoyable I feel that if you enjoy survival games you'd love this game. So much fun and I highly recommend it!)

[h2] I was going to give this game a hard recommend but while trying to get 100% I found out that you need to grind out drops that barely drop from EVERY CREATURE IN THE GAME.  For reference I got 98% completion. [/h2]

Grounded is good and has a great atmosphere and solid combat mechanics but most of the game requires a lot of grinding.  I've played survival games before and Grounded has to be one of the grindiest that I have played.  

Many weapons and armors require you to kill and farm for hours on end just to obtain.  Getting materials to upgrade your weapons or armor to be more effective requires deep searching of the many different caves and tunnels within the Backyard. 
Initially exploring is fun and exciting, you are discovering a new (but familiar) world that is full of wonder and mystery.  After the thousandth time walking through the same patch of grass or killing the same spider, it gets old.  91 hours in, I got tired of grinding.  
Ziplines do exist in this game and do help with fast travel, but it is a chore to zip along them for hundreds of times while grinding out objectives.

I really would like to recommend this game, but some of the design choices in this game get boring and lackluster after a while.


[b] Tl;dr Grounded is pretty fun for the first few times you do something, but then it turns into a grind fest that will eat through your time. [/b]

Grounded: the game that finally answers the age-old question, "What if Honey, I Shrunk the Kids was a survival game?" And let me tell you, it's every bit as awesome as you'd expect. The graphics are so gorgeous, you'll find yourself getting emotionally attached to a blade of grass. And feeling small? Oh, you'll feel small alright. It's like being a borrower in a world where the spiders are the size of SUVs and the dew drops are your personal swimming pools.

The game's packed with quality of life features that make surviving as a tiny human in a giant backyard not just doable, but genuinely enjoyable. Crafting? Smoother than your grandpa's old jazz records. Base building? More satisfying than popping bubble wrap.

And the multiplayer? Flawless. It's like the developers actually understand that we want to play with our friends without needing a degree in server management. It's the perfect game to remind you that size really doesn't matter, especially when you're armed with a spear and your friend is screaming because they're being chased by an ant.

Honestly, there's nothing bad to say about Grounded. It's a tiny world of wonders where every mushroom feels like a skyscraper and every backyard critter is a boss fight. So grab your magnifying glass and your bravest pals, because it's time to get small and live large!

Honey I Shrunk the Kids meets the survival/crafting genre of games!

Starting out seems a little slow, some inhabitants are just "RUN" whenever you see them until you can unlock more recipes and understand strategies to dealing with them, but once you get over that progression is solid and paced only as much as you want to progress it. There are a lot of nifty 'tips and tricks' that the game doesn't tell you the first time around and sure you can whip through the story/campaign relatively quickly without too much investment into the exploration or gathering of materials etc.

My partner and I love survival/crafting games and working together to problem solve and progress through them. If I were to critique one thing is the 'collectibles' mini games (Milk Molars/Mega Milk Molars, SCA.B schemes and Raw Science) need a little bit of tweaking when trying to locate them using the radar...and then being able to 'tick' them off the map for those of us who like to complete everything. 

All in all, a great little game that I thoroughly enjoy.

A Tiny Adventure with Giant Fun: A Review of Grounded

Rating: ★★★★☆

Introduction:
Grounded, developed by Obsidian Entertainment, takes players on an immersive journey into a backyard shrunken to the size of insects. This survival game combines elements of exploration, crafting, and teamwork, providing a unique perspective on the world from a minuscule point of view.

Graphics and Design (4/5):
One of the standout features of Grounded is its stunning visual design. The attention to detail in the miniature world is impressive, with lush foliage, towering grass blades, and giant everyday objects transformed into colossal obstacles. The art style strikes a perfect balance between realism and whimsy, immersing players in the charm of being tiny explorers.

Gameplay Mechanics (4.5/5):
Grounded excels in its gameplay mechanics, seamlessly blending survival elements with a compelling narrative. Players must scavenge for resources, craft tools, and build shelters to survive the challenges of the backyard. The unique twist of insect-sized combat and interaction with everyday items provides a refreshing take on the survival genre.

The game introduces an intriguing arachnophobia mode, allowing players with arachnophobia to replace spiders with less-threatening creatures. This inclusive feature demonstrates a commitment to making the game enjoyable for a wider audience.

Exploration and Atmosphere (4/5):
The backyard setting serves as a captivating playground for exploration. From the towering oak tree to the murky depths of a soda can, Grounded encourages players to uncover secrets and adapt to the challenges posed by the miniature environment. The ambient sounds, from buzzing insects to distant lawnmower rumbles, contribute to the immersive atmosphere, enhancing the overall experience.

Multiplayer Experience (3.5/5):
While Grounded offers a cooperative multiplayer mode for up to four players, there are occasional hiccups in synchronization and connection stability. Nevertheless, the collaborative nature of multiplayer adds an extra layer of enjoyment, as players can strategize, build together, and face the miniature world as a team.

Storyline and Quests (3.5/5):
Grounded introduces an engaging narrative with a science-fiction twist, involving mysterious experiments and an unraveling mystery. While the story adds depth to the game, the quest system can sometimes feel repetitive, with similar objectives and tasks. However, the ongoing updates from the developers promise additional content, potentially addressing this concern in the future.

Conclusion:
Grounded is a delightful and innovative take on the survival genre, offering a unique perspective on the world through the eyes of tiny adventurers. With its impressive visuals, engaging gameplay mechanics, and a promising foundation for future updates, Grounded is a must-play for fans of survival games seeking a fresh and imaginative experience.

I downloaded this game expecting a fun survival crafting game that I could play with friends with a cute environmental gimmick.  What I got was a well-designed game featuring a fabulous mashup of genres that just happens to have a solid survival crafting system incorporated into it. 

To date, I can count:
-Skyrim/Fallout/Breath of the Wild type map exploration and puzzle solving (and I have to say, it is an incredibly meticulously made map with tons of biomes, events, secrets, and more to discover. Well done Obsidian)
-Metroidvania-esque discovery (you unlock some new tool that allows you to explore new parts of old areas)
-Terraria-like armor and weapons mixed with the Fallout/Skyrim perk system makes for fun class builds.
- A solid combat system semi reminiscent of Sekiro/Dark Souls (if a little more simplistic and forgiving).
- A recently added map creation system reminiscent of Halo's Forge Mode that allows players to create their own levels. It's only been a month and it's amazing to see what the community has already created!

The sheer amount of effort it must have taken to develop this game into what it is today is incredible.  My friends and I haven't had this much fun in a survival crafting game in a long time.

While a few things still could use some additional polish (adding some additional rewards for exploring certain areas of the map, some quality of life improvements to the UI and crafting systems), this game is an incredibly well made game that I would consider to be complete at this point in development. Thankfully, the team over at Obsidian is planning to continue development for the game going into 2024, so I'm excited to see what else is added before they wrap up production and hopefully move on to making Grounded 2.

If you're a fan of the above genres, I would highly recommend this game. It's not perfect, but it's damn good, with more than enough content to be worth the full price tag (and definitely worth buying if it's on sale).

Amazing game to play alone or with friends like I did; definitely one of the top survival games right now on the market. My only complaint after beating the game with a 90% score was the combat balancing at the later game with fists, tank builds, archery and certain melee weapons falling extremely fall behind on how viable they were in multiplayer. Hopefully this gets fixed in the future with new builds and balancing but be warned combat will force you down specific paths and builds to complete objectives.

Let's talk about bugs.

Grounded has been a labor of love for over 3.5 years. Since day 1 release in early access on Xbox Gamepass, I've loved this game and spent thousands of hours fighting for my life (Sometimes...I actually win. haha). No really- If you're like me and you are arachnophobic, They've got a setting for that. Don't discount this game because of the spiders. 

You start at the "Kid Case" and venture out, realizing that you're friggen tiny- you've been reduced to a size so small you could literally die from a lawn mite- how annoying and scary is that? You better start building a base- because sooner or later, good ol' Wolfie the Wolf Spider is going to come across your path and sniff you out. And Wolfie doesn't like anyone. 

Through being nosey- you find a Robot named Burg.l. Burg.l.'s design has changed--- his modes used to include a "kill" mode during early access--- this is why the community will tell you that Burg.l... Burg.l. is Sus AF. You find out that you're basically the victim of science gone awry and the only person who can help you has gone missing! Oh no! But though completing quests, Conquering and powering up old laboratories hidden around the backyard that has now become your home, and good old combat with the locals - you will acquire the currency simply known as "raw science'. With said "Rawwww Sciennnnnnce" you can purchase upgrades for your base and weapons, hopefully to make it easier to tackle the next sector of the yard and it's inhabitants. {{DON'T KILL APHIDS- They are friends, not food!!!}} Ugh. I have to admit even the aphids are food sometimes and you'll feel incredibly guilty for eating them if you choose to make one your pet. 

Honestly, as a player who has been around since day one.. I can say I highly recommend this game. Believe me when I tell you that the Devs ARE listening (No really, they even stream every Wednesday on Twitch- and showcase the players in the community.). The amount of bugs they've fixed and quality of life improvements they tirelessly provide is astonishing and I don't believe I've ever seen another Dev team like it. They even let us scaredy cats turn the menacing spiders into angry almonds. Don't believe me? Try this game. You really really won't regret it. 

Oh. And use Hoops. She's amazing! jkjk. They all are- and the voice lines are pretty funny for a group of kidnapped teens.

I've played a ton of survival crafting games, and this one is my favorite out of all of them. It has a whimsical vibe and great sense of humor to it so it's not just existential dread on top of existential dread ad infinitum like some others in the genre. There's a lot to do, building is fun (without overly onerous physics rules), and the crafting and tech trees are extensive but easy to understand. The co-op is also implemented extremely well, and you can use the Shared World feature to play without the original host.

I played this in early early Early Access on Xbox Game Pass and wasn't impressed, but my friends convinced me to check it out again, and I'm really glad I did. It came a huge way since then.

Subnautica was the game that convinced me I could like the survival-craft-em-up genre, and I think Grounded is the game that finally convinced me that was a fluke.

I hate the grind most of all. To upgrade equipment past the first tier you'll be forced to take on enemies that are seemingly impossibly tough, and when you manage it (or cheese it) you find that the new equipment didn't even help that much. To get into places like The Haze you need a gas mask which requires you to take out stink bugs, which are hard to take out without the gas mask. The game is filled with such looping dependencies.

I've since read that the fighting mechanics are actually pretty nuanced, and if you know what you're doing most enemies can be taken out without too much trouble even if you're underequipped. Sadly, as far as I can tell, the game does a really poor job of communicating any of these mechanics to the player. My friends and I got to the black ant hill and had no idea how to get in other than to tank our way through the enemies, for instance, and I later read that we [spoiler]could equip full red ant armor and be ignored by red ants, so I presume the same is true for black ants[/spoiler], but how the heck were we supposed to know that? I mean yeah, it kinda makes sense, even if ants don't work that way in real life, but this is a video game where water fleas are aggressive predators of things 3x their size so whatever. Like, you'll have the character tell me 10x an hour that "The nose knows" but never say anything about how maybe the [spoiler]ants could be fooled by wearing a suit made from their corpses[/spoiler]?

I don't like the idea that I should have a wiki open to play the game in a reasonable way.

Another issue I have with the game is the tonal dissonance of celebrating the wonders of nature on this scale while demanding the player kills non-aggressive creatures in mass numbers for resources. We were reluctant to murder red ants, which left us alone if we left them alone, and ladybugs, but these are apparently some of the best ways to get early game kit.

Everything degrades and eventually breaks, but that's not too bad because most things being repairable, assuming you have the right resources to hand. But otherwise I find that the game too many resources and different kinds of crafting station to make what are very small incremental improvements. Even when you finally get a second tier hammer and can gather all those molars you've been stumbling across (only some of which get mapped apparently?) the rewards are similarly tiny.

Basically, it seems like the game was designed to take a really long time to play, mostly through the tedium of the crafting loop, and I'm not a fan of that kind of design.

To be fair, a lot of this can be mitigated through difficulty settings, but since I'm playing with other people who are apparently having a much better time than I am, I don't want to try and convince them to drop it from the default.

I will also give the game credit for its arachnophobia settings. One of the group I'm playing with would have a much harder time without it.

Ultimately I can't recommend the game because I, personally, don't like a lot of what it is. But if you're reading all of the above and wondering why I'm whining so much then this game might be up your alley.

Grounded is a game where you play a teenager who wakes up shrunk down to a size where blades of grass look like trees. You must find a way to survive the environment, battle bugs that are now giants to you, and figure out how and why you were shrunk and then find a way to get back to normal. The story is light-hearted, and kind of goofy in an entertaining way. I started playing solo, but a friend picked up the game and I am enjoying it a lot more in co-op mode. The crafting and base-building is easy to get into. You occasionally get raided by bugs and it can be fun to defend your base, but sometimes it can be a hassle if you're out harvesting materials and you need to run back. The exploration of the yard is fun in itself as it seems like a decent sized open world (as much as an overgrown backyard can be). Combat is simple, with just an attack and block, but can be somewhat challenging based on the foe and their resistances/weaknesses. 
I'd definitely recommend this if you're looking for something with a friend, though not absolutely required.  Be warned, this game has a lot of bugs. And most are going to attack you.

first played this game on my console after the first week that the game went into its beta phase, a time when the end game content could be reached within a couple of hours, and the building was as basic as walls, roofs, floors, and a few pieces of decor, with the brood mother just being a larger wolf spider that just sat on top of the Frisbee, and seeing how far the game has come today is amazing, the games story is incredible and fun, with an insane amount of content to explore, I heavily recommend this game, though I recommend playing with friends, and it is incredibly unforgiving to play on your own
its really fun
Brilliant game. Perfect pacing. The team who made this game did a great job making you feel like a small dood in a big garden.

Beginning of the game is honestly great I don't see any flaws with the progression between the labs and all of that leading up to the lab under the shed, but the endgame after that can get a little bit repetitive especially if you are going to need different builds for different bosses that you are trying to beat in order to 100% the game. For example, a spicy build is ideal for the Broodmother, but a sour build is ideal for black widows. After the grind for different endgame resources, the game becomes far more intriguing to play similar to how it was at the start. End-game you just beat the final bosses, and then finish exploring the yard and building your base. Only tedious thing left is getting all of the golden cards as it is probably the most time consuming part of the game in my opinion. All in all this has been one of my favorite survival games that I have played, and although I am not finished at the time of this review, I have had a blast playing it so far and don't plan to stop until I get that 100% achievement.

EDIT 1: Now that I have completed the story, defeated all of the bosses, and gotten every achievement, I have to say that this game is very enjoyable. After finishing the main story, it got somewhat intimidating and hard to progress, but after you grind resources for a couple hours and deck out your build for the boss you are going to fight, it becomes rather easy. Every boss has a weakness and there are plenty of guides on Steam showing some of the best builds you can get for each boss and what weaknesses / strengths they each had. After having the right class for each boss and plenty of heals, buffs, etc, the only one that was particularly difficult to me was the Infected Broodmother. She took me 4-5 tries to kill, but I felt a sense of accomplishment afterwards. The Infected Broodmother has 3 lives, unlike the other 3 bosses which only have 1. Each phase gets quicker and deals more damage, which made it tricky. After some trial and error, I had defeated her and the main game was done. Afterwards I had to 100% it. Going around the yard and getting all of the collectibles and Milk Molars that I had missed wasn't terrible, but it took me a good 10-15 hours which got boring towards the end. Overall, this game is great and although I have beaten the base game I would still like to build a really nice base in my main save since I have been living in a little shack for the entirety of my playthrough, and I am also interest in the new sandbox mode as there seem to be some cool maps on that.

Singleplayer: 8.6/10 - Can get boring but can also be easier to progress
Mutliplayer: 8.7/10 - Sometimes slower progression but a great time with friends
Completionist: 9.2/10 - Most games now have annoying or tedious achievements to 100% the game, but aside from all of the collectibles which most don't mind, most of the achievements can be completed from playing the main game and there are a few fun ones like scoring a basketball shot from 30m, etc. mixed in.

Yeah, so this is good. Like, really, really good. Yesterday, I died of a heatstroke in a freakin’ kiddie sandbox of all places, and the simple fact that I did gave me pause. What a bizarre way to perish. I don’t think I could achieve this feat in many other games.

So, I got this on sale, and this was one of the best investments I've done via Steam. My group of friends and I immediately fell in love with this gem of a game. I sank in twenty hours in the first three days upon getting this, I shit you not. Rare are the games that make me love struck on first play, but this one managed. It's such a joyous moment to experience that weird "oh crap, this one'll be good" moment.

Grounded takes an amazing twist on the whole survival genre. Normally, these kinds of games have gotten me a bit jaded, but Grounded does it a clever way, and dayum, it feels so fresh. The fact that your playable character has been shrunken to the size of a flea turns resource gathering in over its head. What seems obvious in other games (chop trees, mine rocks, pick berries, explore nearby caves) suddenly becomes a lot more esoteric in Grounded - yet it still always makes sense. I will forever remember my first time playing, chuckling at the idea that freaking blades of grass now acted as your core building material. How utterly silly. How utterly original.

The map is thrilling to explore. The base building is simple yet intricate. Grinding for crafting never feels like a chore. Journeying to collect resources is always fun. Stumbling upon new "biomes" make for some scary new challenges. Combat is fair and well thought-out.

The game just lets you be creative. There are normal “paths” to explore new portions of the map, but you can always bypass them by just bridging and building towers over to them. You won’t be prevented from cheating your way into cool new territories just because you got a little bit clever. Man, how awesome is that?

Anyway. Shit’s fun. I know for a fact that this is a game I’ll definitely cross the 100 hours threshold.

Grounded is a fun game for a small group. I played this with a friend and my two kids and we had a lot of fun overall.  We made a point of exploring all of the main story line Labs together but even if you are not present, you still get to read the story text on-screen and the group reaps the benefits as a team.  For this reason, the game excels as a multiplayer game for a small group.  The Xbox accounts were cumbersome to set up, but worth it to play. The multiplayer game is also stored on the cloud so anyone in your party can host, or even play it solo if no one else is online at the time.

I put 29 hours into the game before we completed it (the major storyline.) There is still plenty to do afterwards, hidden areas and extra bosses that we never even found. My kids probably have twice the hours as I do.

I also really enjoyed that this world was not procedural generated. Every nook and crannie was hand done and done very well wit a lot of thought put into game progression. It is open world in the same sense that zelda is open world: You can go anywhere as long as you can survive and some areas are blocked unless you have the proper item.  The game story and quests also coax you in the right direction.

Overall the building system can be a tad irritating at times. But easy enough to navigate.  Crafting is pretty simple and the way the game scales felt just right.

We played in Mild difficulty and the game felt mostly easy until the final battle, which I wont give it away, but I'll say that it took us three tries to complete and made us feel like we really earned those end credits and involves some actual prior planning and strategy. I can see why only about 4% of players complete the game. The last battle would be very hard on your own.

My kids love it, particularly my 10 year old son.  My 8 year old daughter found it fun, but mostly played because her brother did.  

The game is very "clean". nothing rude, no nudity or profanity, all of the death is around insects and so as far as that goes, not much to be concerned over.

The spit and polish on the game is quite good. Graphics are perfect for the game type and target audience, no major glitches were discovered.

As a grown up, I found the game enjoyable. Playing in a group of 4 meant it never felt grindy as we sort of split up a lot of the tasks and there is a lot of leeway for personal exploration since the group shares the major finds and accomplishments.

In summary: I would not recommend this game as a solo play unless you want a real challenge and are willing to put in 50-100 or more hours to get it, but that might be just what some folks want. You can tell that the game was very much designed with 2-4 players in mind. I purchased it (along with two other copies for the kids) on sale but I'd rate it as being worth full price.

Such a cute game!  
Pros:
The building system is nice, I like being able to lay out blueprints for my structures. I also like the appearance of the structures & placeables.  Weapons & armor system with the various perks is cool and it does have an upgrade system for them that feels balanced but also has a bit of grind to it.  You can craft and build automatically pulling resources from storage containers in the vicinity which is a really nice feature.
The shared save feature allows me to share a world with friends essentially giving us a private server for free.

Cons:
Only 4 players at a time in game, even just a couple more would be really nice.
Limit of 2 shared worlds per account - I thought it was 3 but it won't let me create my 3rd..

Grounded is an impressive survival game.

Open World game set in a garden, which may seem small at first, but the map is actually big. It's a base-building game with lots of crafting. The story it tells isn't long, but there is a lot to discover in the game. Our opponents are the bugs of the garden, fighting a fierce battle for their lives...
Personally I recommend the game in Co-op, but I picked up the Gold cards on my own.

Currently all Achivements are completed in the game, hopefully there will be an update with more content. Solo map has 2 bases and 4 outposts built for easier movement.

It's a good game in it's genre and definitely deserves the praise it's gotten. When so many other games in the Open World Survival Crafting genre skew toward 18+ content, this is a nice PG game to play with the kids.

One caveat, while the game does support P2P multiplayer, there is no support or running a dedicated server and judging from the community forums, not something that is likely to be added soon if ever. The game runs great in a local LAN setting, but can lag substantially when playing with friends who are spread far apart. Just something to be aware of if you plan on playing with friends internationally or on opposite coasts.

It's a good game, but unfortunately extremely unpolished. If not the tons of bugs, it could compete for the best open world survival craft game ever. I recommend giving it another year or two and watching whether the devs finish this Early Access quality product.

Note that the game is rather difficult and I can't imagine playing it solo - you will need at least one friend to play with.

[h1]There is a number of good ideas and features...[/h1]

... however a lot of them are lacking or only work sometimes:
[list]
[*] You can unpack your entire backpack to nearby chests that have matching items. This can be controlled per chest (so that you don't unpack your arrows to the chest which has more arrows), however it cannot be controlled per item (i.e. you cannot lock an item in your inventory). Also, this "hot deposit" feature doesn't work with "wood logs" carried on the shoulder.
[*] When holding a repair tool, damaged buildings are highlighted in red - however it only works sometimes; and also, sometimes it highlights damaged buildings even if you don't hold the repair tool in your hand.
[*] Crafting and building first draws resources from nearby chests - no more running around the base to bring the resources to the crafting table. However, sometimes I would prefer if it drew resources from the backpack first, and there is obviously no setting for this.
[*] You can create a shared world with chosen friends, so that any of them can be a host (and play without the others). However, the game requires Microsoft Xbox account which is somewhat unreliable - I had a number of disconnects despite having Internet and Steam connection. Also, already hosted game very often doesn't show up in available games, and I have to join it by selecting a friend on Steam and clicking "join game".
[*] Your arrows and thrown spears get a marker on the HUD, however it frequently doesn't show at all.
[*] Walking over arrows picks them up. Sometimes.
[/list]

[h1]And here comes the bad stuff...[/h1]

The most frequent bug is insects getting totally stuck between grass, stones or even inside the walls. Not sure if it's a bad thing, because I can't imagine fighting with them melee.

[b]There is a lot of interface and key mapping bugs:[/b]
[list]
[*] Open chest can only be closed with ESC, not with TAB, unlike the inventory.
[*] Keys shown at the bottom of the screen sometimes don't work at all (or they do something else like ESC opening a menu instead of closing a radial selection), and you have to press the button using a mouse.
[*] Items quite often cannot be interacted with - e.g. the object gets highlighted, you get the info "press E to pick up / hold X to destroy", and while holding X works fine, pressing/holding E does nothing.
[/list]

[b]There is a number of "we are too lazy to implement it" features:[/b]
[list]
[*] Only one person can be looking in the chest at the time.
[*] No compass or mini map.
[*] Position (and facing direction) of players doesn't refresh on the map - you have to reopen the map to see the up to date information.
[*] Mutations (aka skills) and status effects lack any meaningful explanations, so get ready for things like "Block more." or "The fungus (...) lends its power to your unarmed attacks.". No description provides any numbers of how big the bonuses actually are - get ready to play with the wiki open.
[*] Charged bow shot mean to keep a bow fully charged for an unknown amount of time. There is no indicator whether your shot will be "charged" or "uncharged".
[*] Building requires placing a blueprint and then bringing resources to it to actually construct it. Would be nice if buildings destroyed by insects were actually leaving the blueprint behind, so that it's easier to reconstruct it.
[*] Audio is muted when game is not focused and there is no setting to change it.
[*] Number of insects reuse models, textures, sounds and even names. So get ready for things like Ladybug and Ladybird, which in real world are two names of the same insect, but in this game are totally different enemies.
[*] Trail Marker buildings which display a map waypoint, show their names only on HUD but not on the map.
[*] When another player is gliding on the dandelion tuft, you cannot see the tuft, they just look as if they were falling.
[/list]

[b]There is a number of "why would you ever do this" issues:[/b]
[list]
[*] Map marker placed manually disappears after time.
[*] Searching crafting recipes works only in an active category - and there is 10 categories...
[*] When deconstructing an object, sometimes ingredients drop lose on the ground, and sometimes are placed all in a single bag. Would be nice if they were actually placed in the player backpack (or shoulder in case of "wood logs").
[*] After one quest you get an NPC that flies around a random player and annoys them - it doesn't fight, and often gets in the way of shooting.
[*] Some buildings, when snapping, can be rotated by 45 degrees, others only by 90.
[*] Resource nodes drop fake items that disappear after a few seconds, so you have to wait before you can pick the real items.
[*] Your flying pet that follows you can knock you out of a zipline.
[/list]

[b]And finally, there is a number of "how the f*** is this even possible" bugs:[/b]
[list]
[*] One player interacting with objects in the world disrupts other players' interface. It causes blinking, scrolls lists to the top, prevents writing etc.
[*] After encounter with a fish I was being pushed and thrown in random directions - at first I thought it's a water flow, but this continued even on land until I restarted the game...
[*] Another time I got an empty map marker displayed in the centre of the screen - until I restarted the game...
[*] When busting certain candies, the FPS drops to around 3.
[*] Light from the headlight is displayed in the world differently depending on whether I am in the first person or third person view. Makes me wonder how it shows for other players...?
[*] Some buildings are placed not where they are showing before placing.
[*] Frequent desyncs between the clients and the host - clients often see items in different places than they really are, and as a result cannot interact with them.
[*] Collectables proximity detector sometimes gets stuck and keeps showing the same signal strenght despite moving around.
[*] The expiry time of food stored in the fridge keeps running and shows the correct value only once you transfer it to your backpack.
[/list]

[b]Oh, and there are obviously tons of bugs when building:[/b]
[list]
[*] Sometimes the blueprint shows in blue, yet you cannot place it anyway.
[*] Sometimes objects are obstructing each other when they shouldn't; another time they intersect each other just fine.
[*] Sometimes if you move the object, you cannot place it back where it was (and there is snapping).
[*] Sometimes support doesn't work, and buildings flow in the air.
[*] Or sometimes they fall despite having support.
[*] Sometimes two buildings are supporting each other, preventing you from moving either of them.
[*] Sometimes an object cannot be deconstructed because it claims that it supports something, even though there is nothing nearby.
[*] And so on...
[/list]
