Really loved this game, the yard at ant-scale is such a fun environment for an open-world survival game like this. The graphics and colors are vibrant, and I really dug the bizarre bug-punk aesthetic to all the "technology" you create.

It's been a while since I've played one of these types of games, but the quality-of-life improvements are very much appreciated. Building, copying buildings, rapid-assembly are all a breeze, and it makes creation fun. I particularly liked the base-defense mechanic, as it tends to partially destroy you base, requiring you to repel the bugs and rebuild. It keeps the survival aspect fresh.

Also appreciated the comfiness mechanic, as you are given many reasons for putting together a nice-looking, lived-in location. The fact that you can build essentially anywhere in the game is very cool, and I wish every game like this allowed you to do so.

Story is charming, I liked Dr. Wendell in particular. I could've done with more story progression, especially on the Ominent side, but the dream sequences were cool and evocative. I appreciate how this game never loses sight of the fact that you are tiny, you are at the very bottom of the food chain, and the human world is terrifying. Having the largest living creature you regularly encounter be a crow that is utterly oblivious to your existence is very cool.

I have a few gripes. The final achievement (getting 100%) has now become impossible to get since the latest patch, as it requires you to get a 1% drop from every type of bug in the game, including bosses. That's just absolutely absurd. It took 640 of one type of bug for me to get one of those. It's disappointing to get 99% completion, and have it require months of real-time grinding to get 100%. Nobody should attempt that.

The other issue is the hardiness of the bugs, which starts to get annoying, even when you're using optimal equipment and damage type. With good equipment, you should be able to kill a thing in three or so hits. 6-10 just gets tedious. There are also far too many ladybug larva in the late game, which gets annoying.

Those aside, I absolutely adored playing this title, and I look forward to each new content update. The Infected Broodmother was a fantastic addition, and I look for the next challenge.

full of bugs.
-non-host players will see buildings of other players  as incomplete when master has them completed, meaning your client will attempt to go through them then teleport randomly when master tells you you shouldn't have passed through.
-non-host players will see MANY water bubbles bugged in the air after host player as farmed them, making the watering experience frustrating for non-hosts.

tl;dr: 9/10 - A charming Honey I Shrunk the Kids themed survival game. 

This game is similar to Valheim in in many ways; format, quality/stability and gameplay loop. However, the themeing and 3d modelling are far better.

The format is limited to 4 players per server, each player inhabiting one of the four playable teenagers. Your gear will be saved to your steam account, and each time you log in you will be able to select whichever character you'd like to have decked out in your kit. Singleplayer and Multiplayer are both available. There is no Dedicated Server mode, so make sure to have whoever has the highest performance computer host the game.

The quality and stability of this game are great. No mesh issues, the AI is modern, no obvious problems with misbehaving items or abilities.

The gameplay loop is what you would expect for the genre. The farming aspect is kept light. You'll find yourself gathering resources, building a base, fighting bugs and trying to figure out how to get back to normal size.

What could be improved?
End-game travel gets to be a lot. It started to feel like DayZ where 70% of the game was running.

Progression-gated itemization leads to some quality-of-life items only being available for a couple hours of campaign gameplay.

What are the highlights?
The 3d modelling in this game is imaginative and well-executed. If you used Sap and an acorn-top to build your item, then you'll see both of those resources in the finished and placed model. It's adorable, looks amazing, and provides a good deal of immersion to the experience.

The building system is a great implementation of what other survival games provide with some added improvements.

What could be added?
Late-game travel concerns can be addressed in many ways. Many games use either ridable mounts or teleportation. While adding a teleporter item would be easy for implementation, Taming is one of my favorite Survival game systems.

I've played a lot of survival crafting games, and honestly I was very unhappy with this one. It looks like it would be a fun experience and with the art style perhaps even beginner gamer friendly. I tried to play with my friend who is not a very hardcore 'gamer', as it seemed like a nice way to bring them into the hobby. It was awful and ultimately more frustrating rather than fun. 

I'm updating this review as we tried to return to it to see if it gained some polish and fun.

Short answer: No.

Realistically, this should be called 'Grinded'. Often in survival games there's a bit of a grind loop, especially if you want to build some neat stuff. This is totally fine and helps make you have a sense of accomplishment. The problem is, it never ends. It never feels like you achieved anything in this game, you never have figured anything out, you've never succeeded. 

Combat is a slog, every enemy even with upgraded weapons in armor is a health sponge. Unlocking new items often requires strange and exotic parts for no apparent reason other than to make it more difficult and pad out its lackluster story and play time. 

Save your money and play something better like the Forest, The Long Dark, or Green hell.

For a work in progress, this game is fantastic. I like that it uses the Unreal engine. The gameplay experience is smooth now, compared to before, but with each update, major and minor fixes are introduced, as well as content. It is pretty fun to play with your friends and the more the merrier.

I do recommend you purchase this game and get a copy for a friend of yours to go at it together!

Updated Review:

The game is so much better and I still recommend it. They continue to improve the game with free updates and are fixing glitches. I was able to successfully continue an older save from 1 year ago. Right now my favorite part is the ability to share your world with a friend who can come online to do stuff while you are offline, such as base building and resource gathering (that's what I do) which makes it easier to explore the map when you don't have to keep worrying about the same resources.

Grounded does a lot of things right, but drops the ball hard in a few critical areas as a fun solo experience. In a nutshell, the game is a slog to play.

Combat is a slow affair of block/parry, attack in the window while the enemy is stunned, wait for stamina to regen, heal, repeat. Most enemies outside the starting area take 3 or 4 three-hit combo cycles minimum to go down with the weapons you'll be using when it's relevant to fight them for progression/resources (i.e. one tier below what the critter is since you need tier 2 critter parts to make tier 2 weapons/armor), which is about 20-30 seconds per critter. Creature hostility and density is high so there's a very good chance you'll be fighting 3 or 4 enemies at a time on a regular basis while traversing the map. On anything but mild difficulty the enemies also deal punishing amounts of damage to the player when they mess up, further slowing combat as the player will need to spend more time healing/running away/respawning.

Resource gathering is also tedious. Most of the resources for tools/equipment to progress the game come from hunting critters, meaning that even if you don't really enjoy combat you're forced into it to progress. Low % drop rate items from these critters (seriously, why do bees only drop stingers 20% of the time?) mean you'll be spending a LOT of time grinding kills. Base building also takes a vast amount of resources (which is understandable) but the lack of a way to increase inventory size (other than carry a few more planks) or use a mount/fast travel means the player spends even more time running back and forth dealing with overly hostile critters, further adding to the slog. For example, I've done so many trips to the hedge to get berry chunks, it's one of the most overused resources in the game and is only found in one corner of the map.

Then there's base raids. If you kill too many of a type of critter, they'll raid your base that you spent hours building and can quickly do a lot of damage. The game has no automated defenses, and flying enemies will glitch through walls and be a huge PITA. The game tells you none of this up front of course so you'll be fighting off swarms of mosquitoes as part of normal gameplay only to suddenly have them mount a raid on your base (seriously, mosquitoes aren't even territorial IRL and this makes absolutely no sense) and potentially destroy hours of your work. Of course this "feature" is enabled by default on ALL difficulty options and can only be turned off in a custom game mode which disables achievements.

I'm not even going to touch the endgame boss fights based on my experience so far with the story bosses, unless you've got amazing reflexes, pattern recognition and stamina for intense boss fights and have the time to "git gud" they're going to be a miserable experience for most players without a bunch of fully geared up friends.

In co-op these issues lessen as you have more firepower in a group of players to more quickly dispatch enemies, a larger group inventory to lessen the resource grind, and people to interact with to pass the time traversing the map. For solo play though, I've just been finding the game tedious.

I've given up on any achievements myself and just finally switched over to a custom game mode once the raids started coming. I made it through most of the story and that finally broke me. It's not worth it having to deal with that nonsense, and while I was in the custom game settings I pretty much turned off all the annoying features of the game (stamina, item durability, creature aggression) and knocked the creature health way down just so I can finish out the story and explore the areas of the map I've missed with minimal additional slog since the world design and story are the highlight of the game for me anyways. Then I'll probably hop into a creative map and just mess around with building for awhile like I used to do in Subnautica.

I know a lot of people gush about how great this game is, but honestly I found myself more and more disappointed the farther into the game I got with how much time I spent in combat I never really enjoyed in the first place.

I can't get enough of Grounded.

I have played on and off since early access in 2020 on console from xbox gamepass and have played every major update since. I finished the game at the 1.0 release and haven't touched the game since until about 2 weeks ago after I got a PC.

After playing the game on PC, I can say that Grounded is one of my top 10 favourite games of all time.

Combat, Weapons and Armour:
The combat system, with perfect blocking, is a fantastic way to reward players for learning attack patterns and timing parry's allowing good players to take on the toughest Insects with ease, creating that fun skill ceiling that makes you want to improve to become a Grounded combat master. Different insects have different weaknesses and resistances making the choice of weapon matter. Not only do each weapon type deal different types of damage, but there is also elemental damage as well adding another layer of choice and skill to killing insects. The armour and weapons get stronger the further you progress and all have unique mechanics to give them all a fresh feel and to keep the game play from feeling repetitive. And the layer of combat don't stop there, because there are buffs and debuffs that happen depending on the bug you are facing, so don't forget to eat a meal and drink a smoothie as these are ways to get extra buffs to help take down enemies easier. So weather you prefer shooting you're enemy with a bow made from wasps, or want the clobber them with a club made from ants, or maybe you want to slice them in two with a battleaxe made from candy, Grounded has got something for you.

Mutations:
Mutations are a game mechanic that work amazing with the core game adding extra abilities to the player for as long as the player chooses. you unlock different mutations throughout the game by doing different challenges around the yard. Want to run faster, mutation for that, want more hauling strength (carry more stuff), mutation for that, want to minions to fight for you, mutation for that. Mutations are a fantastic and integral addition to the game.

Story:
I will keep the story section spoiler free. The story progresses at a good pace with different data pieces to help piece together the story. I love how it gives the choice to the player on what to do, but guides them so you don't end up never progressing. As you play though the game, different areas of the map have locations you will visit and you get rewarded by unlocking items that will help you take on tougher insects. They really tried to make the story interesting with the players who want more from the story being able to search around for extra pieces of data, whereas if you just want to get through the main story stuff and speed through the progression, you can do that too. It doesn't hold your hand and baby you through the game, but doesn't require a wiki or youtube video to know what to do next. It's hard to talk about the story without spoiling it, so you will have to find out yourself if you play this game.

Exploration:
finding things to discover is easy because of how much the map is packed full of things to find, with raw science, milk molars, sca.b's, new resources, and much more which can give you upgrades, weapons, armour or other goodies. Landmarks can be found around the map and give you a reward for finding them which is a fun way to motivate people to explore the backyard. But if you weren't convinced to explore the backyard, you can find a plethora of different insects. From spiders, to beetles, to ants. Some insects fly, some crawl, and some swim. Some friendly, some neutral and some angry. The variety in insects makes the game so easy to sink hours into, learning and mastering the all the insects.

Building:
The building is easy to understand and has plenty of different things you can build, allowing for creativity. you could build whatever you want really. I'm currently building a basketball stadium because basketball is a playable sport (to a certain extent) in Grounded. Build yourself a base anywhere you like, just be careful because you may annoy the local insects. Building is what can make a play through of the game a long a fun process, giving you a reason to keep playing after you beat the game to 100%. But if gathering resources doesn't tickle your fancy, Grounded has a creative mode allowing you to build whatever you want right away.

Bosses:
I don't want to spoil any bosses because the feeling of walking into a fight not knowing whats coming is a thrilling experience you will get only once. The bosses are all unique, with some being optional and some tied to the story. After facing all of them I can safely say that fighting these bosses with not disappoint. Fighting these bosses give unique and powerful drops making it feel worth fighting the optional bosses. I was not disappointing when facing these almighty foes.

Extra challenge:
Last little thing to talk about is those who want a challenge. Although there is a hard difficulty (Whoa!), I like a real challenge. At the end of the game you receive a report card, it basically shows stats like "insects killed" and "Deaths". You also get a grade based on how much of the game you completed (including the optional stuff). So for those who are completionists like me, Grounded has a completionist challenge with a steam achievement tied to it.

Grounded will forever be a game I will look back on be glad I got to play it. I highly recommend you play this game.

[h1] Claco's Yappathon for Grounded [/h1]
Upon reading my previous review, I felt the need to quickly write an updated version since Grounded is one of my favorite games

[h3] Exploring the Backyard [/h3]
The exploration in the Backyard takes me back to my childhood when I would explore my backyard and imagine the many happenings of the vast yet tiny world beneath my feet. The many different Biomes found in the Backyard offer a distinct feel to the entirety of the map which, alongside the unique landmarks scattered around the map, assist in giving the player an easier time when traversing and finding their way around the map. 

[h3] Combat [/h3]
The combat in this game is centered around its blocking mechanic. All the mobs have a set of moves with each move having its own telegraph and if you can do a perfect block, the damage is negated. Each mob also has weaknesses and resistances that are found out upon PEEPing the creature which gives each weapon a time to shine in the player's arsenal. The different builds that can be created using combinations of weapons and mutations prevent the need to utilize any "meta" builds.

[h3] Recommended Difficulty [/h3]
I would recommend anyone confident in their ability to read enemy telegraphing to play this game in Whoa! difficulty, especially if they are playing with other people who have experience with similar games. I found Medium to be fairly relaxed and would recommend it for people who want to focus more on the exploration side without having to worry too much about combat. If you have no experience with any combat in games, you might want to set it to Mild difficulty.

[h3] Achievement Hunters [/h3]
For those who are a fan of getting 100% Steam achievements, this game is very reasonable in the difficulty of their achievements. If you encounter and defeat every mob, you will most likely already have around 80% of the achievements. The remaining ones would be finding every collectible which is a lot easier in Grounded compared to other games with similar "collect them all" achievements.

[h3] Conclusion [/h3]
All in all, I would highly recommend anyone who is a fan of open-world survival craft games to pick Grounded up. If you are someone with an interest in the genre but haven't been able to decide on which game to start with, Grounded would be a fantastic first pick. [b] (Also play it with friends!) [/b]

Speaking as someone who has loved Obsidian's games in the past, Grounded is a fantastic adventure game with plenty to see and do - base building, resource collecting and combat are all fun and interesting mechanics; and the visual style and creature design/animations are all excellent.

Speaking as a completionist, I would not recommend this game - it is nigh on impossible to obtain the 100% completion acheivement without the assistance of online guides/maps.
The requirements include the gold card death-drops of every single creature, which have a 1% drop rate regardless of how common or rare the creature is (except for bosses with 10%), rolled on spawn rather than death - has lead to me spending hours save-scumming to finally achieve this.
Additionally, there are unmarked Data Logs and Notes which are extremely hidden on the map and have no indication on the in-game scanner, and some that are in the natural progression path that are not very visible as you go through the location.

Without the good work done by online guides and the interactive map/checklists by Map Genie, I feel like 100%-ing this game would have taken double the time I spent on it, which already clocked in at 297 hours - and so unless the above issues are addressed, I would not recommend the game to people like myself who value the completionist aspect.

"Move the Goalposts"
phrase of goalpost
unfairly alter the conditions or rules of a procedure during its course. - Oxford Languages

 Grounded as of November 13th 2023, has moved the goalpost for achieving 100% completion of the game.
With the update, you now have to grind for "Gold Cards" for every single insect in the game. Gold cards have a 1% drop rate. Meaning if you did not finish the game prior to the 13th update, You now have to spend potentially hundreds of more hours grinding out that 1% for each of the 64 enemies in the game.

The community has asked after each minor update that they revert this decision but Obsidian buries their heads in the dirt. I cannot recommend this game to completionist or achievement hunters.

Grounded's unholy marriage of bad design and terrible quality control manages to create a uniquely unpleasant type of gameplay I can only describe as “evil”. Never before have I seen a piece of software so perfectly engineered to extract misery from its end user that even its many failures seem to advance its infernal ends.

How devilish to furnish your multiplayer game with netcode that causes consistent lag and then have the combat system centered around precise parry timings! How demonic to make players disconnect at random times, which causes their inventories to disappear if it happens while they're downed.  How diabolical to include an enemy that forces players to drop their weapons, build a physics engine that makes dropped items roll down the tiniest of inclines, then fail to fix a glitch that causes objects to clip into walls and become permanently inaccessible! A brilliant three step combination with devastating results! I stand in awe of the sheer maliciousness of it.

 It takes virtually no effort to make a game that is simply bad. Steam is inundated with garbage, made by people whose design philosophy starts and ends at stapling giant tits onto Unity assets. Obsidian laughs at such amateurs. 

An incompetent developer might create an open world survival game with no fast travel options, but an evil one will make the fast travel torturously slow, then add enemies that can attack players while they're using it. A bad developer might forget to include the option to split resource stacks, but an evil one will make sure it can only be done one item at a time. What's that? Grounded has functional stack splitting now? Oh, well I guess it only took a year after the game's full release to implement something that existed in Minecraft over a decade ago.  

And it goes on and on like this! No rest for the wicked. Platforming in first person (or having to deal with the terrible third-person camera). Underwater combat. Rapid weapon degradation. Horrible boss design. Annoying flying enemies that poison you and run away to heal themselves. Tedious late game farming to fully upgrade equipment. Achievements locked behind another insufferable grind (added in the latest series of updates, just to make sure players weren't having too much fun).

Okay, I'm done mincing words. Enough is enough. I despise Grounded. It is one of the worst multiplayer experiences of my entire life. A broken, horrific abomination that suckers you in with its clever premise and charming presentation all the while slowly draining you of your happiness. It is the abattoir of fun. A game so bad I would pay to forget that I'd ever played it. A clear indication that developers need their own version of the Hippocratic Oath. I cannot quantify how many Fallout: New Vegases Obsidian would need to make in recompense for this atrocity.

A touching story, with a vast variety of things to do, areas to explore and items to collect, theres no doubt how fun this game is. The backyard is the crucial core of this game, its large exploration allows for players to experience major parts of this game alongside getting creative and building however they please, opportunities are endless. Apart from the very concerning story regarding young children and their somehow unfortunate mishap of being scientific guinea pigs, the story is exciting and touching at its core, definitely something I enjoyed experiencing for the first time.

Enemies are tough and bosses even more so, but the ecosystem in which Grounded provides allows players to constantly kill innocent bugs at their liesure for whatever they may need, just don’t challenge the creepy crawlies until your sure you can survive! Its enjoyable mechanics, exploration, quests, building, item collection and monumental areas surrounding the backyard truely unlock a fun and exciting experience for players, one that will stick with them especially if its their first time.

So, unless you have a fear of dirt, get the game, shrink yourself and get to work, theres a lot of things that need to be done in the backyard y’know.
Loving the game mechanics, story progression, humor and the vibe of the game =)

This is one of the best survivals out there. Maybe even the best one.
Grounded is creative, deep, immersive and well designed. The hard mode is a real challenge as you got to use every resource and mechanic available as well as study the enemy movements to win most fights.
Art direction is superb, the game feels unique and looks incredibly good while doing so.
It's a long game, and better suited to be played with at least one friend, but I've been playing ony my own and I've had more than enough my share of fun while being little over 100 hours and I'm guessing I'm still halfway through.
The depth in this is really surprising. Heck, you have enough tools and options to make many different builds.
Some parts on the hard mode will feel grindy, but you are heavily reward for exploring.
Some mechanics are not explained outright, but there's a pace to unlocking everything.
Even with minor details, this game did everything right for me. Building, combat, exploring, platforming, even the jokes here and there. The story also develops in an interesting way, I'm truly not sure of the ending now and this is a good sign since I'm used to guessing everything and this title keeps handing out surprises every corner I turn.

I really wanted to like this game. I like the concept, the art, the vibe. But it's simply not fun to play.

First, it seriously lacks directions. You reach a quest marker and see nothing around. The objective might be above you, below you, or beyond an impassable wall. To reach it you must find the secret entrance, which is often distant from the marker, with no discernible path. After roaming in circles for an hour the first time, we started relying on Youtube tutorials, and spent much of the playtime with the game minimized, watching tutorials and then repeating the steps like idiots.

Second, the game has too much of everything. Weapons, resources, structures. For example, there are maybe 8 types of level 2 helmets, but you only need one. Everything else is background noise. There is no distinction between functional and aesthetic buildings, and both categories include mostly ones that seem pointless. For example, there are several types of cooking stations, which allow preparing different categories of food - but the most common and basic category is good enough, at least on low difficulty.

Speaking of, the difficulty is not well-balanced. We started out on medium difficulty, but became frustrated when stronger foes repeatedly killed us instantly. We lowered the difficulty, killed some of those foes and crafted better armor - and suddenly most fights posed no challenge whatsoever. But there are still creatures that easily kill you, so we didn't increase the difficulty back.

Combat is annoying. Online guides say you need to wait for the enemy to attack, block and retaliate. But the attack patterns are difficult to discern and remember for each type of foe, and often you fight many creatures simultaneously... IT SIMPLY ISN'T FUN.

The element I enjoy most in survival/crafting them is resource collection and organizing. That's hardly a thing in Grounded, because there are so many resources - and you don't need 99% of them 99% of the time. Sometimes, a resource you need is annoying to collect at your current stage. For example, there is an underwater quest that requires diving equipment, which in turn requires underwater resources. These are a nightmare to collect when you often need to go up for air. Throughout the quest you receive more resources, by which time you're done with diving...


The respawn mechanism is God-awful. You spend a large portion of the game running back from respawn points to your current task. There is no fast travel, nor devices that speed up movement (at least at my stage of the game). While running you constantly need to circumvent obstacles: plant stems, roots that you need to climb from exactly one possible direction, a blocked path which you must go around - again and again, every time you want to grab some resource from the base or hunt some beetle. And at any moment you might be attacked. I was expecting somewhat of a chill experience - this isn't it.

The story is conveyed through dialogues and recordings which are unbelievably long, boring, and recorded in a dissonant voice which makes them annoying to listen to.

The menu system is robust but stupid. For example, the Craft tab has a search function, but it only shows results within the current category of items. So if you don't remember which category an item belongs to, you first filter by item name, and then go category by category(!) to check which one contains the filtered item name. Another example: when crafting a weapon or armor, the game doesn't show a side-by-side stats comparison with your current armor. You need to manually move the mouse between the new and old armor to compare.

Bottom line: This game feels like homework. There are small moments of satisfaction, but at no point was I actually enjoying the gameplay and mechanics. It's not a terrible game, but it mostly made me miss other games.

i ABSOLUTELY DO NOT RECOMMEND THIS GAME TO STEAM PLAYERS. 
go to XBOX, use game pass and play it through there. it's much cheaper and will not conflict as much like it is through steam. you MUST have an xbox account in order to play this game already. i have never had any problems with steam games before, have an updated system and drivers, etc. but GROUNDED is the only one i am struggling with here. i've looked up how to fix my issues (game crashing, save files loading into black screens, xbox account login unavailable, etc.) and multiple other players encountered the same issue and suggested going through XBOX. within minutes, my problems were solved and i played a smoother, easier game with them. 
i've contacted steam and requested a refund, resulting in a denial each time. this game is NOT WORTH THE $40 THEY WILL TAKE FROM YOU. steam's policy only refunds games with 2 hours of game play or less, but the issues were not coming out right off the bat. i played less than 7 hours out of it and my pc can not handle a minute more. go to XBOX and pay the game pass fee (typically $1 the first month, $9.99 each month after) if you don't have it already and you will have a better experience and a broader range of games included.

The thing this game does best, is its progression.

You start with nothing.

You gain a healthy amount of fear for everything around you. 

You try your hand at taking a back yard predator down... You get schmacked. 

Then, you either have to find something you can take down for better gear / change strategy / fighting style / change mutations.

The game does a very good job at establishing a food chain. And you definitely have a feel on where you stand on that chain.

As others have said...this game is "Honey I shrunk the kids" with 4 player co-op! Grounded is a well polished + well rounded game that offers anything from chill exploration, building, crafting, resource grinding, decent action, and with the latest "Playgrounds" update, the ability to make obstacle courses and races. It is Q4 2023 and the devs are (still) continuously updating the game and adding new features. 

I played this with my children and had the greatest time exploring and battling bugs and building locations like quick defensive forts to massive mushroom mansions to zip lines that spanned the entire backyard. Grounded is no walk in the park though, some of the bosses put up a very difficult fight that requires certain mutations (perks) to be leveled up, and leveled up armor and weapons, in addition to teamworking strategies. 

There is another game trying to copy this game on Steam ( I won't say the name because it doesn't deserve the recognition) but Grounded is extremely well polished compared to that nonsense. 

My only minor gripe is the playable character "Max". Nobody ever wants to play as Max. Max is a token character and would not have been included in the game had this game been made in a sensible era. He is the most annoying and obnoxious character with an annoying voice and ghetto sounding quips that contradict himself with just about everything. He's also a bully to Pete (the nerdy playable character). I get that this is just a game... but... the characters in the game would NEVER be friends with someone like Max. Max sucks.

Character creation would have been the icing on the cake with this game but still...Grounded is a wonderful game that provides hundreds of hours of exploration and crafting and building. I highly recommend this game for all ages.

Steam Deck Review 

This game works flawlessly on the deck, stable 40 fps on high graphics. It’s very fun to play handheld, more than the console versions for sure. 

I really like the fact and also recommend that you change the settings in the beginning to make things easier for yourself at least until you get the hang of things. I love that I can scale the hunger/thirst levels to my liking, as well as the day/night cycle. 

It’s easy to get lost in this game and if you don’t mind that then you will have a good time otherwise stick to the main quest because the menu map sucks. 

There’s a ton of customization and crafting available here so you can really get lost in that if that’s your thing, not so much for me but I do enjoy the concept of a cozy home somewhere in the middle of the map. 

If you ever watched “Honey I Shrunk the Kids” you will for sure enjoy this “little” gem. 

Side Note - There’s also a toggle for arachnophobia mode if you’re scared of spiders.

This game is very grindy. I didn’t realize it was a crafting based game so if you don’t like that, this isn’t the game for you. It can be quite tedious but it also means there’s almost always something to do which is nice. 

The enemies take some practiced strategy to defeat, each one has its own strengths and weaknesses to help you kill them. At the beginning, the strategy is to get away, because you don’t have the weapons or armor to win. 

Pretty much every aspect of the game can be altered to your liking (how fast you become hungry and thirsty, how much damage you take, what you drop when you die, etc.) so if the default settings aren't to your liking, you can completely customize your playing experience. 

There are a few bugs. Enemies getting stuck in walls or even the ground. I was building walls and they were solid and built for me, but they looked like the blueprint of a build for my boyfriend, who I was playing with, though he couldn’t walk through them. 

I like that things such as missions and analyzed materials are synced across all players when playing co-op. I think you’ll appreciate it too if you’re playing with someone on a different skill set. I’ve found in other games I’ve played with my boyfriend, he’s miles ahead in player level and unlocked weapons and armor and I’m lagging behind and it’s just not as fun like that (yes, I know that’s a skill issue on my part, but the opinion still stands). It’s nice to play on equal ground with Grounded. 

One thing I really don’t like is the hot bar/inventory. You can’t scroll through your hot bar quickly, you have to open your menu wheel and enter your inventory that way. You do get used to it but there are still a few extra steps in there that shouldn’t be. If you can’t see your waypoints, etc. when you’re walking, it’s because you’ve accidentally toggled it off in your option wheel. It took me too long to figure that out and turn it back on. 

(By the way, I find it kind of ironic that to craft a gas mask, you need to kill a stinkbug, which hurts you with stink gas). 

Overall, I feel like the game could get a little repetitive and therefore boring just because of all the crafting, but so far it’s been pretty fun.

Short version: Really fun concept, completely ruined by glitches and connection problems.

When the game actually works, it's mostly pretty fun. However there are so many frequent problems with it despite already being a year old, I doubt those will be fully fixed.
Just off the top of my head, here's a list of some problems:
* The host has significantly lower FPS (I had 40-60 as host, 120+ as client)
* Objects desync as client (you see stuff that you can't interact with, because it doesn't exist on the host's end)
* As a client the HUD element indicating that a collectible is nearby sometimes glitches out, permanently showing that something is nearby, no matter how far you move away
* Sometimes really glitchy physics as client (likely due to desync)
* Individual players getting disconnected from the game (not an internet problem)
* All (non-host) players getting disconnected from the game (once again, not an internet problem). During some sessions it happened on average every 30 minutes, other times it was completely fine
* Game crashes/freezes
* Tutorials only appear for the host
* Some things/mechanics are never explained (as far as I can tell)
* A certain mid to lategame mechanic is broken: [spoiler]The Waft Emitter, which can be used to make creatures attack your base, can't spawn certain creatures that it should be able to. This is not intended because according to reddit posts it worked prior to the 1.3 update. It also oftentimes just despawns the creatures because they can't find their way to the Waft Emitter, leading you to basically get scammed out of your resources[/spoiler]
* Your menus are affected by other players doing stuff in their menus, which can lead to you crafting the wrong thing and just generally an annoying and sometimes confusing menu navigation
* Crafting something with a full inventory drops the crafted item on the ground, but if you do it this way it won't register for quest progress

I came up with this list in a few minutes, there's likely quite a few more problems I'd remember if I gave it some more time.

And then to top it all off it requires an Xbox account and if you care about 100%ing this game, you will likely have to grind a lot because each enemy can drop a certain thing but it's super rare: [spoiler]for most enemies it's a 1% chance to get their golden card and you need all of them. Of some enemies there are only 1-5 on the entire map and it takes multiple ingame days for them to respawn[/spoiler].

This game is woefully unfinished. A huge disappointment from one of my favorite studios. But even were you not to get stuck on pieces of terrain constantly, the game in general just does not having anything going for it to set it apart from other games in this genre other than its Honey I Shrunk the Kids premise, the novelty of which quickly fades when you're subject to hour after hour of running back and forth between places collecting small amounts of resources all the while facing off the "dangers" of the garden. The enemies themselves pose a little threat, and are unlikely to kill you in any single combat. However you cannot really run from them very often, and so you must continuously engage in battles with boring bugs for the nth time. I do not understand why this genre has chosen to focus so much on the combat aspect, when combat is just clunkily clicking left click at things and then blocking while you whittle down your opponent.

Despite being one of my favorte studios and giving me some of my all time favorite games, between this and the boring slog of nothingness that was Outer Worlds, I do not have high hopes for the future of this studio under its new ownership at Microsoft.

Update: I tried it again, it still sucks.

Grounded is a game that deserves attention and praise. The game has many strengths, such as an original idea, open world, graphics, sound, gameplay, story, characters, game modes, and community support. The game also has some weaknesses such as technical issues, artificial intelligence, replayability, and balance. However, these shortcomings do not spoil the overall experience of the game. I recommend this game to anyone who loves adventure, survival, building, and cooperation. I rate this game 8 out of 10 points.

This is actually, surprisingly, an incredible survivor / builder game.
I've never been a huge fan of Obsidian's work...but they hit the nail right on the head with this game.
This game seems pretty well balanced in all areas, the combat system is really good, the building is good.
Honestly there are only 2 things that I can think of that need improvement...they NEED to give you information about the gear...all of the gear has a lot of stats and buffs and such...it's all very important too, but they don't tell you anything about it within the game and forces you to go to the stupid wiki page for everything.
They really really need to include more information about this in the game because i don't like stopping game play every half hour to alt-tab and read for 5 minutes about gear or the gear upgrade or gear perks.
Also there are some really significant desync bugs in multiplayer that forces constant restarts on both the server and client side. these bugs are very frequent and frustrating because it is game breaking and forces everyone to stop playing and restart the game every hour or so.
but aside from those 2 things - this game is very solid and worth buying, i'd recommend to anyone that enjoys this genre of game.

[h1]My Experience when my Mum says "go play outside" but I'm 5'1[/h1]
Amazing Survival game to play with friends. Everything feels exactly how you'd expect, massive, too scale and lots of locations to explore. 
Tons of enemy bugs, spiders, items to craft, materials to collect and bases to create to keep yourself and your team safe. 
There's an actually well thought out story to uncover that feels very in theme with this style of game where most others just have it as a side note really. 
Great graphic style and very addicting. 

My only gripe would be the game does NOT help you... at all. I don't expect any hand holding when it comes to fighting enemies or surviving but the story objectives don't tell you if you need anything to be able to progress and by the time you do get there you just straight up cannot do it because you missed a random item you needed to craft and have to go all the way back to base. Luckily... Google exists.

Grounded is effectively a multiplayer survival game of "Honey, I Shrunk the Kids". It's well optimised, the building system is polished and it's really immersive to play in. There are tons of building pieces which should make some interesting possibilities for bases. The garden world is pretty huge, hand crafted and full of interesting things to find. At such a small scale, it's really interesting to walk among the dirt, seeing grass stalks as high as trees. There's also tons of verticality; you can climb grass stalks, get high up to get a better view of your surroundings, delve into an ant hill and go diving in the pond. There's also loads of weapon and armour sets to make from bug parts.

[b]Pros[/b]
- Gorgeous, especially the lighting
- The design of the game world is impeccable. You can climb tall things to get a better view, landmarks are useful for navigating etc
- Bugs interact with each other. Bombardiers attack groups of ants. Ants attack weevils.
- There's a blueprint system for planning buildings in advance
- When you throw a spear at a creature, it gets stuck in it
- Really cool hand-crafted map to explore
- There are landmarks scattered around the garden which are great to explore as a tiny person
- You can craft armour out of bugs
- Huge attention to detail. You can climb a stalk of grass at night and watch them all wave gently in the wind
- There's a big pond with lots of underwater things to explore
- You can 'peep' a creature by looking at it while pretending to have binoculars, and it adds that creature's weaknesses to a database
- You unlock special powers (mutations) by performing feats like exploration and killing certain enemies a lot
- There are tons of decor items. One of them is an armour stand that lets you quick-swap the equipped set it's wearing
- You can relocate buildings at any time so you don't lose building materials
- You can quick-drop your inventory into nearby chests

[b]Cons[/b]
- It uses Microsoft instead of Steam for multiplayer, which is a genuinely shitty interface for playing together. Once you eventually manage to add each other as friends (which, unintuitively you do by 'following' each other), it took us a while to work out how to stop hearing everyone twice.
- Pathing could be better. Creatures get stuck in large objects or underneath bases or teleport around them
- The sleep cycle feels a bit broken. The game is dark by 7pm, but if you sleep then, the game warns you that you'll wake up at 3am as you always sleep for exactly 8 hours. You should be able to change the time you're going to wake up
- Major problems getting the game's audio to work as an output-only device with AirPods (because the game switches to "communication mode" even if you disable voice comms)
- No button to auto-sort inventory
- Whenever you quick-drop your inventory, it will add anything from your inventory to a nearby chest. Which is great, except that it also does it for weapons and arrows so I keep leaving the base with no ammo. Should be able to favourite items you never want to quick-sort
- You can place markers, but you can't label them - only symbols. I have to have a text editor open next to the game so I know what all the random symbols are
- Your thirst and hunger reset to about 30% every time you sleep, regardless of how full or empty you were when you went to bed, which makes eating in the afternoon or evening mostly pointless
- Personally I don't think it makes much sense that you need tier 2 bug parts to make tier 2 weapons. That means you need to kill tier 2 creatures with tier 1 weapons and armour to advance
- There aren't enough hotkeys or way to access tools. There are 8 hotbar slots. I have 7 tools, 4 different weapons, and 3 different kinds of healing consumables.
- The combat is the biggest weak point. Your attacks are 3-hit combos, but your attacks don't interrupt the enemy, so they usually attack you during your combo. Bugs can charge you through solid objects. Bugs teleport around things if you run away. Spiders can kill you in 2-3 hits even if you're just running away.

[b]Wishlist from Early Access[/b]
- Weather. Rain would be awesome
- Some kind of building to explore. I guess the house is ambitious, but there's a shed in the garden
- Custom characters and clothing customisation
- Some sort of power system for lighting using a battery for power
- More traps for defense

Grounded is one of the best, most immersive games I've ever played. I'm not sure I could write a review that would do this game justice. So fun. Nothing feels like a grind because all resource stuff has fairly immediate purpose. While there isn't a standard leveling system, the attributes, mutations and better gear combine to make it a rich skill progression. There's a fair variety of weapons and gear so each person can forge their own play style. Since it's not character based leveling as well, you can switch out gear and mutations to adopt different styles/weapons/approaches to different situations. Fun combat. The devs...I just can't say enough. There is a single bug when playing co-op where the non-host has trouble picking up water droplets. Other than that, this game has not felt broken or buggy once. The devs didn't sit on their hands; each major update has been filled with new and amazing content. This should have been nom'd for game of the year but it felt like it just didn't get the attention it deserved. The campaign is extensive with a great story line. I've played it with one friend all the way through. We are nearing game-end and can look around the yard and just see evidence of this really cool journey everywhere. Stellar gaming experience all round. Would LOVE to see more games in this style and genre.
tastes like my moms brussels sprouts

I find myself constantly wondering to myself what the point of this is and I'm just... bored.

There's not much interesting about the garden. It's very small (unironically), you're able to traverse one end to the other within a 5 minute traipse. There's a very small diversity of insects from what I've seen so far, and I have very little motivation to seek the rest if there are any. You have the different type of ants (workers, warriors etc), small spider, big spider, mites and stinkbugs. I also instantly got murdered by a mosquito so that was nice. 85% of the garden is just grass (or dried grass). Haven't been in any nests yet, but again, I have no motivation to do so because what's the point? 

My dislike is probably centered around the fact that base building is just so inconvenient. It's a chore to make a 6 by 6 square let alone an actual flourishing little cradle to call home. I can't even make a window without going to the other end of the garden and back. Unlike other survival games, you need to lug around massive blades of grass - you can't fit them into your bag for later and call it a day. And I do see why they've made it like this to suit the theme of being small, but gameplay should never be sacrificed in favour of the backdrop and that's what the game has felt like for me so far.

Don't be fooled by the impressive builds you see in screenshots because as far as I can tell unless they spent hundreds of hours in that save (you're a better man than me...), they were probably made in creative mode.

That said I don't mean to paint the game as being all bad. There are a few things that are quite impressive but I'll let the other 90%+ other very positive reviews do the talking.

I wanted to like this game.  I wanted to LOVE this game.  I was all primed for it - the premise is right up my alley, like a great 80s kid-caper sci-fi movie, and the graphics are indeed gorgeous and everything you'd want out of this game.  It's fun just to load it up and look around.  The problem is, it doesn't know what kind of game it wants to be, so it tries to be several types and fails at all of them.  Is it an FPS?  Is it an RPG?  Is it a crafter and builder?  Is it an MMORPG?  Who can say?  Only the game designers, who tried to blend all these game types and more together and ended up with a mess that's just plain frustrating to play and not fun at all.  It's not that it's a bad game, and it's not that it's a hard game, it's that it's an unfair game that frankly just expects too much out of the player, and in the end, for all the fun I wanted to have with it, I found myself just getting angry with it and not having any fun at all.  And yes, it was punishingly hard, making it even more frustrating.  So I stopped playing.  And that's the worst, buying a game and expecting to like it, wanting to like it, and finding out that you just plain don't.

I plan to give it a try again some day.  Maybe I just didn't "get it", and wasn't ready to get it.  Now that I've played it a bunch and I know exactly what to expect, maybe I'd have a better time with a restart.  It has such great potential!  But my first experience with it wasn't great, and first impressions can be hard to break.  

Extra Note:  this game is virtually impossible to play effectively without resorting to the online Wiki, which isn't necessarily a problem in and of itself, I like looking up the Wiki for lots of games.  But this game absolutely requires it, or there is stuff you simply will never figure out on your own.  Devs, that's always a bad sign in my book.  The game itself should tell me everything I need to know - not every winning strategy or best way to do something, but everything I need to KNOW.  In this game, several times I got stuck and could go no further without looking things up, because I couldn't for the life of me figure out some essential mechanic or didn't realize what I was really going up against.  That's just plain bad game design.

There is so much potential here, but the game is so obtuse, difficult and inaccessible that it's difficult for me to believe it was actually play-tested by normal, average people.

Although I did enjoy the gameplay and the story, I’ve now played for almost 100 hours and have started working on the achievements of the game. When I first started, I didn’t know what I got myself into. There is A LOT of collectibles in this game you have to get for an achievement, which is tiresome in itself, but doable. BUT there is an achievement that requires you to «peep» every creature (fair enough if you’re playing through the game since you meet 90% somewhere through the main story). This achievement was recently changed into getting a GOLD CARD of every creature. Mind you, this gold card only has a 1% drop chance (except certain bosses). The bad thing about this is that you can end up getting it on 1 kill or 100+. Imo this is just an achievement they changed to make people play the game for longer, but it adds no purpose to the game… it shouldnt matter if you fight a boss 1 or 50 times just for an achievement…

I'm horrified of spiders, heights, and water.

The first story area has me high up.  In a tree.  With no safety nets.  Clambering across tiny tree branches that are painfully easy to fall off, and jumping between them.  All while filled with spiders and spider eggs.

The second story area has me underwater.  With a huge murder fish.  Filled with spiders.  Yes, underwater fucking spiders.

Half my time in this game is spent running around in the dark avoiding giant murderous spiders.  That will screech and horrifyingly leap upon me, bite my shit, and force me to literally stare into their fangs as I desperately fight them.

Why am I having so much fun..?

Okay so I love this game. It's beautiful. It's fun with friends. BUT the only way I'm able to play it is because of arachnophobia mode. It works just fine for me EXCEPT THE FACT that arachnophobia mode isn't applied to the entire game. An example of this is when I was browsing the crafting menu to improve my base coziness. In the crafting submenu with the mounts and stuffed animals, the full spider image is there with no arachnophobia safe mode. IT WAS A LITERAL JUMP SCARE. I don't want to even go in there and see what other spiders are visible because it would cause me emotional damage and mental torture. Please fix this!

Like RDR 2 this game is a beautiful failure. content being locked behind story line is its first fatal flaw. Bugs continuing to spawn inside and around base builds is most annoying. backpack content rearranging itself every time you drop your bag is enraging. Bug raids being able to collapse concrete walls after what it takes to gather material is unforgivable. Concrete walls should be impervious to attack...period. Not to mention bugs raiding your base to me is just stupid.....They are bugs! Not intellectual creatures with that ability, besides maybe ants. With that being said i would still recommend this game due to its awesome graphics and the hours of entertainment one will have navigating the map. Just don't play this game with any seriousness and it will remain fun. And don't ever build a sweet base, its a complete waste of time.

Played the game a couple years back when it was in early access with a buddy. I know I fell in love with the game back then seeing all the possibilities the game offered, and that was back before it was finished and all the content was yet to be added. Well that same friend that I played the game with back then asked me if I wanted to play the game now that it is fully released. Of course I agreed! Well here I am with 75 hours of play time, and we've yet to finish the game fully. We are taking it slow and enjoying everything the game has to offer. So I know the 75 hours I have at the time of posting this, they will only continue to increase. I have not played the game solo any, all the play time I have, has been accumulated from multiplayer with said friend. But Id go out on a limb and say the game would be just as fun, and immersive in single player as in multiplayer. I honestly can not recommend the game enough for anyone that likes these types of games. You wont be disappointed! You will spend plenty of hours being sucked into the game as I was, I'd say.

Too slow moving, armor for defense doesn't compare to timing a perfect block making it a learn every reaction time for each attacking creature, and way too much jumping to get to places way too often. Crafting a new object and spending a good amount of time to find the rare parts to build it just to constantly find the items it makes is locked behind story and bosses. The multiplayer save option isn't tied to steam it's tied to X-box subscription, would be nice to have known that first for coop saves. If you like crafting useful items and not jumping to get to places often, would not recommend this game.

EDIT: 304 hours later, I still love this game.
EDIT: 627 hours later, they keep making huge quality of life updates and it keeps getting better. I'm not a big gamer, so this is literally the most time I've ever invested in any game and I don't think I'll get tired of it.

Absolutely amazing game! From the moment you spawn you constantly have something to do and have some sense of progression. Whether it's with quests, building or your own gear.

I would definitely recommend playing it with a friend (or multiple friends). This makes it even better. Just have a chat, lay back and build some stuff or do some quests together to progress further into the game. The multiple layers of the garden makes it feel like you constantly reach completely new areas with new stuff to do.

The combat in the beginning felt a bit off putting and boring, but later on I realised it was actually pretty engaging and fun. Because of the strength of the bugs, different playstyles and weaknesses.

Overall I would definitely recommend this game! Probably in my top 5 (online co-op) games of all time.

Overall, this game was a great experience that I thoroughly enjoyed. It was SO good that it made me want to 100% it even! (Which I rarely bother with games) But there lies my only complaint: the completion requirements.
It has the usual ones, like collecting all the collectables (both cosmetic and base-stat increasing ones, all placed in exciting places that leave you happy you have been there), visiting all the landmarks (there are so many landmarks, which look both beautiful and unique with the game's miniature perspective), and killing all the bosses (which most are optional but all are tough, and I enjoyed them all (except for IBM but whatever)).
But then comes the Creature Cards. Every creature has a Basic card, which you get on your first encounter with that creature, and a Golden card, which you get after a random number of kills. The chance to get a GC (gold card) from normal creatures is 1% and from repeatable bosses 10% (and 5% for IBM despite it being the most bull boss of them all but whatever). Now, when the creature is small and comes in groups of 5-10, getting the GC is easy enough, even if RNGesus says you have to kill hundreds of them. But when that creature is one that you need endgame gear to kill without treating it like a boss encounter, wanders around alone in three spots in the entire map, takes three in-game days to respawn, and the chance for a GC is still 1%? Yeah, f that.
I spent 109 hours on a single save, and that is the one thing that prevents me from 100%-ing the game.
I love this game, but ffs, please fix that.
(And add a draw distance setting)

At first I really liked this game. I liked the art style, the setting, and the base building mechanic-- it reminds me of [i]The Forest[/i], but without the cannibal mutants pestering you. I really wanted to keep playing.
But... sadly I have two dislikes, and these dislikes are my personal rant/opinion. Send me all the Jesters you want if you can't stand it.

[b]1.[/b] After progressing to finding the first lab and being told where to go, I feel my progression has been halted by two things.
[b]-1a.[/b] The game doesn't tell the player where to get the items to acquire Tier II tools/weapons/armor. I get the hate when tutorials hand hold you too much, but some direction would be nice (instead of being forced to go to the wiki.. which it might not even tell you if the item has a rare drop rate or not).
[b]-1b.[/b] 'Perfect Blocking' (aka react as if you're playing Elden Ring) should not feel like a requirement to survive higher level enemies. But when trying to find a video to explain how I could possibly play my way (aka button mashing).. it doesn't exist. All I see is "git gud with fast reaction blocking, or die (repeatably) and corpse walk to get your inventory back". Look, I'm sure this mechanic is fun for a lot of people, but it's just not for me.

[b]2.[/b] Achievements, are locked behind an Xbox account. When I looked on Google for a "WHY IS THIS A THING?!" answer, I got nothing. Multiplayer locked behind an account (to me), is fine; I'll let that slide. But locking [b]achievements[/b] on Steam?! ...Is this a PC port (and this game was originally on the Xbox)? Because that would make a lot of sense. If not, then what the HELL, man?!

Feedback:
 - Travel gets annoying mid-late game. At least it impedes fun for me.
 - Wasp drones are just broke. Forced ranged. They never get close and heal themselves. In particular I don't like being forced into ranged play. They're doable, but also very not fun.
 - Smoothies impede the flow of the game a lot. Waiting on muscle sprouts to grow. I did start a farm but still slow. I don't like the lillypad wax on the stamina potions change either. Time gates things a lot more.
 - Would like the ability to plant things without opening a menu, quick plant. Or perhaps even if you leave a muscle sprout in a plot, harvest one, the one harvested grows back if the other is left there.
 - The hot tub heal seems unnecessarily slow.
 - After 1.3 all my "bounce pads" are ever so slightly messed up.
 - Infected broodmother isn't fun. Mild is way to easy. Medium is MASSIVELY different then mild. There is no inbetween. Neither feels good. Neither is fun. Particularly the potion debuff is a problem that makes phase 3 impossible.

I have been playing Grounded since early release and in my opinion the game is well worth the purchase.
The unique setting of having common back garden insects and objects being your challenges and opponents forces you to use creativity in the way you complete objectives and take down some of the games bigger foes.

Pros
The crafting system, upgrade and character screen options generally are easily explained and easy to use.
The wonder of wandering around the back garden is both exciting and frightening as some of the enemies in the game are really powerful and therefore night is truly a scary point if you stay awake.
Building a base is not just a building experience, you do require your base for some of the larger crafting tables and some of the craftable items ensure survival is easier.
You can choose custom game settings.

Cons
While I love the game there definitely are some cons.
Despite the game being playable by a single player, the difficulty level, even at Mild, is very difficult.  Some enemies which are camped out very near your first regular stop location are some of the most difficult in the game.  Certain enemy types are so numerous there was clearly a specific weapon type in mind as there are 3 different varieties of weapons with the same perk.  Like a lot of co-op games, survival by a single player was not really considered. If you manage to make it to the point where you're incredibly powerful and well yoked, it's likely that the final sequence of the game is way too much for most players to tackle on their own.
As you cannot unlock certain recipes until you have researched at least some of the items required to create them, exploration of certain areas (specifically the pond and any other water areas which require swimming) can be incredibly difficult to explore and gain access to the recipes.  That said, Brainpower leveling does open up some recipes for you, I'm just not sure that any swimming related assistance items are actually included in this.

All in all, the game is definitely worth it and a much better experience if you're playing with more than one other player.  Personally I love the game and while early game can be frustrating, you will beef yourself up with good weapons and armour and perks to make the game feel a bit more fair but the difficulty level can be brutal so, despite the age of the protagonists, younger kids not used to action adventure games might have difficulty with this one. With the full release came a good guide to get you to the most important locations and an introduction as to how to unlock certain items.  However I would stress that this was not released with a single player in mind.  Enemies surround you in far too great numbers, damage dealt by even the smallest enemies can prove catastrophic in only a few hits, so if you're surrounded, you will likely die.  I think that instead of immediately opening up the 'Playground' as their first major patch, Obsidian should really work on a bit more balancing.  Some enemies have astronomical health levels and not only no weaknesses, but they resist most damage types and spawn with adds.  Hopefully they'll fix this and I am looking forward to any DLC the game might offer to provide more enjoyment out of the story mode of the game :)

If you look at this game and think "This game might be for me, but it looks a little too cutesy" you should still buy it. I thought the same thing and I quickly grew to love the style and, most importantly, the entire game.
The main character is the game world. So many nooks and crannies (literally) to explore. There's a constant sense of adventure every time you venture into the unknown. Or even when visiting familiar places. And with the additions that you unlock along the way the grinding and traversing gets easier making for a pretty smooth ride in the backyard.

The story unfolds nicely throughout and leads you from one end of the map to the other. And you'll be amazed at how big it is. Getting to a high place and looking around you'll realize just how much there is to see. And it has that almost perfectly balanced sense of monster progression where you can go many places, but some places are simply too dangerous until later in the game. I love that.

The only downside to the game that I can think of is that once you've completed the game and seen it all (which will take you ~100 hours) there's not much incentive to go back unless you just want to build bases in creative mode. Base-building is a lot of fun. And you will grow to love your base wherever you decide to put it. But it's not enough of an incentive to keep playing for me personally.

So my recommendation is not to rush the game! Take your time. Make sure you explore it all. There's more than you think. It's not just what you can see on the ground. There's a LOT of hidden places as well. And then some.

Whether you're braving it solo or rolling with a crew, the downsized adventure is a blast. Beware the wolf spiders though – those eight-legged nightmares will haunt your dreams. The graphics are as sharp as a magnifying glass, and the sounds make you question whether you're in a game or a nature documentary. In the world of pint-sized peril, Grounded is a giant success – 10 out of 10, no shrinkage in fun here

A really cool concept greatly executed. 
The cartoony style was a great decision to avoid being overly disturbing for people that dislike bugs, while also having a great charm.
The story is nice and the game allows for both funny and scary moments at the same time, which make it a great experience.

Content-wise, it has a lot to do right now and collectables to grind, with hopefully more content in the future. Sadly, it does not allows for mods at this time, although they just added the custom maps mode, which is a good start.

Getting lost in Grounded is an absolute pleasure and wonder. As players are zapped into miniature form, they find themselves exploring a vast backyard straight out of the 90s. The encompassing experience involves piecing together makeshift tools, weapons, armour, constructing shelters/bases, and collecting food and water. I had a great time creating a network of flying foxes for easy traversal around the backyard, establishing mini-bases as safe havens from the bugs only so that i can go deeper into the backyard and further explore this delightful game. 

Certain armor and weapons work better on certain enemies, so it's imperative for you to kill all kinds of bugs and collect various resources to be scanned into your database to see what you can make from them. The weapons and armor sets are quite diverse, allowing you to explore various build types. Furthermore, you're encouraged to find molars scattered around the backyard for permanent character stat upgrades like HP and Stamina. There is a story to discover about why you have been shrunken down, a friendly robot named BURG.L helping you, and miniature science labs throughout the backyard.

Performance-wise, Grounded is as visually stunning as it is smooth, with no notable issues that I have encountered. The post-launch support for the game has been amazing, consistently introducing new content. Grounded is an easy recommendation.

AMENDMENT: I'm going to amend my review. Due to the level of devotion the devs have continued to show this game, fixing problems that caused people like me frustration. Continuing to add new content and care about their player base, I think I can safely say that I would recommend this game. I recently got the urge to come back to it and was very pleased. Maybe its the distance between my original review and getting the urge to play the game again, realizing I was being unfair in my review.

----old review----
I have played this game for a while, over 200 hours. I loved this game during early access and even during my time replaying the old content, overall its still a really fun concept. However, as time went on the game gets old and the fun from the beginning turns into repetition, grind and tedium. It started to feel like a second job just to gather enough supplies to be geared up for the final parts of the game. 

Lets first talk pros before I go into my list of cons:
 - Really fun concept
 - base building is really good, in line with games like the Forest
 - Creatures look realistic with a bit of that cartoonish fun added to them
 - The game has that good survival feel and I love that basically anywhere on the map could be a roaming scary wolf spider patrolling through (I like that even the starter area isn't safe. 
 - Story was okay, good enough for a mostly survival game
 - voice acting was really good, and I'm a sucker for anything Zachary Levi does
 - I will admit until I got to the 1.0 content I was really enjoying my time in this game

Now lets talk cons:
 - The Inventory, god the stupid inventory - holy crap the INVENTORY. One of the most annoying and limiting factors in any game I've ever encountered. No possibility to upgrade later, (don't talk to me about pets, I'll get to those later....) This inventory system which is basically an exercise in irritating the player, just to make the game take longer.... Heck I turned off weapon and tool decay just so I didn't have to carry around repair supplies.... didn't help much. The UI EVEN has an empty row at the bottom where they could have fit 10 more slots..... Oh and the whole removing your active items from inventory while you're using them, and getting the inevitable "you can't unequip this item your backpack is full" message, SUPER ^@#$ing irritating. Why on earth the devs think their inventory system is good, I will never know, but THATS OKAY THEY GAVE US A DANG SORT BUTTON.....finally. For a game based on progression and getting stronger to survive, not having an upgradeable backpack system is just bonkers to me. Get used to saying "gotta run all the way back to base now, my inventory is full... again" every 5-10 minutes. 

 - Next lets talk about progression.... what progression? Sure you get stronger for the area you're in at first. But there is a point in the game, where all of the good weapons barely make you break even on difficulty, unless you go and farm bosses or really difficult enemies with ridiculously low drop rates.... If you're playing a survival game you WANT/NEED to feel like you're getting stronger by the end, not spending hours on end grinding to just barely scrape by.. I get the game should be hard, but come on, its a game and players like to feel like their hard work has paid off. 

 - Upgrades.... NOT ENOUGH ITEMS, there are not enough resources on the map if you want to upgrade lots of items, or try out new ones. Make the upgrade resources respawn, and making the player have to wait till basically the very end of the game to craft high tier upgrade materials is just stupid, oh and spoilers...[spoiler](it barely gives you a hint on where to go if you want to get the blueprints for them as its optional, but required for the second ending) [/spoiler]

 - Pets.... buggy little bugs... They can't be picked up to move them where you want, their follow AI sucks, I can't even get them to follow me into my base so I can keep them safe. However, you want to have one because its the only way to get 10 extra inventory slots in the most immersion breaking way possible, (devs if you nerf this next part without fixing your terrible inventory system......yeah, just fix the inventory....). Yep, you can keep the pet anywhere on the map, and still push items to its inventory. I trapped an aphid in the mysterious machine just so I'd have extra slots, because warping items to a pet miles (meters) away on the map isn't immersion breaking, but giving upgrades to your inventory is just bad bad bad..... come on get real. There are plenty of resources in the game that you could make a hip pouch or something to increase available space.... or make a quiver to get arrows out of your inventory, SOMETHING better than glitchy pets.

 - Now lets talk about 1.0 release. Everything about the upper yard and final endgame feels rushed. You're only going to be exploring three quarters of the entire yard if you follow the story prompts. The only way to find all the different things is to just wander aimlessly and discover the other areas, and I guarantee you miss a lot of them without help from the internet. There was so much cut content from the feature board. No weather like they wanted to add (really really hoped we'd get this because over time the world feels bland and just same old same old. I know I know, rain would be EXTREMELY hard to figure out because of how big the player is and bases would likely get destroyed if you weren't smart about it, but I still think it was worth trying to figure this out). Only two optional bosses, I don't count the termite king, which should have been required by story in my opinion. They clickbaited me with putting nothing in the milk carton, still salty about that. The game just doesn't feel complete, like a whole bunch of stuff just left out and the story rushed to release because management said they needed to release, typical BS with large companies like Microsoft. They had a whole treasure trove of content that could have made the cut, but was just simply left out and the game just kinda ends...

 - Lastly, because I think I've rambled long enough, its certainly not everything I feel about the game, lets talk about the hotfixes after 1.0 release..... they suck. The devs have nerfed every fun thing about the game. Find a weapon I like... nerfed in next hotfix, but they buff the really useless crap that no one uses, or the really difficult to acquire stuff... STOP NERFING FUN THINGS #justicefortickmacuahuitl. Restore all the poison builds, tick sword, and other fun things you nerfed to their former 1.0 glory, and only buff the ones you want people to use more. Stop taking the fun out of it, this is a PVE game, there is no need to constantly nerf the fun weapons just to keep people from using them as a meta strategy. This 1.0.4 hotfix really killed the game for me, PVE doesn't need nerfs, there's no need to balance the game this hard, unless something is severely broken and not working properly, its not a PVP game, balances like they've been pushing out are so frustrating. 

- oh and the final fight, is severely not balanced for solo play on medium and woah, and the OPTIONAL boss at the end has a game breaking bug that causes your frames to drop to like 10 while fighting it on some machines. Gas arrows also seem to kill frames as well, and I have a RTX 2080 with an i9 and 32gb of memory, this computer can slay games like Cyberpunk, but particle effects in Grounded just murder it. 

Okay, rant over... thanks to the dev's 1.0.4 hotfix, I decided I'm over this game, I still wanted to complete it, I'd spent way too much time in it not to, but I was just kinda done. So I turned the game on Mild, switched off hunger and thirst, and speed ran all the final content just to get through the story and end my time in the backyard. I'm over it, and I don't think I'll be returning unless the devs were to seriously reconsider a LOT of things like I've mentioned above.

Grounded is a fun and creative game. It's similar to minecraft in regards to the open world and creative freedom that it gives you, but has a completely unique combat system, perks, quests/daily quests, scientific inventions and questionable food recipes. It's frustratingly fun having to deal with so many kinds of bugs and feeling the absolute horror of being chased by stink bugs, spiders, and worst of all... the infected.

I highly recommend this game. Especially with friends! 

I look forward to all future updates for this game, and hope they add something to keep us on our tiny toes. :)
They keep updating and supporting it. They are making it better and better as I play.
