One of my favourite games hands-down, this is because this game can never really get boring, yeah sure if you complete the story and get all achievements there isn't too much to do but with this game you can do whatever you want, with the creative mode, and multiplayer, and multiple downloadable assets, you can do whatever you want, you can go anywhere you want and you do anything you want.
(good things) this game never really gets boring, there is multiple side missions or side things you can do, like complete some quests, or get the milk molars, or get the cards and fill out your handbook.
fighting and pvp aren't terrible as some other games and each enemy has their own unique ability to make it interesting. there is hidden easter eggs throughout the map that you can find and a variety of weapons you can choose from. 
(bad things), getting the cards, inside the game if you find a enemy you can "peep" the enemy which marks it in your book and you can look at the picture of the insect, and it will give you a description of it, but some insects don't respawn, so if you forget to peep it you will be left with a empty space in your book and there is no way to get the card, some bosses also only spawn once so if you forget to peep it, again you won't be able to get the card again. (golden cards), these cards you get from killing so many of one insect, it's not numbers it's probability, most regular insects you have a 1 percent chance to get a gold card, and some bosses (excluding the bosses that only spawn once), will usually have a chance of 10 percent for a gold card, but this one "boss" called termite king, which sounds like a boss and acts like a boss and requires boss things, only has a 1 percent chance to drop the golden card, and if you kill him you have to wait another 3.5 hours in real time to try again, this took me like multiple weeks to get it. other annoying things are the puzzles throughout the game, building, and finally the final mission before you complete the story line. this game I would give a 8.9 out of 10 a lot of good things and a few bad things, overall very recommended.
Defeat buggy bosses, build epic bases, and overcome your crippling fear of spiders with (or without) your friends!

-Increase "gold card" drop rate (or add a mercy rule to give a gold card after 50 kills or something like that)
-Add upgrade paths for more rows inventory slots on top of current Mega Milk Molar stack size upgrades
-Fix issue where pet disappears and inventory they were holding also disappears

You do this and you'll finally earn my respect and endorsement. <3

It's like the love child of Subnautica and Honey I Shrunk the Kids.

Although, unlike Subnautica, there's a heavy emphasis on combat with any creatures you encounter. Everything is either a meal on wheels or it has the parts you need to construct a base, armor, weapons, or anything else.

I find the end game isn't quite as satisfying or diverse as the beginning. Later areas don't feel quite as alive or with the depth of critters as the early game. Many times, they feel like trumped up versions of what you already found before (like a ladybug and a ladybird).

Still, there's tons of variety. And the small team of developers continue to update the game after the 1.0 launch. No major new areas, but new critters to fight and new bosses.

Oh, and if you didn't have arachnophobia before, you absolutely will once you've played Grounded.

Fantastic survival/craft/base-building game with a real twist.  Though the concept of the game is not at all new, it sure hasn't been done in this kind of game before.   The scenery is breathtaking, especially when you get a good overhead view and and compare what the backyard really looks like (it's pretty small), compared to what it feels like when you are down there in the muck (it seems vast).  
Sound quality is also excellent, and you can really rely on audio cues for everything from avoiding the most dangerous foes in the early game, to timing your perfect blocks.

I definitely would recommend this to anyone who is a fan of survival/craft/base-building games.   If you like your survival games 'hard' and play this on the highest difficulty options it definitely delivers an experience far better than most survival games do for us gluttons for punishment.

Just keeps getting more improvements a year later.  Definitely should be on the "buy" list for any survival/crafting game fans.

Inability to roll back patches without resorting to piracy. Gabe newell once said "Piracy is a service issue" and this is a good case for that. At 119 hours in I'm not digging the new update at all, and I have no recourse to roll it back. Honestly its another bad move by xbox game studios and honestly they are so close to being on my ban list (Like EA, Ubisoft, Blizzard) that this isn't that shocking.  Really disappointed and going to Hail Mary for a refund even after 120 hours. Its just not worth the time to deal with devs constantly changing the experience for no reason or to meet some sort of vision that I really don't care about. I was having fun, Keyword: WAS

 I appreciate that out of all survival games I was able to make Grounded a super painless experience which was good for a simple relaxing time or playing with friends who have very limited or poor FPS skills. If i wanted a tougher time at all id play literally anything else on the market. Even in the space of arcadey survival games it faces titans like Subnautica, and even they botched their sequel. 

The new content is good quality but over balance changing this late in the game is obtrusive. I had the same problem with Cyberpunk but at least in that case CDProjektRed had the foresight to add the 1.6 patch to the betas list for players to roll back. I hated the perk and combat reblance but I was easily able to go back to the experience I enjoyed.

Honestly I play Grounded to shut my brain off and chill out. If i wanted restrictions on base building, 4 second delays on healing, among other changes then I would play something else. Which is what I'm going to have to do. 

Hope all who continue to play have fun but this is my stop and time to get off this game.

First off the crafting/base building is "the next level". I can't get enough of the way it motivates you to collect things. Yea it can get repetitive but still fresh at the same time. Exploration is consistently fresh and the "tone" of the map changes the more "story elements" you find/unlock. The story is borderline "horror adult". It's friendly look hides the undertone of horror that is the shrunk world. No "human blood and guts", but still if you think about it, it is scary as the thought of being hunted by spiders dawns on you. For me a jaded vet of games like this I restarted and played on the hardest difficulty and I love it. The challenge forces you to become Overpowered and still not be. If fact when you get decent stuff there is still fear of being outnumbered or a number of things. They also recently updated it for a more custom feature that is sure to entice cult-fans. 

In the end I did buy it at a discount but I would of paid full price for this gem.

Challenging, beautiful, rewarding, cute, Grounded is by far my favourite game in the genre!

i LOVE this game and consider it my all-time favourite survival game. since early access, Obsidian has provided incredible support and listened to players. they have also provided a whole bunch of updates (QOL, additional furniture/building assets etc.) since full release and have recently added a new sandbox gamemode, which is lovely in the era of everything being paid DLC. 

pros:
- a visual delight - the lighting!!! every time of day is so gorgeous!!!
- base building is easy for new players but has a high ceiling for what you can accomplish
- super cohesive art design, all the bugs are adorable and stylised really nicely
- ACCESSIBILITY TOOLS!! arachnophobia safe mode (as a slider with different levels to pick from) as well as a text to speech function for easier communication 
- lighthearted storytelling that delivers a fun narrative to follow. the kids are all really endearing and its fun to hear them banter with each other 

cons:
- multiplayer goes through xbox/microsoft so you do need an account with them even when playing on Steam. Connection can be a bit wobbly at times
- perfect blocking is really important in combat and aforementioned wobbly multiplayer connection can make that very difficult with any kind of latency 
- Cannot make a telescope with a dew drop and piece of grass like in A Bugs Life, stuck only using my feeble human hands to peep
This is really awesome game! Play it with friends and have fun. One of the best game ever

Grounded is a great, well-rounded sandbox experience. It has everything you’d expect from its genre: resource gathering ☑, crafting and upgrading ☑, base building ☑, combat and exploration ☑ – all of which combined create an impressive amount of depth. Not to mention countless small details and an abundance of content scattered around the yard.

I haven’t yet finished the game as of writing this review, but I expect to spend many more hours exploring this cool tiny world and seeing what new adventures it will take me on.

The only gripe I have has to do with how obscure some really fun parts of the game are. I just don’t like it when I have to sift through wiki articles in order to understand basic game mechanics, only to find out that I could have been using them for a while. Or when I need to find one specific item in the corner of the map to unlock new upgrades, items and structures.

But otherwise, it’s definitely one of my favorite games so far.

I've played a decent number of (mostly multiplayer) survival games, stuff like The Forest and Raft. It's a genre of games with a really big range of quality, plus a whole lot of ever-present jank. Sometimes they're good, even really good. Other times they're not so good.

Grounded is unique in that it's great.

Never before have I played a survival game with so much character and so much quality. It's certainly not perfect, the jank is certainly there (it's Obsidian, what did you expect?), but it does so so many things right (it's Obsidian, what did you expect?). The characters are all fun and unique and I love hearing them interact with each other, plus the audio logs are all campy and wonderful. It's the first game I've played that made first-person melee combat fun and interesting. It gives you so much freedom to fuck around and find out, and yet its several areas, bosses, and "dungeons" give a really nice feeling of progression.

I could sit here and list all the flaws I can come up with if I really wanted to, but that would be a waste of my time and yours. Looking at games like they're a collection of specifications to be compared rather than pieces of art to be admired is dumb and stupid. Just play Grounded, it's amazing.

(Also it's on Xbox Gamepass if that's your bag.)

Similar to The Forest, but better in just about every conceivable metric. The story isn't as dark or mysterious, but if you liked anything regarding the crafting, exploration, or survival aspects of that game, you'll surely appreciate this game. The mechanics and combat alone are shockingly clean and satisfying; the weapon swapping and animation cancelling potential leads to some very active fights with decent amount of skill expression. This is only made greater by the large variety of enemies found throughout the game as well as a handful of unique boss encounters.

It's difficult to overstate the level of polish exhibited by this game, which is very impressive considering the sheer volume of content present. The game is already very worth the purchase as is, and yet the devs continue to release major updates, only further improving upon an already great deal. I went into the game expecting another generic survival-craft with the aesthetic of a children's game, but instead was truly impressed by the scale and quality of the experience.

Probably one of my favorite survival games.

It seems as though Obsidian has taken great games that were already there and made them just a bit better. And yet here we are, with a unique survival game of it's own. Obviously this screams 'Honey, I Shrunk the Kids', has a very cartoon appearance and seems to be inspired and / or set in the 80's. Make no mistake though, this game can be punishing for the unprepared. The thought of trying to survive a backyard where the spiders triple your size is enticing enough. I want to say I started my adventure shortly after the Koi Pond update. I've watched this game continuously expand and grow since then at an alarming pace. Lots of love has been poured into this game, and appears to have tons of room for more. For any survival / rpg fans - this is a winner with an enormous amount of things to do / craft / explore and imagine. Be careful out there.

Edit: After 1.0 release and a fresh world, I can say - easily one of the best survival games of all time. Please don't neglect this game - continue to update it, it has so much potential and can be such an awesome experience. Nominate this for Game of the Year or Labor of Love. It deserves it!

Edit 2: Still worthy of Labor of Love

There's a bit of jank and quite a harsh learning curve at the start, but once you start getting the hang of the world (or backyard) you live in, the nuances of the combat and the intricacies of the building and crafting, Grounded manages to present one of the best survival sandboxes I’ve played since Subnautica.

And comparing it to Subnautica is surprisingly apt, as you find yourself stuck in an alien environment with terrifying threats that, if you want to advance the story and unlock better gear, you will be forced to face head first.

However, there’s one crucial detail that Grounded provides that Subnautica lacks: You are encouraged to test the wilds together with some friends! And it makes a huge difference. There is more of a dungeon-crawling aspect to the game once you have a party going, and defeating the daunting terrors of the yard becomes a grand adventure you forge onto together.

My friends and I have sunk a good number of hours into the game already, but it’s clear that we’re still far from the finish line, and I look forward to every opportunity we get to continue our escapade. Be it facing lowly ants, imposing stink bugs, or the absolutely terrifying spiders that the yard provides, I am far from sick of this romp.

Give it a go! But do it with some friends. It’s very lonely being shrunken down and stuck when you’re on your own.

[h3]Update:[/h3]
This was also an easy nomination for this years [url=https://store.steampowered.com/steamawards/nominations]The Steam Awards[/url] for the "[i]Labor of Love Award[/i]", it's a game that the developers have just continued to endlessly pour their blood, sweat and tears into, and that clearly shows!

I have over 600 hours in this game between 2 acounts, in the incredible world of Grounded, and it's safe to say that Obsidian Entertainment has crafted a gem for PC gamers.

*Ease of Play:*
Navigating the game is a breeze, making it accessible for both seasoned players and newcomers. The controls are intuitive, ensuring a smooth gaming experience.

*Colors:*
The vibrant and well-balanced color palette brings the backyard to life. It adds a visually appealing touch to the game, enhancing the overall immersion.

*Item Variety:*
Grounded impresses with its diverse array of items. From makeshift weapons to resource-gathering tools, the game offers a satisfying variety that keeps gameplay fresh and engaging.

*Build Mode:*
The build mode is a standout feature, allowing players to unleash their creativity in the miniature world. Constructing bases becomes a joy, offering strategic depth to the gameplay.

*Crafting Ease:*
Crafting is straightforward and user-friendly. The crafting system adds a layer of depth without becoming overly complex, striking a perfect balance.

*Interactivity of Environment:*
The environment feels alive and interactive. From the rustling blades of grass to the gentle sway of leaves, every detail contributes to an immersive and captivating experience.

*Enemies and Difficulties:*
Grounded doesn't disappoint in the threat department. The variety of enemies and their increasing difficulties keep the gameplay challenging and rewarding.

*Overall Adorableness:*
Grounded's charm is undeniable. The adorable character designs and the scaled-down world contribute to an overall cute aesthetic that puts a smile on your face.

*Attention to Details:*
Obsidian Entertainment's meticulous attention to detail is evident throughout the game. Every nook and cranny of the backyard is rich with subtle touches that enhance the overall atmosphere.

*Remarkable Lighting and Shadowing:*
The lighting and shadow effects are nothing short of remarkable. They add depth to the visuals, creating a dynamic and visually stunning world.

*Great Multiplayer:*
Grounded truly shines in multiplayer. Cooperative play is seamless, and the shared exploration and construction experiences make it a fantastic game to enjoy with friends.

In summary, Grounded is a miniature masterpiece that excels in gameplay, visuals, and multiplayer dynamics. Whether you're an avid gamer or new to the scene, this game offers a delightful and memorable journey into the backyard wilderness. Highly recommended!

As someone who achievements grinds games from time to time, the newest update completely ruined trying to 100% this game. Previously it was already tedious but they added that you have to have every golden creature card to achieve 100%. 
These are pretty rare cards that you can receive by killing a bug, and harvesting their remains. (according to the grounded wiki) , there is a 1% drop chance for a gold card with at base for ordinary creatures. As well as a 10% drop chance for repeatable bosses. This doesn't include the infected broodmother that has a lower drop chance. Which is already in my opinion the most annoying boss fight to do, as it has three phases.
In fact, the percentage drop for the infected broodmother is only 5%, (according to the grounded wiki) even though it is a repeatable boss. in my opinion this just completely ruins trying to grind for 100% on this game, and was completely unnecessary. 
Grinding for games shouldn't be so tedious that it makes you want to just quit because you might have spent multiple days just trying to get the creature cards needed.

Original text: This game was great. But see my playtime? How long it is? at least 40% of that playtime was COMPLETELY WASTED and useless because they riddle the entire map with inaccessible objectives FROM THE START OF THE GAME that you can't even TOUCH until right before the END GAME. And we still haven't even finished the game yet, yet have only explored 4 set piece areas? So....basically...you start the game. Then it goes "here's your main objectives! And some side objectives *if you wanna do them*! Have fun!" but COMPLETELY DOESN'T TELL YOU THAT EVERY SINGLE SIDE OBJECTIVE IS INACCESSIBLE UNTIL AFTER EVERY MAIN OBJECTIVE HAS BEEN ACCOMPLISHED. 

Me and my bf spent 30-40 hours scouring the entire game world looking for ways to access these optional areas, but it turns out every single optional area is locked off by design until you've finished 4 out of 5 of the main quest objectives in the entire game. I had to find this out by Googling answers...I was really trying hard not to look anything up, too, but the game gives you zero information! My #1 rule for video games is DON'T WASTE MY TIME and despite how good this game is, I'm so annoyed how unclear they were about the objectives I'm not even going to recommend the whole thing.

DEVS: IF YOU'RE GOING TO GIVE ME AN OPEN WORLD CRAFTING GAME AND THEN FORCE ME TO EXPLORE IT IN THE SPECIFIC WAY YOU WANT ME TO, YOU GOTTA AT LEAST MAKE IT CRYSTAL CLEAR I HAVE NO ACTUAL CHOICES AND AM DOING IT WRONG IF I'M NOT FOLLOWING THE QUESTS!

P.s. the game takes a huge dive in general about 65% of the way through, as the whole northern area of the map seems to be designed as nothing but a time sink of endless tedious enemies, with any new bugs you need for upgrades specifically hidden in small areas you don't discover until you basically finish the game. So no exploration once again until you get those main quests done. 

They really phoned this game in after early access, IMO. Basically. It feels like they play tested the hell out of the first 30 hours to make sure it felt good for early access, then just shrugged and checked off content boxes and released the rest without even checking to make sure if it was fun. A waste of a really cool concept, really. Bummer.

IF you like minecraft but want a more immersive experience and aren't too scared of bugs then you should consider buying this. I enjoyed building and crafting in this game.  It's been fun so far whether solo or playing in a group of friends.

I am not the target audience, and if you aren't a huge fan of combat, neither are you.

I was lured in by an imaginative, exploratory basebuilding game, but there's a lot of combat. And scarce options in the game settings to tweak that. Random base raids, enemy damage being all-or-nothing, and tightly integrated combat to the storyline make the game less appealing to a casual player like me. And while I appreciate the lack of glass walls - I can just build stairs up a wall if I spend enough time - repeatedly encountering a lab entrance that just says "locked" kills that vibe. It feels like the devs have intentionally stretched out the playtime of the game. I really like the concept of the game, of reimagining the world from a new point of view, but it's just targeted at an audience that excludes me.
good game

If you're looking to sink weeks into a fantastic survival craft world with your homies, it really doesn't get much better than Grounded. I can't recommend this game enough. I tend to get overwhelmed with survival craft games due to my ADHD because there is just too much to do and I experience choice paralysis. But with Grounded, I was always looking forward to the next thing. I had such fun with this game, I grinded out the 100% this last week.

[h1]THE GOOD AND THE FANTASTIC -[/h1]
- The games vibes are immaculate. It's the perfect rendition of a bunch of 80s kids getting shrunk down in a backyard and surviving using cartoon-ish science. The style of the game, the designs of the bugs, the music and ambient noise--it's perfect. Grounded achieves everything that it is trying to do and more.
- Amazing game progression. I never lost steam in the game because I always knew what I wanted to do next.
- "Shared worlds" (basically like Minecraft Realms) where your friends can log onto the world without you and push the save to the Microsoft servers. Anyone can then load the save and see what was built/achieved while they were gone.
- Fantastic combat system with a perfect parry system?! What the heck?! It's way too good.
- Crafting system where all the ingredients make cartoonish sense for what you're building.
- Unique and interesting builds and gameplay styles depending on your mutations, armor sets, and weapon choice.
- Unique dialogue depending on the characters that you play.
- The map is huge and full of surprises and things to discover. Unlike a lot of other survival craft games, the map of Grounded is NOT procedurally generated but hand-crafted. Every secret and collectable is placed with purpose.
- The best 3D base building I have ever experienced. It has all the QOL you could want from base building and also fun furniture options.

[h1]THE NOT-SO-GOOD -[/h1]
- My fellow arachnophobes, be careful... this game is gonna be real hard to get through...
- Because this is a multi-session kind of game, multiplayer connectivity and desync issues are going to happen.
- Very late game can be a bit of a slog to get through.
- Grounded is a shining example of a game that is incredibly fun to play through and beat but a horrible pain in the ass to 100%.

EDIT [11/15/2023] - Today, I saw that Grounded had a massive 1.3 edit that makes 100%ing the game much better and adds more difficulty options. When I played, there was no way to tell which SCA.Bs and Molars you already picked up which made it a huge chore. They revamped the map and added this information. Amazing... what did we do to deserve devs like these?

[h1]TL;DR - If looking at the screenshots of the game excites you, get it. You won't regret it. [/h1]

Not often I write a review but this deserves one. 
This game has been great fun. Me and a friend have regularly come back to it each time a new update has come out (we started playing when it was still relatively new as an early access game) and even though we normally get through the new content within, say, 2 weeks of casual play, we always continue for a while as there's always something to keep it enjoyable afterwards. 
I did find it got a bit old after a few playthroughs but that's to be expected, what isn't expected however is just how much Obsidian are doing with the game, I'm always impressed to see how much they add each time and after the last update I thought it would be the last. It's great to see a game company who actually care enough about their content to continue working on it and trying to ensure people can continue enjoying it even after release without simply pumping out overpriced DLC that barely adds anything to the game. I've reached out to them once about a bug which was the only time I had anything that was enough of an issue to take note of. And they not only replied quickly but also got it sorted just as fast. It was clear they actually took note of it too rather than throwing you through the normal loops you often get with larger franchise games, if they even bother responding which is really refreshing.

[list]

  [*]Don't Starve

Recommend for anyone, highly recommend for open world survival fans.

The game is brilliant (Version 1.2.6). I think, this is the most enjoyable piece of Software since years. Everything looks pretty well thought out. The whole span of the story with it kinks and changes is great and not to much or to little, the variety and the side tasks never make the game a repetitive chore. The whole map is fantastic, with its countless lairs and dungeons, the treasure hunts, easter eggs, etc., in which you are almost automatically guided further and further by the story and tasks and where you can constantly make new discoveries and keep the game experience fresh. It is always challenging and exciting to venture into new areas. Surprises are waiting everywhere. The base building is nice and looks great, even the buffs you will get from it is a nice little addition. 
Fighting and movement works as it should be (omg, how many games could not bring these basic things together!?), all the Setting, the NPCs and Mobs are well done and have have their own behaviour pattern, in fights all readable. Fighting is challenging when playing Solo, the down scaling from multiplayer could be better, but that is not a real issue at all. The stamina system never gets in the way of fighting, it feels natural and fits perfectly (Hello Valheim!! Look here!).
Also the system with the mutations is awesome! The itemization is great and the need to plan your equipment for the next excursion makes this game even better. The Progress with Equipment through the tiers and the constantly increasing level of difficulty fits perfectly together. The User Interface works, the Quality of Life things like the automatic stashing of your inventory in your base, building and crafting auf of the stashes etc etc. Everything is working greatly. It's just that the few npc voice overs quickly becomes too repetitive.
If you like Valheim and never played Grounded: Instant downloed this game and you will know, what Valheim is missing (a good fight and movementsystem!)! Unbelievably, this game almost passed me by because the comic-like graphics and especially the publisher and X-Box bullshit put me off at first. I can not believe that there was not a bigger hype arround this little gem! Since the map is fixed and not procedural, the replay value isn't as high as in Valheim, but that's said while playing 2 playthroughs at once (one in group, one solo).
This is by far the best survival base builder I played (and I played a lot!) It is a VERY positive example of finished software and a great, well thought-out game, both in terms of story and game mechanics. Except for the X-Box crap.

[h1]  Fun But Got Stuck in the End  [/h1] 

Grounded was a blast with enjoyable and mysterious adventure in a miniature world, offering a fascinating map and engaging gameplay. However, the experience takes an unexpected turn towards the end game. 

! Spoiler Warning !

[spoiler] Without clear warnings or guidance, players may find themselves at a critical juncture where they need to defend multiple locations simultaneously. This challenge becomes particularly daunting for solo players or even duos.

Turns out, building walls is key for defense, but there was no information or a hint was given earlier. Now, I'm getting bombarded by O.R.C bugs, and I can't even get to my base. Solo or even with a buddy, it's a struggle. Wish I knew about this madness before diving in. :)

I wanted to keep exploring, but these relentless attacks have me stuck. It's like, "Let me enjoy the game, please!" Grounded is awesome, but a heads-up on the defense thing would've been golden. Now, I'm just bug-swatting instead of having a good time exploring the rest of this tiny world.   [/spoiler]

"Bug's Life" meets "Honey, I Shrunk the Kids"... THE VIDEO GAME

I started playing this game pretty much with all cheats enabled, because I wanted to get a feel for it. Within 10 minutes however, I started a new save that was MUCH more survival-based, simply because the world was so fun to explore and I wanted to get the full experience. 

This game feels a lot like ARK: Survival Evolved at first, with one of your first goals being the crafting of tools and establishment of a shelter, then figuring out how to stop AVOIDING all of the scary insects and spiders, and actually take them on (on purpose). The story of the game is pretty fun, and while a certain NPC can get pretty annoying at times, it's still a fun ride.

The thrill you get from your first spider take-down (and there are several varieties, meaning you get said thrill several times!) is unbelievable, like taking down a Souls boss for the first time. The combat can get a bit repetitive at times, and by the end of the game your inventory will likely remain constantly half-full of various weapons, simply because so many insects/creatures have very different weaknesses. The combat system has modifiers for basic things (piercing damage, blunt damage, chopping damage, etc.), in addition to 'elemental' damage types (think fire and ice damage, but with much more comical in-game implementation), so you can only be so-prepared to face various threats unless you account for a lot of possible encounters. 

The building aspect of the game is a lot of fun. If you want a relatively easy/fast progression, enabling and using your Handy Gnat can let you teleport your possessions AND yourself (claim a bedroll, move it somewhere else with your Gnat, enable 'keep-inventory', die, then respawn wherever your Gnat put the bedroll, even across the map) and you can cheese some pretty tough enemies if you're clever by building, but in the end the game is as hard as you want it to be. I really enjoy all of the customization options, though there are several missing construction shapes that would be really nice to have. Base construction absolutely takes up a good chunk of my play-time, because that's part of the game I really enjoy (Fallout 4, ARK: SE, Return to Moria, Satisfactory, Minecraft, base-building is fun!).

This game has actually made me more likely to take in my surroundings. I've started noticing the small details on the ground a lot more often since diving into this game, such as seeing an interesting mushroom formation and thinking about how a 1cm-tall person could parkour it. Taking walks with my dog has an additional fun aspect because of that!

As for difficulty, as mentioned earlier it's pretty much as hard as you want it to be. Now there are a few things that likely will take a few tries to get through (yes, there is an 'underwater level'), but in the end you can make it as easy or as hard as you want. And if your parkour skills aren't fantastic, well probably start practicing. 
Disclaimer: I have only ever played solo.

A survival game, where you explore the backyard of a house after being shrunken to roughly the size of an ant,  This is a very narrative focused survival game, much like Subnautica, but it has a huge amount of freedom as well.  It has the standard gathering, building, exploring aspects of other survival games, but the setting really gives it a unique feel.  Climbing grass, collecting dew, fighting roly-polys, etc is just not something you see everyday.  You will need to progress the story to move forward though.  The graphics are very cartoony, and the game starts out fairly easy, but don't let that fool you.  The game becomes very challenging and the backyard is huge with lots of things to keep you busy.

The main pros, to me, are the setting and the exploration aspect of the game.  There is a ton to explore, with new resources, new creatures and new biomes to challenge you.  I played this in 2022/2023, and there had been several very large content drops before I started playing, so older reviews may not reflect this.  The building lets you get creative and it is fairly easy to align and plan, though it can take a while to unlock that variety.  There are many types of weapons and armors to cater to many styles of combat.  The story kept me engaged but was a bit goofy and light-hearted for my tastes.  It is also co-op but I played 100% solo so no idea how well that is implemented.

The biggest cons, are the very consolely interface and the need to login to XBox to get achievements.  Huge text, radial menus, limited save locations and clunky menus.  Disappointing but you get used to it, and may be preferred by those playing on a TV or using controllers.  Beyond that, the game can get very difficult, too difficult in some places.  The final boss (which I think is optional) was a crazy, unfun battle and I needed to lower the difficulty for it (the only time).  Even on easy this battle was pretty crazy.  I don't want to spoil things so I won't go into details.  Maybe I could have beaten it on medium but I definitely would have needed to max out most of my equipment and built things like bombs which are tedious to make..  There are other bosses which I didn't bother to try and fight because I struggled enough with just normal enemies (wolf spiders, black widows, black ox beetles, etc).  This is partially me just not being great at the combat (I suck at perfect blocking), but I gather it will get daunting for most people in places.  Combat is also a bit clunky feeling, with most weapons being slow and you running out of stamina often.  Also, for my tastes, there was actually too much content.  The game was very good, but it got a bit tedious later in the game and I just wanted it to end after a while.  This is partly because of the difficulty, with many powerful bugs that are seemingly around every corner and the large distances that need to be traveled.  There is no fast travel but you can eventually build some things to help with moving around (mutations, equipment and zip lines).  The ziplines are great but it can take a lot of effort to set these up as there are so many things that get in the way.  I also like to explore and do most of the content, so I played longer than I needed to (didn't 100% the game or anything though).  Still only like 4% of people finished the game, so I don't think I'm alone.

It is a great game though, just be prepared to sink some real time into it if you want to finish it and unlock most of it's secrets.  If you just want a nice, relaxing diversion, it may not be what you want.

In the gripping and fantastic survival adventure game Grounded, you take on the role of a shrinking child in a dangerous garden. I've spent 920 hours playing the game so far and I really enjoy it; I suggest it.

You have to explore, craft, and battle your way through a world full of enormous insects, plants, and other dangers. The game is full of surprises and obstacles. The story of the game is deep and captivating, revealing the mysteries of your shrinkage and the insane scientist responsible. You can play the game online by yourself or with friends, and you can alter the character, base, and difficulty settings. This adds to the game's replay value.

It's one of the best survival games I've played, and I can't stop playing it. It is a fun, inventive, and masterwork of game design. Anybody who enjoys sandbox, adventure, or survival games should definitely play it.

Grounded on its surface may seem like a cute sandbox building game where you're shrunk to the size of an ant and have to survive in the wilds, but believe me, this is one game where looks can be deceiving. On the surface, Grounded contains all the normal elements of your everyday survival game. Manage hunger and hydration whilst you venture around the backyard, gathering resources to build your own camp whilst fighting off all manner of creatures that want to eat you. But it is so so much more than just this. Let's get into all the awesome things you can expect.

1. Biomes
On the surface of things, one may think "How could you turn a backyard into a set of distinct and unique biomes?" Well, Grounded does ALL of that, and so much more. Explore the undergrowth in the Grasslands, dive into the depths of a massive Koi Pond, navigate your way through the surprisingly labyrinthine branches of the Hedge, or try to survive the blistering heat of the Sandbox on your hunt for buried treasure. There are 16 unique biomes in the backyard, as well as many tunnels and dungeons to delve through, from anthills, spider nests, and long forgotten ruins of tiny human activities.

2. Creatures
Grounded will pitch you against many different type of creature, each with their own character, style, and attack preferences. Fight your way through hordes of ants and termites to plunder their food stores, sneak past the spiders and try to avoid getting yourself trapped in their confounded webbing, or test your mettle against the mighty black ox beetles that roam the jungles of the Upper Yard. But don't think the bugs aren't taking notice of your actions. If you bother them too much, you might find they pay you a visit when you return home...

3. Character Progression
As well as having survival and combat elements, Grounded also gives your character many ways to progress in the game, from crafting better tools and weapons from the remains of slain foes, to infusing your character with the power of Yoked Girth Milk Molars. You will uncover character perks as your explore, known as Mutations, which you can activate or deactivate at any time to give yourself advantages in many different situations. Weapons and armor can also be upgraded and imbued with special properties, take advantage of creature weaknesses with elemental weapon upgrades, or give your armor hidden properties with sleek upgrades.

4. Story
Grounded has a fully playable story that will have you exploring the backyard in its entirety. It all starts when trying to reactivate the Mysterious Machine to grow back to your normal size - which unfortunately for you, ends in cataclysmic failure, causing explosive damage to a nearby oak tree and its unassuming robotic resident, BURG.L - Acting Science Manager for Dr Wendell Tully. But it will soon be revealed that the explosion corrupted BURG.Ls memory banks, and he can't remember how to fix the Mysterious Machine. But he does know he has backup files on Super Chips scattered throughout the backyard. It is your mission, brave adventurer, to retrieve them, return them to BURG.L, and try to piece together how you got so small, where Wendell has gone, and most importantly, how to get you home.

5. Exploration
As well as exploring the backyard to help BURG.L recover his memories, there are tons of optional areas to explore as well, all having their own secrets and rewards. Discover the story of past long lost adventurers from Ominent, brought here and tasked with the documentation and classification of Wendell's research and his whereabouts, or discover what happens when you activate all of the MIX.Rs located throughout the backyard. Or follow the stories of the four BIG BUG BOSSES and make it your quest to rid the backyard of these tyrannical creatures... After finding just the right thing to lure them out of hiding. What in the world could enjoy the taste of a Mouldy Haogie!?

6. Base Building
The base building in Grounded is extensive and comprises of several tiers of building structures, starting at grass plank and weed stem buildings, all the way through to mushroom brick and cement structures as the game progresses. As well as having many building options, you can decorate your base with all manner of furniture, crafting stations, lighting and trophies of all the creatures you've killed on your adventures. You can build in most parts of the backyard, and even connect bases with ziplines for fast travel across the backyard.  You will also have access to traps and turrets to defend your base when the bugs come knocking, because believe me, they will, and you'll need to be prepared for the onslaught!

As of the 1.2 Super Duper update, building bases now becomes even more important. As you get a better base, you get higher levels of Coziness, and that gives you new buffs whilst you're in your base, even unlocking more build pieces for you to use. Some of these build pieces also have extra uses when interacted with, like bug wall trophies giving you attack buffs against that particular type of creature, the stuffed bug statues giving you extra chances for rare loot, and the new Petal Bed giving the Comfy Stamina and Comfy Defense buffs to anyone who sleeps in it for the entire next day.

7. Bosses
Grounded has a mixture of required and optional bosses to complete the story. Without giving too much away, there are 2 main story bosses and 5 extra, completely optional bosses that you can fight. All story and optional bosses give you a special mutation upon their defeat, so even if the other five are not required to complete the story, the experience is worth it and the things you can craft from their parts are definitely worth it.

8. Playgrounds
Do you want to make your own maps and challenges in the world of Grounded? With the 1.3 update, you can now create your very own Playgrounds and custom interactions between objects! Place most terrain pieces and points of interest, down to each individual blade of grass, spawn bugs anywhere including bosses, make parkour maps and arenas, the only limit is your creativity!

Now we have some other things to talk about that will make themselves more apparent after a playthrough or two.

1. No Modding Support
Mods for Grounded are extremely limited currently as Obsidian have not enabled mod support for their game at the moment, and have stated that this is not planned. A small group of modders have currently been working on a project to inject mod pak files, but this is not fully finished as of yet. Since the game is built on Unreal Engine we also don't have luxuries like Harmony or BepInEx, making mod creation a little tougher as well.

2. Late Game Creatures
A good majority of the creatures in the late game are essentially reskins of the early game creatures you find in the grasslands. Most of these have some alternate attacks compared to their original counterparts and hit harder, but you may find variety a little lacking. Example: Ladybird being a reskin of a Ladybug. Whilst this is not a dealbreaker or anything, it would be nice eventually to see more variety of creatures in the end game, and as of the 1.2 Super Duper update, the devs have introduced 4 more creatures, 2 of them being bosses. The other noticeable part is that some biomes, such as the Sandbox, only have one type of creature that predominantly resides there, and you won't see much variety in the entire biome. It would be great in future updates if these were fleshed out some more.

Overall, I can highly recommend Grounded. Even after the 1.0 launch the Obsidian team are working hard on more updates, more base pieces, more bosses, and more content for us. Things did feel a little sketchy when 1.0 came out due to much content getting scrapped last minute, but rest assured the 1.2.2 update has convinced me that this game is FAR from done.

I recommend playing this game. Therefore, I got a lot of multiplayer issues while playing in duo. I kicked me out of the game way too much. I am now the host and it stopped very happy.
Game is much good. yaes, much.

What I like:
Art style, very pleasant for the eye
Building and crafting, the uniqueness of each weapon and armor.
Lots of things to collect, like the creature cards, molars and items. I like games where you have to collect things
The achievements to unlock, all are fun to unlock and not very hard
The story-line, is very interesting and with many lighthearted moments
The custom game mode, after I finished the game on regular mode I played for many hours on custom and built everything that was hard resource-wise on regular

What I wish was in the game:
The story line to be longer, I feel the early game quests are easy and you progress rather quick. That might be my personal experience since I had played the game since early access and had a stronger start when the game launched. But, even after a second playthrough the story felt short.
I wish they fixed the pet bugs AI. when I travel on ziplines they bump onto you so often its infuriating, kicking you off the zipline and having to walk to the destination, which for a long zipline is often times from one corner of the map to the other.
I would love if they didn't cut off content like the inside of the shed, which from the leaks seemed to be almost finished. Or maybe some DLC going to the veranda or even the house. This is no major issue, but could help the developers add a few twists to the story and make it longer.
What I really love on the game are the MIX.R, super MIX.R and JavaMatic missions. they don't guide you at all on how to defend them, and that's what makes them good. you have to build defenses using the building mechanic, resources and your imagination. also there are a few SCA.B schemes that you need to build to get to, those are good moments as well, because the game doesn't tell you how to get them. what I wish was on the game essentially is having more of these moments where you use whatever there's in the game to get something. that's why I like the building mechanic and ziplines especially. you can build as many ziplines you like, anywhere you like, basically "breaking" the game's difficulty if you're creative and hard working enough.

Overall the game's one of the best I have played and would recommend to anyone who likes survival games.

In the vast realm of interactive entertainment, Obsidian Entertainment's magnum opus, "Grounded," emerges as a resplendent testament to the boundless creativity of human ingenuity. This masterful fusion of captivating storytelling and immersive gameplay unfurls within the confines of a mesmerizing microcosm, where players are irresistibly drawn into the enchanting tapestry of a backyard teeming with life. In this exquisite odyssey, the mundane transforms into the extraordinary, as players shrink to the size of minuscule insects, their perspective altering with a cosmic profundity. What elevates "Grounded" to the echelons of greatness is not merely its technical prowess, but its ability to evoke a profound sense of wonder and awe. With each meticulously crafted detail, the verdant foliage, shimmering dewdrops, and the frenetic dance of arachnids all coalesce into a symphony of visual splendor, immersing players in a world that transcends the confines of mere pixels and polygons.

Beyond its visual splendor, "Grounded" enchants the soul with its rich tapestry of gameplay mechanics, a veritable feast for the senses and intellect alike. The game ingeniously marries survivalist instincts with the unbridled curiosity of childhood, inviting players to navigate a labyrinthine maze of challenges while nurturing their innate sense of wonder. The sheer diversity of flora and fauna, each meticulously designed to reflect the awe-inspiring intricacies of the natural world, serves as a testament to the developers' dedication to authenticity. In this realm, teamwork becomes paramount, forging bonds among players akin to the delicate filaments of a spider's web. "Grounded" transcends the boundaries of conventional gaming, becoming an immersive voyage that stimulates the mind, ignites the imagination, and, above all, celebrates the unbridled spirit of exploration that resides within us all. Truly, it stands as a beacon in the gaming landscape, inviting adventurers to embark on a transformative odyssey where the mundane metamorphoses into the extraordinary, and the extraordinary, in turn, becomes an inseparable part of the human soul.

I really wanted to like Grounded.  It has all the things I like about survival games (for the most part).  But... unless you really enjoy combat... the tech tree is broken.  At some point in the game, you'll find out that you need Tier 2 equipment to keep moving forward (without dying constantly).  No problem...except...I'm having a hard time getting Tier 2 equipment because you need spider parts (or other difficult to kill bugs) to build most of them.  Again...no problem...except...the spiders kill me before I can kill them.  So...maybe I'm doing it wrong...so I look up videos/guides of "How to kill spiders".  First thing every one of them says is "Make sure you have Tier 2 equipment before going to kill them".  So...you get a chicken and the egg problem.  Can't get Tier 2 equipment without killing spiders...which requires Tier 2 equipment (or lots of frustration/death/luck).

Maybe if you play this on co-op its a lot easier (I could see how killing spiders and other difficult creatures would be a lot easier with help).  But...for a solo adventurer, the game eventually just comes to a halt.

Wanted to like it...played for a long time and did enjoy it for a while.

This is my new obsession.  
I played 'Subnautica' with a nearly equal fervor, but was disappointed by the lack of any real ability to defend myself.  If you're looking for a game that immerses you, makes you feel like you're running for your life, and then gradually learn how to fight back until you're an unstoppable force of will- well you're in luck!
I have tried my best to not use outside resources, but there were a few things I overlooked which in hindsight were comically difficult to miss, however my recommendation stands: you'll get the most out of this game by following the leads given.  There are no hard rails in this game.  There's nothing really stopping you from simply creating the most lavish and defensible dwellings you can imagine.  It's your game and you can choose or create whatever fighting style works best for you.  
I have been playing computer games since Wolfenstein and Doom were first out (on CD ROM!) and this game has me hooked like no other.  
There's so much to find, so much to learn, terrors to overcome, your curiosity and desire to explore are constantly rewarded, and heroic battles to leave you trembling with excitement.  I have never played anything like it, and once it's done I may need to take a break from games for awhile, heh.

Update 2 from October 2023: Changed from thumbs down to thumbs up. The game has gone from a clear 49% for me, to 51%. ;) From "Too annoying to play" to "Still anoying to play, but the fun part slightly outweighs the annoyance. Even if the difficulty spikes are beyond crazy."

The game has improved since its premature release. Some of the not-so-nice things were patched. What is still most annoying to me is that when you pick up stuff and switch equipment, your backpack's content is automatically re-arranged in what seems to be a random logic. If you can stand this, can stand accidentally tearing down your whole castle because you pulled the wrong brick out of one of its walls, and you do not mind (real-life) days of gathering resources, even for bare-minumum bases, I whole-heartedly recommend playing this game.

Warning to everyone who expects a game with a balanced difficulty, though: This is not it. The game can go from "relaxing" to "WTF - I am dead?" within seconds. Even on Easy setting.

- - -

Update 1 from August 2022: The devs announced today that the game will leave Early Access in late September 2022. So, it is likely that the basic problems that are here today will be the problems in the "finished" game.

So, here is my take on Grounded as of late July 2022 - it could be an almost brilliant game. Note the "could".

- - -

My pre-announcement review - I do not expect any of this to change until release:

The game is a mess. It would be fine for $15 and three years more of development, but not priced as a AA game, closing development in two months, with extensive announced additions. Which - as it looks like - will be tested by the gamers in the FINAL version and never fixed, as they pull out the development staff.

If they actually finished and polished the game, it would be a gem among immersive survival games, surpassing Subnautica. Fat chance that they can do this in the remaining two months, when most of the staff will be moved to other Obsidian projects.

For the moment, a clear thumbs down for me, unfortunately. I like what the game had the potential to be, but it is a mile away from that point. The few steps they can take in the remaining two months will make a potentially brilliant game to just be almost good.

Why?

- Too many unfixed bugs and janky features that have been known for years. Every few minutes I stare open-mouthed at the screen and think "How is this not fixed? It happens so often and is annoying as stepping into a turd in real life." Just a few examples: Everytime you interact with the inventory, it gets resorted, and not in a consistent way; good luck finding something you just added to the inventory five seconds ago. You can set one (ONE!) marker on the map which disappears from view when the game feels like it. Your character can get into a state where it is impossible to  do certain things, e.g. climb a ladder. The list goes on and on. The building system is janky, as well. Imagine a castle crashing down because you remove one stone.

- Vastly missing quality of life UI features, UI bugs aside. Plus, those UI features that exist are a drag to use with mouse & keyboard: "Let me quickly eat this mushroom I stored for situations like this." Four keystrokes later ... "Oh, wait, I have to find it in the inventory first." They could learn much from the Subnautica UI. Even from 7 Days to Die. Preventing a deadly opponent spawning begind you in your castle? Long solved  by 7D2D, an unsurmountable probnlem for Grounded. You  just die.

- I see where they were going with the sound stage. They are not there, yet, unfortunately. A dog barking in the distance should not play a sample of "Dog, barking". They got it almost right for the backyard crow, looking as big as a skyscraper. When the crow lands on a perch, that sounds like a rockslide. Being the size I am, I would not hear a barking dog. I would either be shaken by a subsonic wave, or notice nothing at all. If they got these super- and sub-perception sounds right, it could be awesome. Not enough time, though.

Currently, it looks like the game will forever be a case of "almost good". Let us hope that they do not introduce so many bugs in the final version that it become "almost unplayable" instead. Remember, we are talking about a major game studio that has earned almost $100 million already from selling the beta version, not a team of starving, inexperienced newcomers.

What does work already, and actually impresses me:

- The immersion into the environment. The backyard does feel like a jungle / desert / swamp. Visuals, sound, and small details feel great.

- The animals and plants. When blades of grass sway in the distance, you know that a potential enemy beyond a certain weight goes there. Or a harmless ladybug.

The game is fun when it works, but most of the time it does not.

Should you buy Grounded while it still is in Early Access?

If you loved Subnautica, my advicve is to wait until it is out of Early Access. Only those players who played Subnautica for the challenge of killing each Reaper several times over will be guaranteed satisfaction for buying Grounded now. For those who liked to participate in the Subnautica Beta, I would also advise a buy.

If you like what you see in the videos praising the game and have not yet played Subnautice or Subnautica Below Zero, play those first. Remember: Youtubers who seem to be out of themselves for excitement when they present a game video - they make money with the video. The more excitement they show, the more views they generate, which translates into ad income.

The two Subnautica games evoke the feeling which Grounded tries to achieve. (Below Zero for a more guided experience, Subnautica if you like to explore a lot on your own, and do not mind getting frustrated now and then.)

Why do I constantly compare Grounded to Subnautica?

The closest how I could describe Grounded to someone is "Subnautica, but the Leviathan killer monsters are out to get you right from the start." You will get the same picture when reading some other reviews. Imagine getting killed by a Leviathan on day 2 repeatedly, while you do not have any idea yet how to build a base. That is the initial Grounded experience.

Manageable, after you understand how the game works. Likely demotivating before that point.

After this, be prepared to grind, and also grind, and grind some more.  For resources.

Otherwise your castle, your bulwark against attacks from hostile animal armies - it will be not the size of a castle, it will be a bathroom with barely the space for sink and toilet. On each attack, you risk losing all the different workbenches you had to build outside, as you did not have the room in your monk's cell. This is why it is easier to play the game with your friends or family. Provided you find someone among them who can stand, as one of the other reviewers put it, "to grind for seven hours, to achieve one hour of game progress".

This game balance is all over the places. Weapons (status effect arrows) are unusable because they cost so much to make for the little damage they do. Enemies are overpowered (wasp) and raids are just over destructive sessions. You kill normal moskitoes and larva and you got Tiger and Lava versions coming instead. 

I truly thought for a while that Obsidian knew what they were doing and show the world how to make a proper survival type game. It seems that either the veteran devs became lazy or that juniors are handling deployment without vet supervision. Plus don't get me started on the typical Unreal engine collision clipping (falling out of the map, enemies stuck in the ground, stuck everywhere on the map trying to run or jump).

For a survival game, it's pretty amazing - the progression system is near perfect; the feeding component is not too intrusive on the gameplay while giving you a few options in terms of what to eat.   

Combat, is pretty solid, the choice of mutations, armor, weapons and learning when to block, the patterns of attack of the various bugs, their weaknesses... that's not quiet "souls like" but there's a lot more depth than just wacking away till dead.

Graphically it's good, but I would probably prefer having more option to tweak than the presets provided by the menu - it may look a bit blurry at times.

Sounds, they're ok... nothing amazing, and the music while decent is easily forgettable.  The character dialogues though really add to the feel of the game. 

With its bright colours, cartoon style, and humour ... it's still pretty much an "horror" game.  

The experience is pretty good as a solo player, however this game shines in coop with friends - the only thing is the way multiplayer sessions are hosted is probably not going to please everyone.   Dedicated servers for 4 players may seem overkill, but having one player hosting for the others - and having a shared save on the xbox network is not exactly great.

I purchased this game, very hesitantly, when it was on sale. Hesitant, because it was still in early access and I assumed it was unfinished. And, I also felt the concept was cartoonish. 

Anyway, I started on medium difficulty and boy oh boy, what a steep learning curve it was. The first 10 days in the game was utter horror with me just sprinting and running from everything like a headless chicken. I almost quit, before I slowly started getting the hang of the game mechanics and then pretty soon I was totally addicted. What a stunning game this is! Absolutely fabulous. 

And today, after 203 days of shrinkage, I am whole again having completed the entire game. I was so into the game that I've spent the last 30 minutes contemplating what to do next. I am actually wondering whether my in-game life or my real life is the actual reality..............

Overall i really like Grounded. Back when I bought it around two years ago it didn't have enough content to really keep me busy. However, now that I began playing it with a friend it seemingly offers infinite possibilities to spend your time. Exploring the world, fighting your way up the food chain, building a castle made of mushroom bricks, establishing a zipline network to any point of the garden - and more. The only issues I have with the game is the bad netcode. Water drops in dew collectors appear on the ground for my friend, sometimes things that i built aren't visible to him if he wasn't present during the time i built it - etc. However, it overall works great and I love the setting - definitely worth it.

A game made by Obsidian. Do I need to say more? 

From the first teaser, this game reminded me of one of my favourite childhood movies "Honey i shrunk the kids", and depicted the world almost exactly as I imagined it 33 years ago.

The game has beautiful graphics, fantastic story and sound, but most importantly co-op play. I enjoyed every bit of it playing with my friends. 

Flora and fauna of the backyard where game takes place are masterfully crafted. Base building is spot on, just as weapons and armours are. Difference between night and day, one chill other scary is key part of gameplay. Roaming through tall grass during night time is one hell of a adrenalin rush, while roaming during the day is really relaxing, unless you meet some nasty bug. 

Anyway, fantastic game from a fantastic studio. I enjoyed it from start to finish. Every fan of survival genre should play it.

This game is really well done for the most part, and if you're going to play solo it'll be a lot of fun. It's a lot of fun too with a major glaring issue in multiplayer.  De-syncing between host and peers is a major problem. Items on the ground will not appear where they are supposed to be thereby not allowing you to pick them up.  As a peer, sometimes it'll show that a platform still needs building even though it's completed on the host's side and you can even walk thru the piece. Most of the time re-connecting to the host is good enough to solve that issue but it can happen several times in an hour which is unacceptable. Especially when other games like Conan Exiles have been around a while and don't have that issue.

8/10

Solid 8 out of 10 for a survival game. Easy one of the best survival game that have been released in recent years.

The good:
- Very well written story with interesting development. Little notes / memos you find on the way feels like a great enrichment to the story.
- The world / yard design is absolutely amazing. Amount of effort for little details / planning is really showing off. You can tell that people that was in charge of that part of the game did it with huge passion. 
- Pleasant crafting system with a bunch of Quality of Life improvements since original game version release
- Huge diversity in weapons / armors to craft / pick from
- Exploration is rewarding. Your accidental slip off the branch and falling down while yelling out of frustration is quickly to be replaced with "Oh! It's a shiney down there! Woohoo!" moment.

The bad:
- Monsters (even a year after game release) still getting stuck in textures. You have monsters spawning in wooden fences / giant rocks / trees.
- Missing tooltips from Weapons / Armor explaining what certain set bonus / ability actually doing before crafting item and equipping it. Yes you read "Bleed" or "Corrosion" on item.. and..? How much damage it actually do? Is it 1? Is it 1 million? Does it stack? Does it refresh? Is there diminishing return? Is it worth to craft it? No? Do i really need to google this kind of stuff again? *frustration levels rising up*
- Game forces you to google up 3rd party websites in order to find missing Molers / CBA's if you are into full game completion. I think it's a massive flaw of the game that ruins end game / finale enjoyment. While i understand that exploration and fact of mystery is a big part of the game, but if a person beaten game / killed all bosses etc (or point of no return when you are about to grow big again?). Why not let player use Field Stations to scan for missing item like a Moler or CBA's? Even if its not pin-pointing exact location where item is located, at least point an area where to look at (a LAB or area name). That way player still have a last bit of journey / mystery to solve while looking for it. If game design leaves no other option than opening up Youtube guide and following it blindly with 0 excitement / discovery - game dropped the ball, immersion is ruined.
- People going for 100% completion and not understanding why they are stuck at 99% game completion. In-game data collection list shows that everything is found / collected / visited. Well, apparently there are 2 extra Molers (even if you upgraded every possible skill that there is) you still need to find 2 extra ones. Game doesn't tell you that / there is no indicator how many Molers you have already collected and how many you still need to look for.
- Emotes for Raw Science (that is required to buy if you are going for achievements) with current price tag that is now is a bad game design. I'm solo player, I havent used a single character emote in entire playthrough of 100 hours and yet, game is forcing me to spend 30k+ of Raw Science on researching stuff that is literally focused only on certain group of people that play together. This is opposite of fun to grind for something that you know that is useless. If your goal as game designer is to force player to spend X amount of in game currency (Raw Science in our case) then main focus should be allowing to buy people stuff that is usable by everyone and make stuff like Cosmetics / Emote optional for Symbolic price (100-500). While covering price difference of Raw Science by adding other stuff to the shop that is actually FUN:
Faster Zip-Line technology (10-20%) - 10k Raw Science
Additional Trinket Slot - 10k Raw Science
Equip your Aphid pet with Flaming Koltana and witness the making of new John Wick 5 - 30k Raw Science
There are tons and tons of things that player would be excited to grind for without feeling like its a soul breaking torture, because there is some kind of usable reward / advantage in any form at the end. At this point (with current Raw Science prices for Emotes) you can just add a 30k worth piece of paper with a message - "We really had no idea how to fuck people over to force them play game for a few days more, so here, have this useless piece of paper instead because it has same effect for you as emotes, you wont ever use ANY of those ROFLKEKLOLGAMEDESIGN".

Is this game worth the money? - ABSOLUTELY!

Grounded is in my top games of all time, truly. I can't even begin to describe how much fun this game is, and if I gave a comprehensive list of all the reasons I love this game it would stretch on for miles. Shaking dew drops from blades of grass, sneaking into anthills to make bombs, fighting for your life against spiders the size of elephants, this game is packed to bursting with charm and character that just draws you in and grabs ahold of you. If I had to pick one single game to play for the rest of my life this would be the top candidate, because even on a single playthrough there is just so much to do and so many places to explore that by the time you're finished you've essentially forgotten what it was like starting out, and you can just hop right into it again. My 256 hours at the time of writing this were played on a single survival playthrough if thats an indicator of how absolutely gargantuan this game is (or rather, how microscopically tiny you are in comparison). 11/10, I will be naming my firstborn son after this game.

Also, if you don't go nuts and start worshipping a paganesque insect deity at some point, you aren't playing the game right. All glory to the Weevil God.

The controls were a little different at first but it was really fun for a long time. It seemed like the pacing was very good up until the 70 or so hour mark for us. Then, we hit a wall with what needed to be unlocked, etc. The base-building parts were super fun. The traversal via ziplines was unexpectedly cool. There are some freaky moments in here with the crazy bugs and I like the different versions that would stalk you or just hang out looking intimidating (wolf spiders). If you're going from Grounded to Smalland, there are some QoL stuff that Smalland does better and gets right, but it is lacking in content compared to Grounded. Both are still fun in their own ways, though.

Grounded is one of the best survival style games that I have played in awhile, at first I was unsure if I would like the game since I am a solo style player however I am now hooked on it.  
- Very Immersive - can really get into the game through the eyes of a shrunken player questing to answer the questions of how they got there.   There are four preset teens to play and they can be swapped as you progress through the game which adds to the variety.
-  The building options are very good including setting up a zip-line network as you progress through the game. 
- Very good storyline to follow however you can deviate from it at any time and play as you like.   Story adds to experience and some of it is needed to continue crafting better gear, weapons and character enhancements. 
- Community if very active with plenty of guides & videos available. 
- No bugs encountered yet, It is fun to be able to play through with 0 glitches so far. 
- Spiders!  The bugs in this game are so realistic including awesome graphics.  

I will continue to update as I play through, taking time to enjoy the game, time flies when having fun!

Played Early Access for 8 hours (Wasn't really into the game at the time, but still fun)

Now I've played 320 hours and gotten every achievement and my god has it been the best 320 hours spent in a game period.

+ Some of the best progression I've seen in a Survival game

+ Has a story with a beginning and an end, so you have something to aim towards constantly.

+ Has one of the best building systems and a fun hauling system in place, so this also makes for something to aim towards.

+ Has RPG elements, and plenty of them as expected from an Obsidian title. Stats that can be acquired through [spoiler]Milk Molar candies[/spoiler] and items to get through the progression

+ A rather large open world/garden to roam in. All areas are open from the beginning pretty much, but requires better gear, otherwise yo screwed, but you can go there! (Goes back to Fallout pretty much)

+ A full underwater system and places to go there too, though short lived, it's still fun during that time.

+ Best inventory/chest management I've seen.. All Survival games I will compare to this moving forward and I HAVE. (Press N to deposit all current items to a chest that has that exact item already in it) Build structures and items from Chests within distance. (Goes for Pallets too, this is where you store hauled grass planks and weed stems)

+ 1.2 added so much great stuff from Boss improvements and new enemies like the [spoiler]Wasps and Wasp Queen[/spoiler]

+ Fantastic combat system that is easy to learn and once you learn enemy attack patterns they become much easier to deal with, so it's not unfair, it's all about how YOU learn about them. (You can cheese them too, if that's your thing)

+ Potions and Cooking. Potions are simple to make, uses a base ingredient which is required and 3 ingredients that you can freely choose what to be. Be it grass fiber or pebbles.. Just as long as 3 items are used. Food is made using a variety of jerkies and other meats, but they provide long lasting boosts, which is stacked with potion effects.

+ Base defense (Once you've pissed off some bugs long enough)

+ Base defense II, these are spoilers, so I won't mention the name. But you gotta defend these points using anything at your disposal. Build defenses, walls and other things and stock up. (This provides an achievement when all are defended and some small items to aid your journey temporarily)

+ Weapon and Armor upgrading, these materials are found throughout the areas you visit, so look carefully. [spoiler]They are finite during the first half of the game.[/spoiler]

+ Mutations (This is basically leveling in the game besides stat boosts through the other mentioned means) These are earned doing their respective things, such as attacking enemies with the specific weapon that the mutation improves. Or simply running out of breath over and over again etc. (Like Fallout/Oblivion skills) Initially 2 can be activated at a time, this can further be increased with the other mentioned stat boost system.

+ Dude it's just great... Buy it if you like RPG's and Survival Games.


- Farming is extremely disappointing. Even with the latest update it's slow and very expensive compared to the alt methods of acquiring those items.

- Medium is a tad too easy in my opinion.. The reason why I don't play Whoa! (Hard) is because it makes your item durability drain SO FAST! And that grind becomes tedious fast.. But that's just me. In order to avoid that, you'd have to fully upgrade your stuff, which is not possible until late game.

- Pets are awful.. Don't bother unless you play Custom Game.

- Some minor frame rate issues with a lot of light objects like torches and so on.

Grounded is a superb co-op-focused craft-em-up with enough charming deviations from the usual survival game formula to lift my skepticism about the genre. The game’s logical gameplay conveniences, appealing identity, phenomenal graphical composition/lighting, and abundant environmental details always made scheduled weekly sessions with friends something to look forward to.

Exploring Grounded's handcrafted landscape is a thoroughly engaging task as the world contains a dense variety of unique features, helpful secrets, and new resources. The backyard feels big enough to always have somewhere new to discover yet small enough to traverse in reasonable amounts of time (especially with the help of a system of zip lines). It’s also memorable enough that Grounded forgoes the use of a minimap and is able to limit its main map to be primarily informational. Even though you can get literally lost in the weeds when in unfamiliar territory, it’s easy to get your bearings thanks to all the giant surrounding landmarks. However, I did still find myself wishing for an on-screen compass every now and then, if only to have quick knowledge of my relative direction during travel.

I enjoyed how there's a touch of story to contextualize your movement up the food chain as well as to motivate through exploration of this detailed world. So many other survival crafting games lack this kind of connective flavor. It by no means leads the experience, but it does feel great to be curious about what narrative clues unsurveyed locations may contain and excited whenever you know an answer lies around the corner.

Towards the very end, once you've essentially seen the whole yard, the grind for materials picks up a decent bit. Useful materials exist in less abundance but equipment gets used up or requires repair at the usual rate. A repetitive process of maintaining your supply of the upper tiers of resources takes the stage and the meaningful exploration that's essentially been used up at that point can no longer distract you from your material needs. But that happened like 35+ hours in for us, and it was more of a sign that we had basically done everything we wanted to.

Solo play is serviceable, although it won’t be the most expedient way to play. I reckon it’d be much more difficult in comparison as well. Grounded is clearly built around having a squad for delegating survival tasks and additional agro/damage for tough enemies. The four-player aspect is even baked right into the four-playable characters. So, if you’ve got two or preferably three friends who are interested in a collaborative game and coordinated enough to see the adventure through, Grounded should be an easy pick for you.

(Also, thank you for the 'spider slider' option. It made them merely terrifying in gameplay and not visually terrifying too.)
