best game i've played

The game devs have really hit a sweet spot here, between challenging and entertaining.  Rather than a punishing grind requirement or ridiculous carry restrictions as a mechanism to (antagonistically) extend the playability time or cripple progression in a game that inherently lacks content; these devs have stepped up and created a world environment that is challenging - along with the gathering and progression feeling more natural and organic (cough), rather than punitive or ridiculously crippled to make up for a world design itself lacking in challenge as so many other games must resort to. 
Maybe it wasn't so - from the beginning of the game's life cycle.  At this point though I give a solid two thumbs up to these guys after playing for a good 3-4 days or so.  I've heard that the mid to late game progression feels like it stalls a bit, or ramps up too high too fast for gaining tiers and access to improved items.  If I hit something which seems to break or drastically reduce the games playability I'll post an edited rant and drop the thumbs down, which I'm just sure they are super terrified of coming from one other unknown nerd.

By far the best survival game I've ever played, and I've played my fair share. It's a great premise (albeit nabbed from an 80s flick), has a high level of polish, and is pretty large and deep. It does a really excellent job of quality-of-life gameplay ideas. For example, as you level up you can carry more planks. Can't do that in Raft. Can't do that in Green Hell.  Automatically pulling resources from nearby storage when crafting/building is a huge plus.  Whoever designed some of these mechanics are really good at their job.  The bugs and combat and such are also very very good. Having your torch go out in the middle of the night with a spider in the area instantly becomes a horror game. I had a larva attacking me so I jumped on a nearby clover. The larva began cutting down the clover, so I jumped to the next, so he cut started cutting down that one. That's amazing. It's got a lot of RPG elements for a survival game. The map is huge, varied, and interesting. Probably the best feature is the way it handles multiplayer hosting. The saved file is stored in the xbox cloud, then the first of your white-listed group who tries to play at any given time, they become the host. So me and my friends can all play whenever we want without one person running a server or leaving their game running or any of that nonsense. All multiplayer survival games should do it this way. I waited years to buy it because it never seemed to go on sale when I was ready to get into a new game.  This is a rare game where I'd say it's worth the MSRP, but if it goes on sale in any fashion, definitely worth picking up.

This is one of the best games I've ever played, and watching it grow from Early Access day 1 to now has been a great experience. The combat is quick, diverse, and responsive, the weapons and armor have unique designs that perfectly match the game's environment, and exploring the yard is always fun (and thrilling, especially on higher difficulties).

If you want to just enjoy playing with friends and experience the story, or you don't play many games and want to try this one, you can customize your experience any way you like, like by playing on Mild difficulty or by setting a custom game mode that disables bug aggression, or makes building/crafting instant and free. If you've played the game a lot and want to push yourself, the Whoa! game mode is challenging but not punishing, so you always feel like your skill level is the only thing holding you back.

If you like survival games, if you like base building games, if you like a challenge when it comes to combat, if you like exploration, if you like co-op, if you like Honey I Shrunk the Kids, you'll love Grounded.

Grounded is a pretty nice game to play, with lots of possiblities, but also contains some glitches. 
Starting the game, we got rekt by almost every evil creature. Without knowing attack patterns in the first hours, it was a complete desaster and ended up being very hard to be confident in the fighting system. After finally getting to know the game, starting to actually play the story and do the labs and stuff, it was hard because even though the blocking etc helped, enemy masses just were crazy.  Later, with proper equipment ofc, we ended up being slightly overpowered? Like wolfspiders, infected ones and all the bosses were peanuts, regardless of the difficulty (medium). It started very hard, but ended up being no challenge. The only challenge we had was simply not killing each other while fighting. 
The story was interesting and ended up like expected. But the grind for the achievement of the 100% report card was literally pain. Going through everything, we ended up playing 25h or so just to get to the 100% (which we would never have reached if we didn't look up what was missing). I gladly deinstalled the game directly after getting the final achievement lol.

The glitches whatsoever became apparent in the building system. I loved the way of placing the blueprint before actually building something, so you could proper do the planning, but when you put in the materials, the object itself moved from the blueprint spot to another one, which could be solved by just placing other walls/objects first, but it was still really annoying.
When something was destroyed or loot was dropped, sometimes it's very hard to pick it up, because it is bugged either inside the ground or just being at a different position. 

Anyways, Grounded is a wonderful survival game to play with friends, and I highly recomment to give it a chance!

Jeez, what an honest review xD

EDIT:

The new update with the new bosses was fun to play, but also a hard challenge. The Wasp Queen was way easier to beat than the infected Broodmother, however not easy after all. The broodmother was absolutely hard to kill, we looked up strats and had much heal and buffs but we managed to kill her after roughly 15 attempts. But it was a nice challenge after all and a great addition to the game :)

Not worth $30 at the time of this review. Has plenty of potential, needs lots of bug fixes(no pun intended). Have had ants clip through walls and wolf spiders spawn inside the house, most enemies will at points randomly decide to stop being intelligent and just let you kill them or cheese them. There is a mechanic where some enemies, such as the mosquito will fly away when weak but becomes totally invulnerable to attacks, I fail to understand why this would ever be a good feature so I'm going to call that a bug. The depth of field is broken, things in the background can never be totally focused on so it just makes your character feel like they just have terrible vision. The inventory and hotbar mechanic is unnecessarily unique, perhaps I just don't see whatever benefit it has over something like Terraria. Why not just have the top row of items in the inventory serve as the hotbar? And for controller players to just have a few buttons mapped to particular slots? 

Already reviews covering the building I'm sure so I wont comment on that. Final note: Just hold out for maybe another year or two for a sale and more content because as it stands this doesn't have the quality to recommend for $30.

Grounded is a game that has taken the world of survival gaming by storm, and after embarking on an epic journey with my friends, I can confidently say that it stands as one of the finest examples of the genre I've ever had the pleasure of playing. This pint-sized adventure offered a host of impressive features that left us buzzing with excitement. Here's a closer look at what makes Grounded such a standout experience:

1. Ingenious Building System: Grounded's building mechanics are a true highlight. Crafting intricate bases and structures is a breeze, and the attention to detail is nothing short of astonishing. It truly feels like you've been shrunken down and are constructing epic fortresses in your own backyard.

2. Streamlined User Interface: The game's interface and quality of life features are a breath of fresh air. Accessing resources from nearby chests and quickly storing items became second nature, streamlining the gameplay experience and eliminating needless tedium.

3. Diverse Adversaries: Grounded excels in creature diversity. The array of enemies and formidable bosses each bring unique strengths and weaknesses to the table, ensuring that combat remains engaging and unpredictable throughout the game.

4. Adaptability Through Mutations, Weapons, and Armor: The ability to customize your character's abilities through mutations adds a layer of strategy to combat. Combined with an arsenal of weapons and armor, Grounded offers a rich variety of options to tackle its challenges, allowing players to experiment and find their preferred playstyle.

5. Thrilling Defense Events: Few things are as exhilarating as defending your base against a horde of relentless foes. Grounded delivers on this front with exciting defense events that demand quick thinking, teamwork, and effective utilization of your resources.

6. Achievements with Attainable Goals: One of Grounded's standout features is its achievable achievements within a single playthrough. This design choice provides a sense of accomplishment as you progress through the game, making each milestone a satisfying conquest.

7. Engaging Story and Quests: Grounded isn't just about surviving in a backyard; it weaves an engaging narrative with intriguing quests. This element adds a sense of purpose to your adventures, making the game feel more like an epic quest than a mere survival sandbox.

8. Abundant Resource Variety: Grounded offers a plethora of resources scattered throughout its diverse locations. This feature ensures that the farming aspect of the game never grows monotonous. Whether you're scouring the grasslands, exploring the depths of a murky pond, or venturing into the dense foliage of the backyard, the game consistently rewards exploration with an array of valuable materials. This abundance keeps the farming part of the game engaging and ensures that you and your friends always have new objectives to pursue, enhancing the overall depth of the experience.

While Grounded offers an abundance of thrilling features, it does have one notable drawback: the four-player limit. For those with larger friend groups, like our party of six, this limitation can be a bit disappointing. However, it's a minor blemish on an otherwise stellar gaming experience.

In conclusion, Grounded is an exceptional co-op survival game that immerses you in a world where the ordinary becomes extraordinary. From its ingenious building system to its diverse enemies and engaging narrative, it captivates players in a microcosmic adventure like no other. While it may not accommodate larger groups, it more than makes up for it with its wealth of features and satisfying gameplay. Grounded has certainly earned its place among the best in the genre, and I eagerly anticipate the adventures that await as the game continues to evolve and expand.

Grounded excels as a cooperative survival game, perfect for group play. While enjoyable with four players, the potential for 6 to 10 players would elevate the experience.

The building system is intuitive, enhancing creativity. Automatic chest storage simplifies inventory management. The engaging story, thrilling boss battles, and attainable achievements provide purpose and excitement.

Mutations add strategy, and resource farming is oddly therapeutic. Recommended for fans of Ark and Valheim, Grounded is a standout in the survival genre.
great open world game with an amazing story line. it is overall a great game.

Grounded delivers an exceptional survival gaming experience, particularly when you bring friends along for the ride. While it's undeniably entertaining with a group of four, the prospect of accommodating larger parties, perhaps 6 to 10 players, would undoubtedly take the cooperative chaos to new heights.

The game's building mechanics are a standout feature, offering an intuitive and deeply satisfying crafting and construction system. This allows players to unleash their creativity as they erect fortifications to fend off the looming threats in their tiny world.

A small but wonderful detail that greatly enhances the gameplay experience is the automatic storage solution for chests. It simplifies inventory management and showcases the developers' commitment to player convenience, earning a special place in players' hearts.

Grounded also distinguishes itself with a compelling storyline and engaging quests, providing players with purpose and motivation as they delve into the secrets hidden within the backyard.

Boss battles and defense events in the game are nothing short of exhilarating. They present formidable challenges and a genuine sense of accomplishment when conquered, elevating the cooperative gaming experience to new heights.

Achievements in Grounded are genuinely attainable, serving as satisfying milestones to pursue and enhancing the game's replayability factor.

One unique and noteworthy feature is the mutations system, which bestows buffs upon all players and can be easily unlocked. This introduces an exciting layer of strategy into the gameplay, encouraging diverse and inventive approaches to survival.

Lastly, there's an oddly therapeutic quality to resource farming in Grounded. It's a captivating and immersive aspect of the game that keeps players immersed in the miniature world they're exploring.

In summary, Grounded is a must-play for survival game enthusiasts, particularly those who have found enjoyment in titles like Ark and Valheim. With its emphasis on cooperative play, outstanding building mechanics, immersive storyline, thrilling boss encounters, and player-friendly features like automatic storage, Grounded stands out as a top-tier entry in the genre. It's an adventure in the tiny wilderness that should not be missed!

The story is done beautifully, with environmental story telling, puzzles that can be observed and be figured out. A story of a scientists dreams, and where you fit in all of this? Why don't you remember who you are? which slowly gets revealed the further you delve into the game. It makes you want to explore the map and leave no leaf un-turned. it rewards exploration and easily marked landmarks for you. 

lots of RPG mechanics, with purposeful made resources, that don't become clutter unlike some other survival games. There is a hot loot button (n) and when you press it, it automatically deposits all resources to chests with similar items, the chests can be toggled too so you don't accidentally place an item you want to keep on you.

base building is streamlined and well thought out, easy to build and allows easy relocation of assets no problem. All resources are fully refunded when recycled, so it doesn't punish you and allows you to experiment to your hearts desire.

items and progression, is really easily explained and customisation is super in depth. Allowing a part to play different roles when fighting or engaging events/bosses. 

great game overall

For a game that's had this much attention paid to it, and from a developer that's got a pretty decent rep, the ball's been dropped pretty fuckin' hard here.

This might be fun for ARK tryhards, but for the everyman, the game is still garbage. There's no purpose for common insects to have unreasonably large health pools, and to have Tier 2 equipment gated behind defeating enemies with unreasonably high heath pools that can also put out insane damage.  
Ditch this nonsense, go play The Forest.

Grounded is a unique mix of beautiful, strange, familiar, and frightening. The world and even the scenario are familiar—you are tiny, ant-sized, trying to survive a hostile backyard environment as in the movie "Honey, I Shrunk the Kids." But rich, realistic visuals, creative and thoughtful open-world design, and the bright, eclectic sounds of a tiny living jungle make the world compelling and immersive, leading to adventures much greater than you might imagine finding in a common suburban backyard. 

Go murky cavern-diving in the koi pond, dash for shade in the sizzling desert of the sandbox, climb the maze of webbed branches in the hedge, crawl through ant-crowded tunnels. The world of Grounded and its experiences are surprisingly varied. One moment you'll be searching for moonlit dewdrops in the tips of grass above you, the next you'll be running, not daring to look back, as a massive spider chases you through terrifying darkness, crashing through the cracking grass stalks, intense music drumming up heart-pounding fear. 

Build a tiny sanctuary out of grass blades and stems, research better equipment and explore deeper into the yard, struggle to survive at the wrong end of a long food chain. Uncover secrets and discover sights in a world where a piece of trash or a discarded toy are imposing and strange as alien monoliths. At the time of this review, there is a story, but don't expect it to ever be as compelling as the need to scout, build, and thrive. Grounded gives players a well-crafted and rewarding virtual world in which to do that.

One caveat: Grounded has the most spidery spiders that ever spided. Seriously, this warrants caution.

When I first bought this game I didn't really know what I was getting into. I thought the trailer was cool, Obsidian Entertainment had made my favorite fallout game, and it was on sale. 74 hours later I finally finished the campaign and man, what a journey. This game is one of the most competent and well put together survival games that on the market right now. I spent hours building and customizing my base, going from a scared teenager being hunted by spiders to becoming a one girl army slaughter hordes of spiders and other little beasts. Other than a couple bugs phasing through the ground and a few moments where the game slowed to a crawl, I am happy to saw I never encountered and glitches that harmed my experience with Grounded. I full-heartedly recommend Grounded for anyone with a passing interest in the survival genre and experience the wonderful world that Obsidian has crafted in Grounded. 

TL;DR: Grounded is a massively better survival game than The Forest and Rust by a mile and I will fight anyone who disagrees.

(add about 80 hours to my play time as I played on a console for a lot) Grounded is the best survival base building game I've ever played, and I've played some of the greats. Most don't honestly pull me in much, but I love the concept of being shrunk down, and this game is so good at immersing me in that experience while also providing a great backyard to explore. None of the backyard feels repetitive, and it's all fun to explore. The combat while simple and robust is still engaging because the enemy design is so good. Also, the arachnophobia mode was a godsend, as it allowed me to be in the same room as my partner and not freak them out as I killed (or often got killed) by the spiders in this game. 11/10, even the water level is fun.

Would recommend unless you're worse off than me for entomophobia

Let me preface this by saying I enjoy this game, but this is the kind of game that falls into a predictable cycle:

1. Grind the hell out of the game for a week or two.
2. Proceed to reach the end game, beat it, and run around doing random repetitive things (Farming bosses, materials, building, etc)
3. Put game down for a few months
4. Hear news about update coming and get excited to play again 
5. Play new update and grind the new update for a week or two
6. Put the game down again and wait for another update.

It's perfectly okay to put it down for a few months and come back to it.

After finishing "It Takes Two" with my boyfriend, we needed another game to play together. This game is perfect if you like Minecraft (but with a plot); I highly recommend it! It's an exploration and survival game that combines "Honey I Shrunk the Kids" with combat of the lower grounds (aka, bugs!). There's endless goals to finish even after the end game (collecting all the bug cards, finding all the items/collectibles, expanding your bases etc.). Though I will say, multiplayer can be buggy. I disconnected multiple times but it didn't deteriorate my experience of the game. The bugs that happened for me included:

-dew drops not spawning correctly
-materials not being able to be picked up
-blueprints appearing even though structures were built 

The Host never got most of these bugs but I didn't mind at all. You can also play the game with 2 other friends who own the game! Even though my boyfriend is the real gamer between us, it's a game that you can develop other gaming skills as you play more (I suck at parrying and fighting lol) I had fun collecting materials for our base and fighting alongside him. During this review, I can proudly say we both 100% the game! ♥

"Grounded" shrinks you down to the size of an ant and plunges you into a backyard teeming with life, danger, and adventure. It's like "Honey, I Shrunk the Kids" got a video game adaptation, and the result is a survival game that's as engaging as it is unique. Craft tools, build shelters, and fend off gigantic bugs as you explore a world where everyday objects become towering obstacles and small critters turn into menacing foes.

The graphics are vibrant and bring the miniature world to life in vivid detail. Whether you're spelunking in anthills or creating your own leafy fortress, the game provides a variety of activities that make survival an engaging endeavour. You can go it alone or team up with friends, offering flexibility in how you tackle the challenges ahead.

Having graduated from early access, "Grounded" is a polished experience that offers hours of gameplay for both solo players and teams alike. If you're looking for a fresh spin on the survival genre or ever wondered what life looks like from a bug's perspective, this game is a must-play. 🐜🍃

One of the most immersive games around - what's it like to be the size of an insect in a garden? Well creepy and quite difficult... Co-op is the best mode to play in (if you have a regular group or partner to play with), but there's certainly plenty of exploration for the single gamer too.

Title: An Enchanting Microscopic Adventure

Rating: ★★★★☆ (4/5)

Review:
Grounded takes a giant leap into a tiny world, transforming your everyday backyard into a captivating and visually stunning microcosm. Obsidian Entertainment's foray into survival gaming brings a fresh perspective, melding survival mechanics with the wonder of exploring a world from a minuscule perspective.

The scale shift is truly the star of the show here. From towering blades of grass to insects that become fearsome foes, the attention to detail in creating a believable miniature ecosystem is commendable. The art direction and level design turn your surroundings into a captivating playground of discovery.

The survival mechanics add depth to the experience. Gathering resources, constructing shelters, and crafting tools form the core gameplay loop. The gradual progression system ensures that your character evolves in tandem with your understanding of the environment, keeping the gameplay engaging as you adapt to your new circumstances.

Co-op shines in Grounded. Joining forces with friends to tackle the challenges of the backyard is where the game truly shines. Cooperation is essential for tackling larger threats and building intricate bases. The blend of humor and camaraderie during multiplayer sessions creates memorable moments.

However, as with any early access title, there are areas that could use polish. Some bugs and performance issues can momentarily take you out of the immersion. Additionally, while the current content is enjoyable, the game's overall scope might leave you wanting more variety in creatures, crafting options, and exploration opportunities.

Grounded's potential is evident. The developers have shown a commitment to regular updates and improvements, promising a promising trajectory for the game's future. As the title continues to evolve and expand, it's likely to grow into an even more captivating experience.

In summary, Grounded offers a refreshing take on the survival genre, allowing players to experience the marvels and challenges of a miniature world. The potential for growth combined with the joy of co-op exploration makes this early access title one to watch. Dive into the backyard and get ready to uncover the hidden wonders that await.

the sea men are so realistic<<<333
I never played survival games before, but this one I really like.

By far the most polished and fun co-op survival experience I had a pleasure to this. So many useful QoL features were baked in that in e.g. Valheim we had to use a mod for. 

The exploration is very rewarding - you have a feeling that you can find something interesting in every corner. The combat is challenging, but not overly punishing (we played on Medium). The base building feels really good, it's easy to build the kind of base you set out to. The gear/skill progression feels meaningful - but not to the point that new stuff invalidates all previous gear instantly. Also, it's not overly grindy (except maybe some of the late game weapons/enchantments).

All in all, a masterpiece of game design we had a pleasure to experience. I'm not sure if I would still sing such praises if I played solo, because I don't really enjoy the survival genre when played solo, but in multiplayer Grounded shines like a well-polished diamond it is!

Grounded is an awesome game. I haven't seen a game with such an amount of customisation and build options regarding perks, equipment and weapons since Terraria, and this goes even beyond that.

I felt like a child exploring the huge yard, discovering secret after secret. Combat is super fluid and challenging, relying on parries and mobility and multiplayer is super fun.

Even though players that join (not the host) have some sync issues, and the UI/UX could be improved somewhat, I cannot recommend Grounded enough.

This has been one if not the best survival/crafting game I played so far.

[b] Theme [/b]
They chose a really interesting theme and developed it almost flawlessly. Many times with a cool concepts you end up thinking that there was a lot of wasted potential in the execution, but this is not the case. There were countless instances where I said "wow, I'd have never though of putting this into the game, this cool!".
I can't really comment on the story as I skipped most of the exposition since I was playing with a friends, for what I saw it seems at least servisable.

[b] Art/Graphics [/b]
The art style complements the theme and it's gorgeous, but it still runs well on lower end pcs. My laptop only had some problems in some parts of a foggy area, but I still didn't feel the need to lower the settings. I'm still surprised they managed to make the plants translucent without impacting performances.

[b] Gameplay [/b]
The gameplay is a mix of exploration, combat and crafting, all driven by a story/set of quests. All these elements complement and blend with eachother in a really nice way, pushing you to keep exploring to craft new things, discover new creatures and unlock new and interesting parts of the map.

[b] Crafting [/b]
The crafting and base building left me especially pleased, including a bunch o quality of life choices that improve the longevity of the game, like being able to move built items at will, even crates full of items.

[b] Combat [/b]
The actual combat isn't deep but works well, with a mix of "dodging", parring and attacking. After playing a while some enemies' fighting patterns can start to become repetitive, but usually at that point you are suoppoped to face new ones so it works. The combat preparation on the other hand can be deeper, as you can choose the type of weapon, the type of armor, which consumables to bring and which mutations (special buff you can swap at will) to use.

[b] Exploration [/b]
This is probably the biggest selling point of the game. Each "biome" is nicely flashed out and usually with a nice spin or gimmick. New areas often leave you in awe and with child-like wonder. Reaching a new biome feels like an accomplishment, and while doing that sometimes involve obtaining a new crafter tool/equipment (kind of like a metroidvania) the game never prevents you from doing that in more creative ways.

[b] FINAL CONCLUSIONS [/b]
This is probably the best crafting/survival game out there for my taste and I recommend it.

Pros:
 - almost everything, the game is a seamless blend of art, theme and gameplay element that mix together to deliver an outstanding game

Cons:
 - combat can get repetitive at times if you decide to fight the same enemies over and over
 - the netcode is a bit wonky at times. sometimes the players that are not hosting might not be able to see certain water droplets, or see build items (walls, crates, etc.) still in construction, if they were completed while they were far. Fortunately it works fine where it matter most (exploration and combat)

Just about anything Obsidian puts its name on, I can be assured it's going to be good. But this game is Great! It's every kid's imagination brought to life. When kids ask me, "Are there real monsters in the world," I say, "Yes. But, they're called bugs and they're really small and you can smash them." Well . . . that's no longer true. 🐜 Grounded: A Giant Adventure in Miniature Form 🐜

Grounded proves that size doesn't matter when it comes to delivering a triple-A gaming experience. This game hits all the right marks, offering a journey into the micro world that's packed with excitement, creativity, and sheer fun.

Pros:

🌿 Vast Miniature World: Get ready to be awed by the intricate detail of the miniature world in Grounded. From towering grass blades to sprawling landscapes, the game immerses you in a unique perspective.

🔨 Creative Base Building: The base-building mechanics are a standout feature. Construct your tiny haven with an assortment of materials and innovative designs that reflect your creative genius.

🐜 Creature Companions: The game's diverse and vibrant ecosystem keeps you on your toes. Encounter and interact with creatures of all sizes, some of which can become unlikely companions in your journey.

🎮 Smooth Gameplay: Grounded doesn't skimp on polish. The controls are intuitive, combat is satisfying, and the overall gameplay is a testament to the developers' dedication to creating a seamless experience.

🛠️ Regular Updates: The developers are on the ball when it comes to updates. New content, bug fixes, and optimizations are consistently delivered, ensuring that your journey in the miniature world is always fresh.

Rating: 5/5 - An Epic Adventure in a Tiny Realm 🌟

Grounded is a game that punches above its weight, offering a gaming experience that's both immersive and captivating. Dive into the miniature marvels, explore, build, and overcome challenges that prove that even the tiniest heroes can leave a giant impact.
Very fun, I drank 13 cups of coffee so i could keep going. Very FUN!!!!

At this point I think I might have to say Grounded is my favorite game to play. I've been playing since the pond update in early access so I have restarted and play through all the available content multiple times as updates were made. A couple years later here I am playing again going for 100% run. 

There is a lot more whimsy in this survival game than any other I've played. 

The various play modes and options you can customize help most players find a style that is fun for them. You can make it so you can just explore and build as you please while discovering the story or you can make everything a challenge/grind.

Each of the characters you can play as have their own personalities making replaying a bit more fun as you can have different commentary/reactions as you explore. If you play with friends your characters will talk to each other.

In real life I have a bug phobia... still love this game. I'm mentioning that in case you too are thinking of passing on this due to 'bug' issues. 

There is a lot of content in the game. The map feels huge despite being a backyard. There are several distinct biomes. There are multiple dungeons (labs & underground tunnels). The Hedge feels like a forest with the lab areas being set up like tree fort. The Pond is the underwater biome with a lab definitely feeling more like secret agent hideout. The Haze feels like an alien planet that is hazardous to your health. The Sandbox is a desert that can literally cook you. The Grill is like a volcano  that can also cook you.  The Blank Ant Lab feels like a labyrinth. The Termite Mound... well every game has a worst dungeon... it exists. The upper Yard feels like jungle. 

There is fair number of enemies (to be fair several are re-skins) but most types have their own attack patterns, habits, and loot. When you start out, especially on 'Whoa!' mode, most enemies can kill you in 1 to 3 hits. You need to make armor and get skilled at blocking real quick.. or running away. Running away is real good option at the start.

You'll quickly learn new recipes/blueprints and create better weapons/armor/bases.  I've seen a lot of people complain about progressing to tier two weapons/armor... go to the Hedge like the game suggests. Web sacs have more than spiders inside them. You'll be able to get some key resources that way instead of taking on insects you are not ready for. Once you have a tier 2 hammer things really start changing as you can open milk molars which let you upgrade basic stats and storage.

Check out some let's play videos on this game... more than one. How you play greatly impacts how the game feels. See if it can be your cup of tea. :)
The game is amazing, you can discover it organically and continue with the story or spend hours and hours trough the garden building your base, weapons or other gadgets. I would totally reccomend.

An absolutely stellar game!
If you loved Honey I Shrunk the Kids, have an interest in bugs, are into survival-craft games, or just like picturing the world from a different point of view, this game is probably for you.
I'm not much of a survival-craft kind of person. I enjoyed minecraft, but once I run out of objectives for survival and start living comfortably, I tend lose interest quickly. This game avoids that entirely. With a fully cohesive story line, constant challenges, and a full and rather sizeable yard to explore, I never ran out of stuff to do all the way through to the end.
Cute but accurate insect depictions made for an interesting and educational experience, while also providing arachnophobia sensitive settings. Combat is simplistic but still satisfying, bosses are challenging but fun. The level up system along with the weapons and armor crafting had me trying all sorts of weapon/armor/damage types. The music is incredibly fun and sets every scene as you are constantly stumbling into some new horror/wonder.
Lots of love went into this game and you can feel it. A passion project that is still updating. A bargain at any price.

Grade: A

Okay, so this is my *all-time* favorite survival craft game to play with friends. Here is a quick list of why:
-The story is incredibly quirky and fun.
-The world is rich and has a ton of personality.
-The graphics are great.
-Combat is super fun and not too difficult to master.
-Base-building is intuitive and satisfying.
-THE MUSIC. GOOD LORD, THE MUSIC IS ASTOUNDING.
-It has arachnophobia mode for anyone spooked from spiders!
-You can tell this is a passion project. Lots of love went into this.

I played through the campaign as Max, (he was my favorite) and I had 3 other friends to play through with. We played on easy, and it was definitely still a challenge at times. It seems difficult to play solo, but others have done it, so if you wanted to you totally could. I cannot recommend this game enough. It's worth it at any price, because there is so much you can do and has a lot you can come back to. If you liked 'Honey, I Shrunk The Kids', or "Micro" by Michael Crichton...BUY THIS GAME!!!

A Miniature Adventure Packed with Potential

"Grounded" is a charming and inventive take on the survival genre that shrinks players down to the size of insects and immerses them in a visually stunning micro-world. Set in a suburban backyard teeming with life, the game offers a unique perspective on survival, exploration, and cooperation.

The visuals in "Grounded" are a highlight in themselves. The level of detail put into crafting a realistic environment from a miniature perspective is nothing short of impressive. Blades of grass become towering forests, pebbles transform into imposing boulders, and insects take on new significance as both adversaries and resources. The attention to detail captures the sense of wonder that comes with exploring a familiar world from an entirely different viewpoint.

The survival mechanics in "Grounded" are well-executed, requiring players to gather resources, build shelters, and craft tools to thrive in their tiny environment. The game encourages creative problem-solving, whether it's constructing a base out of everyday objects or devising strategies to take on the surprisingly menacing insects that inhabit the yard.

Multiplayer is a strong focus in "Grounded," allowing players to team up with friends to tackle challenges, build bases, and explore together. The cooperative gameplay adds a layer of social interaction that can be highly rewarding, particularly when working together to overcome formidable foes.

However, it's important to note that, as an early access title, "Grounded" might have some rough edges. Bugs and performance issues are to be expected, and the content available during early access might be limited compared to the game's full potential. Players looking for a polished and complete experience might want to wait until the game's development progresses further.

In conclusion, "Grounded" presents a novel concept that sets it apart from other survival games. Its immersive world and unique mechanics make it a captivating experience, especially for those intrigued by the idea of exploring a world from a miniature perspective. While it might still be a work in progress, the foundation "Grounded" has laid out showcases a game with immense potential, and it's worth keeping an eye on as it continues to evolve during its early access phase.

This is simply one of the very best games I've ever played. 
The amount of details in this world is amazing. The graphics are stunning and the story is nice. The building aspect is good with a decent amount of materials and items to choose from. The devs created the perfect atmosphere with a world full of areas to explore.
My only complaint is the multiplayer. I played through the whole game, getting 100% achievements with a partner without problems, but we ran into connecting issues after playing for a week or so. It wasn't game-breaking for us, but it was annoying and frustrating. Often the host had no issues, but the second player kept getting kicked off the session. I'm not sure what this was caused by since there were no pattern to it. However, more often than not, we had no problems, but I did read about others who were very effected by this issue.
Multiplayer issues aside, this is one of the most detailed and fun games I've ever played. I've spend hours upon hours, just running around and exploring every little corner and cave of this stunning world.
If you like open world survival/craft games, this is a must-play!

For a game that seems "aimed" at a younger audience, it is absolutely way too hard when playing co-op with one other person (two players total.) We dropped the difficulty to "Mild" but it's still ridiculously grindy and getting the materials needed to upgrade is a huge challenge. Enemies get stronger but we were never able to get stronger. 26 hours in and...constantly dying when trying to advance. Enemies are extremely cheap and can hit you, even the damn mites from earliest game, they phase through everything and can follow you endlessly and always land a hit on you when you are just trying to run past. They aren't hard. but its extremely annoying. 

Seriously, the game needs some balancing. It's just not fun to play past a certain point. If people want a challenge, they should be able to play on Hard mode. But this game is way too hard even on "mild" which is the easiest mode. And I've played plenty of difficult games including Elden ring. But this one is just too annoying and I can't be bothered to finish the story mode after all this time spent on the game.

I have 26 hours in this game at the time of writing. I've been playing the game coop with my Brother. The first thing we had to do was drop the difficulty after 30 minutes because everything was killing us super fast.

The game just does not have any sort of balance at all. Even on the "Mild" Difficulty the game starts at hard and only gets harder. Insect HP is so high and their movements so erratic it takes over 1 minute to kill a single large insect. Then once its dead it gives 1 material only. So you have to spend 30 minutes hunting just to make a single piece of gear.

Normally as a game progresses enemies get harder but you also get more powerful. Not in this game. Enemies just keep getting tankier and with faster attack combos. Even farming upgrade materials and upgrading our gear did not help.

Grounded belongs to a very, very particular genre of game that, despite the game's superficial "survival crafting" structure, is actually a rare breed. This kind of game:

1. has a complex, [i]hand-crafted[/i] map that the game focuses around exploring. this is key; randomly-generated maps just won't do.
2. as you explore, more and more of the map becomes your home, your stomping ground, as you become familiar with it. areas that were once terrifying are now not so bad. but neither do old areas become "obsolete" as you "level out" of them, either.
3. you slowly get more powerful -- not just through gear upgrades, but also through understanding how to deal with (often very lethal) dangers and threats around you.

I played alone, so I can't speak how Grounded is with friends, but the difficulty was rather high -- but at the same time, that high difficulty rewarded creative gameplay and wise choices, making me feel very clever when I came up with a way to defeat something much stronger than me.

Overall, it's a really unique experience. If you like the idea of exploring a big, layered, and terrifying world filled with things that want to kill you, you'll have a lot of fun with Grounded.

After over 300 hours of playing almost exclusively solo both with an intermediate version and lately the full version (including ending), I can wholeheartedly say that I did enjoy this game. It's key selling point are atmosphere and level design - basically what I bought it for after watching a colleague play it. Ever since "Honey I shrunk the kids" I wanted to experience this concept in a game form and that's very much what you get here. It's absolutely great in that respect and unique in the way it represents it.

What I didn't like, though, is (unfortunately) most of the gameplay. There's a whole load of base building, crafting, farming, grinding, being annoyed about overly tanky enemies (especially bosses) and a damage system that has conceptional connections to the bug world you're in but is so abstracted-out that I barely ever bothered using it. A lot of what you can do in the game is locked until you've found certain areas and have beaten certain bosses with areas of interest being simply unmanageable/inaccessible to due to lack of key items and/or resources. This will leave the more exploration minded player frustrated at first and then gradually bored since "the good stuff" requires grinding another hour to get key materials, build stuff and wait for crafting stations to have another layers of materials for more crafting. Combine this with an often more functional than exciting combat + item management system and you get a whole load of moments where you simply have to force yourself to continue. It gets better with major advances in your main quest  but I only found every, say, third point of key advancement to be interesting in terms of rewards (exploration, new interactions etc).

Overall, it works quite ok since there are many elements to busy yourself with and certain moments only truly work if you've spend a decent amount of time working towards it. What absolutely didn't work for me under any circumstances were the bosses, consistently respawning enemies, overly long enemy health bars (without ways to shorten battles), lackluster base defense mechanisms (you're often better off just fighting normally) and the amount of grinding to required to advance any of your gear or even base building blocks. Maybe that's because I played solo and prefer exploring, but I can't imagine having fun grinding even more to upgrade four players than just one. Afaik there are game options to simply unlock most advances at game start but that of course kills the fun of progression. A poor but welcomed fix if I ever want to play it it again.

As such, I can recommend it to players who don't mind tackling mandatory grinding with the outlook of experiencing a rather unique feel and level design. Personally I don't think I'll be touching it again for at least a couple years but will be looking forward to playing it again with adjusted settings where I don't need to bothered with its lackluster elements.

This game is epic!! Exploration is very satisfying, the game looks stunning, the music is absolutely on point (the whole game is worth playing just for that sweet "Noble Spirit" to play before growing up) and the atmosphere is chilling!

All in all, it reminds me a lot of Subnautica - not the aesthetic, obviously, but the style of play in terms of surviving, building and exploring. Your bases can genuinely be very satisfying to build - I love my strongholds - and the build-tool is intuitive and simple. Building one grand base is entirely plausible, but you'll probably build a few outposts as well (I'd recommend this in general).

Exploring feels great - but like Subnautica, beware! When you're swimming through the endless ocean, you might just hear a roar off in the distance... You tilt your craft down as you zoom through the ocean, but looking down 100 - 200 m you cannot see nothing in that dark void below you ... when suddenly a leviathon pops out and OH MY GAAWWWD!!!! Well... You'll find yourself hitting similar vibes in this on the occasion. You're walking around, and suddenly you hear some monstrous shriek and then there's 8 legs crawling all over you! Those Wolf Spiders are not to be underestimated, even when you are kitted out with some of the best gear.. I've gotten some of, if not the, best gear in the game, and when I'm running from A to B at max sprint through the blades of grass, I still get those tingles down my spine that at any minute I could just run into something seriously scary! With the way the world works, your vision is actually very limited at times, and it can be unnerving to say the least.

But! This is why the game is so damn good! It starts hard, and though those early areas become relatively easy, you still have to be on edge a little! There may be secrets you missed and there's little challenges knocking around as well, so an "old" area isn't ignored once you've gone onto the next (which I like).

And again, visually, it's very charming. The armour and weapons are nicely varied, and some of the higher tiers genuinely look pretty sweet!

All in all, this game is absolutely fantastic and WELL worth the money!! If you're a little hesitant, then shove it on your wishlist and wait for a discount. And do note that you absolutely can play it solo - I've completed the game entirely on my own on medium. (Though I've yet to try a few of the end-game bosses.)

Started playing in a 4-player party with not much prior knowledge to what the game is about. 
To be honest, it was very challenging to survive on the first day of playing. All of us had no idea what was going on and what we were supposed to do to survive, while meeting mobs every ten steps and getting wrecked left and right. (we played in medium difficulty.) i was pretty frustrated and actually thought about refunding the game. But boy, am I glad that I decided to stick through. As soon as we got the hang of it, it was one of the most engaging multiplayer experience. It took a lot of guides, trials and errors and youtube videos to really understand everything and learn stuff the game would not tell you though. But it is so worth it and I find myself continuing to build and explore everyday even after we finished the story quests. I do have some suggestions: cutscenes for the boss encounters and as a building fanatic, it would be nice to see some more furniture variations like lounge beds, parasols, flower vases to help make the bases even more cozier. I can't wait for the coming future updates for new areas and other stuff!

This is probably in my top ten list of games ever.  To win that prize a game needs 3 things:
1) A compelling narrative
2) To occasionally surprise me with a unique mechanical innovation in the context of the title
3) A core gameplay and progression loop that is rewarding and consistently fun to play until the end

Grounded has all these things and more.  The story is excellent, and Zachary Levi is a joy to listen to as it unfolds.  This point is doubly important for a survival/crafting game, the overwhelming majority of which don't appear to have any kind of coherent narrative at all, or at least one that's not delivered through collectibles.  The innovation in the context of a crafting game is so good, I can't imagine being able to stick with other survival titles unless they include some of the things I've seen here: Hot deposit of matching items into nearby containers, crafting from workstations using materials in nearby containers, freeform ziplines for large-scale world traversal, and more.  There is never any opportunity in this game to increase your inventory size, and I can't imagine that not being a deal breaker in any other survival game, but Grounded is inventive enough to make it work.  The core gameplay loop of examining parts from defeated yard creatures and constantly unlocking new gear until you become the yard's apex predator is also extremely satisfying.

My only gripe is that it may not appeal to the casual gamer, despite its easy-going aesthetic.  Some parts of it are just plain hard, especially if you're playing by yourself (and this is coming from a rabbid Souls fan).  Grab a friend for the optimal experience, but with or without companions it remains one of the best games I've ever played.

TL;DR - Mow the yard one blade at a time, kill car-sized spiders, Zachary Levi, what's not to love?

There's a lot I really WANT to like about this game. The aesthetic is great, building is fun and satisfying to do! I love the goofy setting and while the characters' voice lines do get annoying, I like that they're each individuals with their own thing to say.

The problem is that the progression feels like absolute ass. You start out way too weak to kill the bugs you need to kill in order to get upgrades. Perfect blocking is way too demanding (my reflexes are horrible, admittedly) and basically the only way to get by. Arrows feel utterly pathetic and do barely any damage to enemies, so trying to kill things "safely" from range is an absolute joke. Fundamentally nonsense concepts like needing a gas mask to kill a stink bug -- which drops the parts you need to craft a gas mask. It feels. Really. Bad.

Just absolutely needs to be rethought from the ground (lol) up, honestly. Which sucks, 'cause there's a lot of charm and a lot to love. But as it stands it's a miserable slog.

Grounded is the result of handing a halfassed survival game like Icarus to a bunch of baboons and locking them in a room with computers for a year. Sporting questionable design choice after choice you'll find yourself pondering why someone paid these people in the first place given the wide array of terrain glitches, connection issues, client errors, enemy monsters that float around cleaving players who aren't actually in hit range, mandatory death passages, and many more fun things. Grounded is to my mind anyways, yet another fine example of why one should think before buying a game when it claims to have left early access. Far as actual gameplay go, Grounded still needs another while to cook it would seem.

Update: One major expansion later, all problems remain and only have gotten worse. This is by far one of the shoddiest survival games on the market.

Awesome game. Singly great. It is addictive and interesting. The designers did a great job of fleshing out the backyard, designing the larger than life enmies it's a fun romp through a cheeky world that is super addictive.

Building is satisfying, combat is satisfying, progression is satisfying with all upgrades being shared amongst the team, even those that join in later. 

Crafting is excellent, with materials being taken from nearby chests, with the ability to exempt chests and hot drop all your inventory is great quality of life. 

Weapons and upgrades come at a satisfying pace with lots to find hidden all over the map, the story is done pretty well (though I am not to the end yet).

My group of 3 simply can not put this game down, we play it ever chance we get. Can't speak to replayability just yet (doesn't seem like it will be as great on a replay) but even once through is well worth the purchase.

Grounded is a game centered around [b]player fun[/b] and comes with many difficulty settings that allow you to decide how much of a challenge is wanted, its Custom Mode has many Options:
[list]
    [*]Difficulty
    [*]All Recipes Unlocked
    [*]All Recipes Free
    [*]Bugs Spawn
    [*]Quests
    [*]All Mutations Unlocked
    [*]Fully Yoked
    [*]Bugs Ignore Players
    [*]Building Integrity
    [*]Player Damage
    [*]Friendly Fire
    [*]Pet Invincibility
    [*]Hunger/Thirst Drain
    [*]Stamina Drain
    [*]Equipment Durability
    [*]Food Spoiling
    [*]Menus Pause Game
    [*]Faction Reactivity
    [*]Handy Gnat Enabled
    [*]Backpack Items on Death
[/list]
[spoiler]I wish Valheim had that many options to let players customize the way they want to experience Valheim.[/spoiler]

Grounded also has many [i]quality of life[/i] things like you can quick deposit stuff into nearby chests and when you craft something materials get pulled out directly from containers nearby. To build structures you can place down blueprints first and complete it later and it is also very easy to just relocate any structure you build to another spot, this goes as far as allowing you to abuse this system to move full storage containers with you on the go. Just if you get hit while"holding" the to-move item it is reset.

If you like builder type games, like Subnautica among others then I can only suggest you to take a look at Grounded. The one and only thing to watch out for is that the game can suck hours out of you just farming materials and building stuff. While it is possible to beat the game without building a big base, there are a couple "defend the spot" missions one being among the required last story missions which require you to build defenses. And for those you do need to a smal'ish base, which doesn't need to be ultra defended. The biggest work is probably building a [i]tall central tower[/i] so you can create a spidernet of ziplines, but it is not essential.

Had a blast playing this with my wife. We do not usually play survival games together, but this one was really fun - we were hooked from the beginning. The natural progression of the story and obtaining (and discovering) new resources, gear and equipment kept us busy for many fun hours. Glad there was a nice story and ending, will definitely recommend this game.

Then it will happen to him and we have to repeat the process. Otherwise it's fantastic. Great amount of fun content with good progression and leveling. Excited for more updates.

TLDR: Incredible and unique survival crafting game with massive amount content, highly polished mechanics, and dedicated team of devs. Buy it now and bring a friend. This review is for casual gamers, not the hardcore or the streamers. 

I play many survival crafting games. I don't think of myself as an expert, I view myself as a casual gamer who plays a lot - and always with others on coop. In other words, I represent the lay gamer who gets off the beaten path of big titles and who plays socially. 

Grounded probably has to be the best survival crafting game I've ever played. Even though I like the environment of Valheim better, the tranquility of Raft better, and the idea of Stranded Deep better - these are all aesthetic preferences. When it comes to considering which survival crafting game must actually be better in any objective sense, for me that has to be Grounded. Here is why:

First off, Grounded is just extremely well polished. Things work very well. It doesn't constantly crash. It had the feeling of a completed game even before 1.0 was released. Combat mechanics, for example, are excellent and offer a wide variety of builds and methods of setting up a team. 

Secondly, the amount of content in this game is incredible. At time of writing, I've sunk 136 hours into the game and could easily do that over again. Every time you think you've done it all, you find a load more you can do. The map is huge and extremely interesting, with nooks and crannies that will keep you surprised and excited for long hours. Are there things they didn't add that they could? Sure, but the fact that they're still doing just that brings me to my next point.

Devs won't quit. The fact that this game is still getting large updates, which meaningfully expand gameplay and content, is just really impressive. I wish many of the other games I play had the same kind of dedication and consistent updates. 

Huge potential for creativity. You can craft a lot of very cool and beautiful structures or bases. But a big difference with this game is that you can absolutely make them practical. Don't get me wrong, I'm a sucker for crafting projects for their own sake (E.g. my double upside down pyramid towers in Raft). But it's also really nice when you can put a lot of work into structures that you continue to use and benefit from. Our system of zipline towers connecting bases across the map has really made the game a lot more fun. My teammate and I really feel like we've built a networked empire across the map from which we can launch expeditions to whichever of the myriad of activities that the game offers. 

Freedom. The settings let you do a lot with the game that many comparable games don't. Want to change the color of the lights you just put up? Sure. Wanna pose for selfies with your friends after an accomplishment? Do it. 

Uniqueness. I've never seen a lot of the things the devs had added into this game. Seriously, I wish I could've sat in on their board meetings and listened to them brainstorm because I don't know how the heck you come up with this stuff. Shrunken teens collecting crow feathers and smashing loose human teeth scattered around the backyard with a hammer to unlock special stat points? Okey dokie. I'll be darned if it doesn't work though. Somehow all with a strange 80s vibe = extra points. If this sounds crazy, just try it and see if it doesn't somehow work seamlessly. 

I'm biased, but I'd say I recommend bringing a friend. This game is definitely better when you're building and exploring in a team or a pair, but I'm notorious for never playing single player so if that isn't you just disregard that.

10/10 would dive in the pond again.

TOP TIER GAME

If you love exploring and base building this game is amazing. I really truly enjoyed it. 

If you want to explore a rich diverse game world - BUY THIS GAME.

But it does have some issues. 

I'm not a big fan of multi-player survival/explore/base build. I far prefer it be single player only. Just let me run around and get lost in the world. But there is multi player for this and some stuff that is definitely biased towards multi player (post end of story bosses as an example.) Can they be done solo? Sure - I've seen videos of it. Is it geared for that? Doesn't seem to be. Also things like getting the Coaltana or any of the MIX.R events seem very multi-player driven.

Getting from one Tier to the next Tier is an issue. To get to the next tier of gear you have to kill that tier's mobs with your current tier gear. As an example, to get your first Tier 2 items you have to kill Tier 2 mobs with your current Tier 1 gear. The movement from one tier to the next is not gradual. (Tier 2 to Tier 3 was worse.)

Upgrade materials for weapons would make that tier to tier jump more doable - but the upgrade items are rare (quartzite and marble) and they don't respawn.  By the time you are trying to get Tier 3 - you'll probably have it down. But when you're still new and don't know which items you should upgrade a bad choice might stick with you for a long time. 

I dislike CONSTANTLY having to hunt for food and fresh water. It's a constant burden in the Grounded world.

I also don't care for constantly having to repair weapons and gear. I managed to kill a couple of bees and make a related weapon! Yahoo for me! But then I found I was frequently hunting bees (not fun) to keep the weapon repaired. Tier 3 stuff gets easier - as it all repairs with 'glue'. But I spent a lot of time hunting and repeat killing the same mobs over and over to keep my gear repaired.

I don't mind some farming, even occasionally heavy farming. Grounded requires so much resource farming. Gathering clay, grass, weeds, etc. WAY too much farming.

The different types of weapons (slash, stab, chop, bash) combined with dmg types (spicy, fresh, salty, sour) is interesting. Until you have to carry 8 weapons with you everywhere to make sure you'll have one that works on whatever mobs you might encounter. 

Inventory space is WAY WAY WAY too limited. It gets better for storage at your base as the game progresses, but your carry space is always very limited. That is more of a problem when you have to carry lots of different gear all the time.

I do not want to be exhaustive here.  After a second play-through, the game now fully completed, I would still recommend Grounded.  I will admit that the armor system is more than annoying, as well as, the way you heal.  The fact that you cannot set your gear to match your mutations and action bar is a big hole in the enjoyment factor.  The fact that there are only 4 variations of saved mutations is a shortfall with so many combinations of gear, mutations, consumables and so on.  Because of this, and if you want to maximize efficiency, you spend a lot of time messing with gear manually.  The fact that a trinket is in the same slot as a tuft is simply nonsense.  The staves charging option is very delayed and sometimes does not react properly.  Attacks are stored up very oddly, so that you can click three times, even when the action takes a very long time, the attacks still execute.  This was very odd for those who played with me as well.  The game is very choppy in this way though the fighting itself is relatively smooth.  Pets are another annoyance.  They are completely worthless in my opinion.  The noises they make, alone, make them better off dead.  And the worse part of the game, by far, is the friendly fire.  This is simply a disease that should have been cured day one but remains unless you lower the difficulty or make a custom game which disables achievements.  Building is another drain.  The way you carry grass blades, the structural height limitations, the lack of elevators, the lack of bridges, the way every resources spills out bounces and is collected individually is a pain after the millionth time of having to endure it, are all little annoyances that cause more frustration than I think they are worth.  There are so many interesting discoveries that making a few building adjustments would not remove the excitement of discovery in my opinion but streamline it.  They took away valid areas you used to be able to build before the full release, that was a pain.

However, the finished game has so much to do in finding gear, recipes, raw science, Sca.b, molars, etc.  The landscape is probably the most impressive part.  It is very well thought out.  The team that put it together deserve the love for this labor.  Other games will have areas which seem as if they should be for hidden rewards but they are empty and meaningless.  it seems like the Grounded team's purpose was to make every corner rewarding.  It was also very expansive in every direction, climbing the top of a wood pile or sandbox, descending to the depths of the ant hills or pond.   Very well done.  I really appreciate the voice acting as well.  It is not that gamers cannot read, but voice acting adds a level of intimacy in personalizing the story development.  Done well, which it was, and complete, you have a interactive and involved mission you want to be a part of, and otherwise, it can be a huge drain.  Again, very well done.  Not to give too much away, but the story ended happily.  That is a huge plus.  Others had suggested that the characters should have been, playable, large for a short while at the end of the story, giving it more closure, but it did not lack satisfaction in totality.  Again, the story was completed, the bad guys lost the good guys won, well done.

Only play this if you have at least 1 friends. This game is not balanced for solo, and with a party, it's a total slugfest with mobs have absurd hp, bs hitboxes that often ignore shield (eg. explosions) and a lot of facetanking.  

The enemies also lack moveset varieties. Once you've beaten Wolf spider, you basically seen every enemies in the game. The differences between low tier vs high tier mobs are HP and damage, which are basically artificial difficulty.    

If you don't have custom game enabled (disables achievement), I hope you enjoy spending 20min retrieving your items from halfway across the map during late game due to poor balancing, especially if [spoiler] you seal the haze cannister. [/spoiler]   

That being said, this game could be great if they introduce some more QoL features and tune down those late game mobs. The map is also handcrafted and gives similar exploration vibe to Subnautica. But right now, it's only recommended if you have friend(s) who can endure the stall-fest.
Worth the wait.

[h1]RAW SCIENCE![/h1]
Grounded's core foundation is on being played together, 2 players or more and with each additional player it becomes easier. It regularly receives updates with new content and patches and is very easy to pick up and play at any time. Worlds can be hosted online for free to allow one player to play even while the other is away (Basically Minecraft Realms but free). It is a fantastic take on being shrunk down in the backyard and definetly takes inspiration from older movies. Definetly worth buying if your have someone else who is interested - you will not be dissapointed.

Chilli con carne recipe

if you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding Chilli con carne recipe you've come to the right place,

Ingredients

1 large onion
1 red pepper
2 garlic cloves
1 tbsp oil
1 heaped tsp hot chilli powder (or 1 level tbsp if you only have mild)

1 tsp paprika
1 tsp ground cumin
500g lean minced beef
1 beef stock cube
400g can chopped tomatoes
½ tsp dried marjoram
1 tsp sugar (or add a thumbnail-sized piece of dark chocolate along with the beans instead, see tip)

2 tbsp tomato purée
410g can red kidney beans
plain boiled long grain rice, to serve
soured cream, to serve

Directions

STEP 1
Prepare your vegetables. Chop 1 large onion into small dice, about 5mm square. The easiest way to do this is to cut the onion in half from root to tip, peel it and slice each half into thick matchsticks lengthways, not quite cutting all the way to the root end so they are still held together. Slice across the matchsticks into neat dice.

STEP 2
Cut 1 red pepper in half lengthways, remove stalk and wash the seeds away, then chop. Peel and finely chop 2 garlic cloves.

STEP 3
Start cooking. Put your pan on the hob over a medium heat. Add 1 tbsp oil and leave it for 1-2 minutes until hot (a little longer for an electric hob).

STEP 4
Add the onion and cook, stirring fairly frequently, for about 5 minutes, or until the onion is soft, squidgy and slightly translucent.

STEP 5
Tip in the garlic, red pepper, 1 heaped tsp hot chilli powder or 1 level tbsp mild chilli powder, 1 tsp paprika and 1 tsp ground cumin.

STEP 6
Give it a good stir, then leave it to cook for another 5 minutes, stirring occasionally.

STEP 7
Brown 500g lean minced beef. Turn the heat up a bit, add the meat to the pan and break it up with your spoon or spatula. The mix should sizzle a bit when you add the mince.

STEP 8
Keep stirring and prodding for at least 5 minutes, until all the mince is in uniform, mince-sized lumps and there are no more pink bits. Make sure you keep the heat hot enough for the meat to fry and become brown, rather than just stew.

STEP 9
Make the sauce. Crumble 1 beef stock cube into 300ml hot water. Pour this into the pan with the mince mixture.


info.
This great chilli recipe has to be one of the best dishes to serve to friends for a casual get-together. An easy sharing favourite that uses up storecupboard ingredients.
it's also freezable

Probably one of the best survival crafting games around. I think I put more hours into Terraria but I genuinely love this game. 

The atmosphere, the difficulty, the progression, the weapons are everything I wanted. At night, I feel the danger and when the game gets easy, it slaps you in the face with a new area. Amazing atmosphere and a game I am actually wanting some DLC for. this game is complete, one of the most complete survival crafting games and definitely the most complete 3d survival crafting game. The game's hot deposit is pretty good and the shared world is a wonderful addition that all games should have. If you have 4 players in the world, the game can allow any user to host and grind on their own. Shared world means that all players can grind, turn off the server, and anybody else can pickup the game where the other left off. This completely removes any jank with using a shared dropbox or google cloud save and sharing with your friends. Upgrades are meaningful and there are times when  I have to sit down and think about how to approach enemies or what mutations work best here.


Some cons
- QOL is needed, especially gardening
- Multiplayer can be a bit weird, dew drops being fake, buildings arent filled in until you hit it or something. syncing.
- The building system is just OK, its not clunky, but theres no real reason to innovate or push yourself to build interesting bases. no redstone or any other electricity to push the envelope.
- More bosses are needed especially in the early game.
- buffs are visible but lack any % or tangible numbers. sometimes we have to go to the wiki to find out what certain trinkets do or the % on mutations.

9.5/10 This game is so good its a top 2 survival crafting game and I thoroughly enjoyed my time.

A survival sandbox game with an amusing twist. Much like any other, you need shelter, food and water to survive. Playing as one of four kids that have been shrunk, your average garden just became a terrifying fight for survival. Spiders, mites and other creepy crawlies are out to get you! Fight your way through abandoned laboratories and uncover secrets, or take on the meanest of the bugs in epic boss battles, or maybe you fancy yourself an interior designer. The game provides fun for all, easy, normal, hard or creative if you prefer to just build fantastical bases. It is very much a game that rewards curiosity and exploration. 

Grounded has a fun and whimsical story that sends you discovering old laboratories left by an eccentric scientist. The vibe is light hearted and very much fitting the children's movie vibe. Each lab is located in tough to reach areas and often require you to at least get some gear before taking on the challenge. Each lab provides a reward, be it unlocking new areas or quality of life upgrades. 

As a casual player I found the combat to be reasonably challenging, it feels responsive and it's easy to aim your strikes. Blocking is a core mechanic, and with practice and good timing most bugs are now easily overcome. The game does an amazing job building your confidence as you progress. Dying means dropping your backpack, meaning your items can be retrieved. However keep in mind where you venture, you might not be able to get it back as easily as you were hoping. The game is also great at providing variety, you can take on the challenges of the garden with a whole bunch of weapons, axes, daggers ,hammers, spears or even just your fist. Each bug having weaknesses and resistances forces you to carry at least a few different weapons in order to survive. 

The mechanics are easy to learn, but they are more in depth that is what is described. The game does a poor job teaching you about new things at times. Armors give passives, and sets give an even better passive, sometimes the passives are needed to progress as well. And unlocking upgrades can be a guessing game unless you have the wiki next to you. At times I was left clueless as to what the next step was. However most of the time it meant that I had not dared to explore the deeper parts of the garden. 

Overall, this is an amazing experience, I reckon around 150 hours is enough to soak in the entire experience but in any sandbox game. The game is what you make it, I have yet to complete my base and take on the hardest of bosses. Better yet, the game is still getting updates and content is added somewhat frequently. For me it's the stylized approach, with upgrade systems, weapon variations and armor passives that gives this game an amazing variety in playstyles. Making sure everyone finds something they like.

You have to log in with a Microsoft account to unlock Steam achievements, even for single-player.

I was having multiplayer mode login issue (many threads that people had same problem back in 2020 are still active with new player asking for help, which shows how lazy these devs are). I finally find out it is "XBox Networking" problem:
1. type "Xbox networking" in win10 search bar, click the best match
2. it shows the problem is "Teredo is unable to qualify" and "server is blocked"

After searched "Teredo is unable to qualify" and test with many solutions, I was able to fix the problem by:
1. type "Computer Management" in search bar, click the best match
2. go to "Services and Applications" -> "Services", make sure the service "IP Helper" is running
3. type "Edit group policy" in search bar, click the best match
4. go to "Computer Configuration" -> "Administrator Templates" -> "Network" -> "TCPIP Settings" -> "IPv6 Transition Technologies"
5. click "Set Teredo State", and set "Enable" and states to "Enterprise Client"
6. click "Set Teredo Server Name", and set server name to "win10.ipv6.microsoft.com"
(
these are all server names provided, change if one of them not help:
-- teredo.remlab.net
-- teredo2.remlab.net
-- teredo.iks-jena.de (this is best for me)
-- win10.ipv6.microsoft.com
-- teredo.ipv6.microsoft.com
-- teredo.trex.fi
)
7. finally check teredo state using CMD: "netsh interface Teredo show state". the result should be look like this:
(
-- Type                                : enterpriseclient (Group Policy)
-- Server Name                   : win10.ipv6.microsoft.com (Group Policy)
-- Client Refresh Interval    : 30 seconds
-- Client Port                       : unspecified
-- State                                : qualified
-- Client Type                      : teredo client
-- Network                          : managed
-- NAT                                 : cone
-- NAT Special Behaviour   : UPNP: Yes, PortPreserving: No
-- Local Mapping                : xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx:55595
-- External NAT Mapping    : xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx:16323
)
and check "Xbox networking" to make sure "Xbox Live multiplayer" server connectivity is "Connected"
8. open game and login to multiplayer mode, enjoy!

Grounded is a very fun Survical Adventure-Builder game. Excellent co-op title for 4 players. Im not huge into survival games, but this one is great in a lot of aspects to where its caters to all survival skill levels.

There is some minor issues with physics based items and building / building components. Takes a lot of resources on GPU's and CPU's. My friend has a PC a few years older than mine, started with a 2060Ti (Medium settings) and he was only able to get 45fps average in Base Areas and peak of 65 in open world. I upgraded him to a 4070Ti, he maxed settings to Epic and he was able to get at least 65fps in our most densest built base and anywhere between 120-150fps in the open world. Physics based areas like the Charcoal Grill he was only getting about 35fps even with a 4070Ti due to his 9700KF 8-Core CPU.

My PC - 4070Ti and 12700KF 12-Core CPU - Our densest base I got about 90fps, open world 140-180fps with everything maxed out. Physics was the only issue I had beside a few random crashes or disconnects (not related to steam outages).

All-in-all id say this game is a 9 out of 10.

For the few hours I was able to play this with my daughter, it was fun. However, the multiplayer uses XBox Live, and logging in is hit or miss. It should be a simple matter to connect to a friend and play together. Getting it running was clunky. We finally got it running, though, and had fun. Then, in the little time I have during my busy schedule, we sit down to play again, and it says I have to login to the XBox Network. I click the button. The logging in sign circles for about a second and disappears. I am not logged in. I repeat this multiple times. Same thing happens. No error message. I can't find anything online specific to this issue, though some people say multiplayer was broken with the latest update. I try logging out of XBox Live and logging back in. I try rebooting my computer. No dice. My daughter is able to log in, though. I should be able to sit down and play this game with her without this waste of time. Hey, Obsidian, make this simple and robust! This frustration is making me very negative about a game that otherwise is enjoyable.

Edit: Okay, I was able to fix the problem. I had to go into the Xbox App and unlink my Steam account. Then, when I opened Grounded again, it brought up a brand new login prompt. Here's how I did it:

1. Open App
2. Click username in top left corner
3. Click settings
4. You should be on the account page. Scroll down to Linked accounts.
5. Click unlink on the Steam account.
6. Now start up Grounded and log in.

Hope this helps someone. Fun game, but this is ridiculous. If they streamline the process and make it simpler to connect to friends, I will change this review, because I like the game in general.
