Overall Rating: 10/10

I was in love from first weevil sighting. It's all about the Honey I Shrunk the Kids setting, and the early game open world exploration while running for your life from terrifyingly large spiders. Such good sound design on all the creatures! I played this single player which was still super fun, but hard as balls on medium difficulty until you can craft better equipment. I love a good collection / crafting grind so no complaints there; discovering a new resource always feels cool. The base building is well designed with snap points, and later in the game you start transforming the world to get around more efficiently. It's such a beautifully designed world too, with a variety of environments and challenges that made me want to explore every last bit of it.

Title: An Unforgettable Miniature Adventure - Grounded Review

Rating: ★★★★★ (5/5)

I can confidently say that Grounded is one of the most exceptional multiplayer experiences I've had in years. Teaming up with two friends, we were instantly transported into a world where everything felt surreal and intriguingly small. The game's atmosphere, paired with its vast maps, truly immerses players in the feeling of being shrunken down to the size of insects.

One of the standout features of Grounded is its breathtaking environments. The world is a masterpiece, full of wonders to explore and secrets to uncover. The attention to detail is astounding, and it's genuinely remarkable how the game designers managed to make even the tiniest nooks and crannies captivating.

Furthermore, the consistent flow of updates that keep changing and enhancing the gaming experience. The developers' commitment to improving the game based on player feedback is commendable, and as improved our gaming experience even that far off the release date of the game. 

Grounded was an absolute blast to play with my friends. The progression system is exceptionally well-designed, creating a perfect balance of challenge and reward. The desire to improve our gear wasn't just a meaningless grind; it directly impacted our survival chances. This added a layer of motivation and meaning to our cooperative efforts.

From exploring the lush greenery of the backyard to navigating the treacherous terrain of the garden, each location is uniquely crafted to keep players engaged and excited.

The charming characters in Grounded perfectly balance fun and relatability. Whether it's engaging in witty banter or navigating challenging situations, their personalities add a not always so subtle depth to the overall experience.

Moreover, the game's intriguing storyline is a driving force that keeps players coming back for more. As we unraveled the mysteries of the tiny world, the desire to uncover its secrets became irresistible. The narrative adds a sense of purpose to the gameplay, elevating the overall enjoyment.

Grounded is the epitome of a multiplayer game that requires cooperation and planning while still maintaining a lighthearted feel. The laughs, the challenges, and the triumphant moments we shared as a team are memories I'll cherish for a long time.

Incredible game so far! Only open world survival with a really fleshed out story that comes with cutscenes and a inner mystery. When I played Raft the story was very forgettable and gameplay mechanics kind of jank. Ark was the same way, there were hundreds of cool ideas but the bugs and story wasn't very well ... put together. With Grounded by Obsidian Entertainment I've experienced such a polished and well crafted mystery as I try to survive in the world of the small. I can practically build anywhere and the bugs can plan raids to your base! Your PC is a actual character with dialogue and a personality a part of this 4man team and your gameplay style will evolve depending on what the group wants to do. Music and sound is incredibly satisfying and at times perspective really feels like you are as small as Olimar and you feel this larger world in front of you. The Nights are immersive with really dark areas that you'll be happy to have a torch for as you setup strongholds and look further in the reason why your there to begin with.

Hands down the best survival crafting co-op game I've ever played. Unlike other games in the genre, it's so damn polished. Incredible effort and care has gone (and is still going) into developing this. Nothing seems to lack attention to detail. The unique areas of the giant map, atmospheric music, crazy bug sounds, crafting, inventory management, etc. ...It's all just solidly put together and surprisingly nostalgic for the "Honey I Shrunk the Kids" generation.

The story is goofy, but perfectly fits the charm of the world. Gameplay progresses forward at a nice pace to keep things challenging even into end game content. So much to do, explore, and of course, the base building. 

My only issue overall is the jump mechanics are a bit clumsy and tough to get used to. This is only a problem because of the many awkward platforming challenges and hidden items everywhere.
There is a reason less than 5% of players have the achievement for beating the game.

The first thing you'll notice is how darn good this game looks. We're talking about a bug's-eye view of a suburban backyard, and let me tell you, it's jaw-dropping. Each blade of grass is like a towering tree, and tiny pebbles are massive boulders – everything feels gigantic! And don't even get me started on the bugs. They've got these bugs down to a tee, from tiny little ants to huge, terrifying spiders (yeah, arachnophobes beware!).

Next up, the whole vibe of the game is spot on. It’s like you’ve been zapped into Honey, I Shrunk the Kids, and it's a wild ride. The ambiance is just something else - chilling beneath a leaf in the shadowy afternoon or being out in the open when the sunlight's beaming down, it's strangely soothing yet creepy at the same time.

Now, let's talk gameplay. As a casual gamer, I’ve gotta say, Grounded hits the sweet spot. It's got all the survival stuff - collecting things, crafting gear, building your micro fortress - it's a full plate. And the bugs aren't just for show, you’ll be fighting them off too. Each insect is a unique fight, so you gotta stay on your toes. And if you have buddies to join you, it’s a riot! But trust me, even playing solo is an absolute blast.

The story's not completely there yet, but it's getting intriguing. It's like they're teasing out a mystery about why you're so tiny and stuck in this place. Feels kinda like being in an adventure novel, except you're the main character.

Sure, there are a few rough edges. Sometimes the bugs (I mean the software ones, not the giant ants) can be a pain, like when a spider gets stuck in a rock or something. But honestly, it doesn't mess with the fun all that much. They've got the big things so right that the small glitches just kinda blend in.
This game is 10/10 it is perfect
It's such a massive game that you will feel very small. Lots of bugs but I like them.

Like all games that spent any time in early access, it shows. It can be buggy and you have to prepare yourself for that. 

BUT it is a genuinely good time. The first few hours in the game, being tiny and starving and dying of dehydration, are wildly most effective than most survival games I've played. The scale at first comes off as a gimmick, but after fighting off the first successful spider the feeling of success is enormous. I was on on my second set of armor and tools when I killed one on my own, no cheesing, just a fair fight. A giant orb weaver attacking our base in the dead of night and I was the only one any where near the house. It was after that I realized that the sizing and scale had a bigger impact than I realized. That spider felt like an insurmountably large monster even though he was only maybe two to three times the size of my player character and as far as video game bosses go that's not very large. The game had worked hard to make me afraid of it anyways, to make the player literally feel small. Just so I could conquer it.

Also there was no way I wasn't going to die defending our beautiful two story home with a cozy chimney and adorable clover leaf roof shingles. The base buildings pretty good.

Overall a great game, highly recommend!

This game is quite the unique take on a survival craft. It is similar to Deep Rock Galactic, in which one of the main objectives is to eliminate hostile insects in order to progress and reach higher levels of gear. The different ranges of bugs, weaponry, and armor made the first few hours enjoyable and interesting until a lot of the major issues with the game started to show:

1) Poor Optimization 

This game is poorly optimized. For the level of detail it offers this game should not be this demanding. I run a RTX 3050ti with 16GB of ram and a Ryzen 7 6800H. I had this game on lowest settings 1080p and had to even bring the resolution scale down to 80%. I was averaging ~70fps. This is really really bad. 

2) Limited Map/Level Design

The map design overall felt like it lacked effort. It felt like all the different kinds of insects and resources were just scattered around with no apparent difference in ambience or anything special linked to a certain type of insect. 
Three examples of better ambience: 

1- The red fire ants could have some kind of nest that is on fire adding environmental challenges while in engagement with them. This would push the player to engage from longer distances.

2- Black Widow Spiders could live in fog only areas limiting the players visibility and not allowing the spider to be seen until the last second. This would force players to switch to a more tanky gear set etc.

BONUS- You could have random events throughout the map such as a huge lawnmower going over the map cutting the tops of the grass cause you know people cut their grass (this wouldn't harm the player as the blade would be above their height but they could take small amounts of damage if they stood under it for a while). Or something like an insect migration.

This is a game it doesn't have to reflect reality just make things interesting and spicy for the player. Sure it is great that each insect has weaknesses but it isn't enough. The way the game is right now takes away the feeling of: "Wow I just discovered a new type of insect I wonder what is the best way of fighting it." Right now it's like this: "Cool a new insect let me check its weak spots and what weapons deal more damage to it and farm them until I can make the higher tier tool the harvests provide." It was like this for each new insect and it got very repetitive very fast. Rather every insect should be a surprise to the player. Since there isn't much emphasis on the story and this game has no PVP elements the only thing keeping the player hooked is progression and surprising environmental challenges/events like the ones mentioned above.

3) Tanky Insects

The insects are way too strong! Me and my friends played on medium difficulty and the insects had way too much health. The worst part is they also barely drop enough for you to craft the higher tier weapons using their body parts. This was the worst! If you are gonna make tanky enemies you have to make them rewarding to fight. If you are gonna make them drop very little they must be less tanky! Me and my friends were in this constant cycle of dying to the same insect and farming the same insect until we were able to craft the higher tier gear. It was painful. There must be some kind of balance. Perhaps an option is to increase player HP! Additionally killing an insect should be more satisfying. All insects have the same animation. They roll onto their back and freeze in place until you harvest them. Add some variance some spice for God's sake.

Summary: Surely this game is not completely horrible. The inventory mechanics are nice, building is fun/fast, and the fact that you can gain an advantage over insects by building towers and whatnot is also nice. Some parts of the game are quite solid such as movement, physics, ragdolls, weapon animations, and gear design. BUT. I do not agree with the price. Overall, this game did not meet my expectations at all with the price range it is at. Without any discount this game is $40 dollars. I am sorry but this game can be at most valued at $20 max with what it is putting on the table! Anything more than that is overvaluation. If you are going to purchase this game I would say wait for a discount of more than 50%!!!

I normally dislike sandbox games because of the lack of story and feel of purposeful progression, but Grounded doesn't make me feel that way. There is a light presence of plot in this game that is entirely optional. The art style and general theme of the 80's-90's are charming. I also really love the setup of unlocking "mutations" (perks) as you play and being able to expand and create multiple builds that you can effortlessly swap between even in combat. The armor and weapon bonuses are also very neat as well and can be combined with perks for fun min/maxing. Lastly, the building options are very fun and I love all the different styles and options.

Very frequent disconnects (basically once every 10-15m) together with desync issues remove a lot of the enjoyability from the co-op mode of this game. These issues were already in the game since beta and for a 40$ game marketed as a fun co-op experience it is unacceptable that they are still in the game 3 years later.

The bugs too are very problematic and then I don't mean the npc enemies. No I'm talking about water droplets getting stuck in the air untill you restart the game (you can't survive without these). Enemies can sometimes clip through terrain and attack you, you and npc can sometimes randomly teleport short distances which can get you killed if you're near a cliff/boss. This game has quite some game breaking bugs and feels more like an early access game than an actual product.

That aside the actual gameplay is pretty fun, the bugs look great and the fluff is pretty fun. Grounded can be worth it on sale but definetly not for full price.

Grounded is a truly special survival game that has evolved significantly since its early access period. With its "Honey, I Shrunk the Kids" premise, it exceeds expectations by offering a stunningly creative and consistently funny adventure. Drawing inspiration from RPG mechanics, the game combines scavenging, crafting, building, combat, exploration, and character progression. The sandbox-like backyard environment is beautifully designed, with each area presenting its own unique challenges and personality. The game strikes a great balance between making you feel on your own and introducing quirky characters. The story, although not always at the forefront, is utterly ridiculous and laugh-out-loud funny. Despite some inventory and stability issues, Grounded delivers a zany, challenging, and memorable experience, cementing its place among the best survival games.

Ok. The game is good - great even. BUT, there are somehow still two deal-breaking issues (for me specifically) that make this game  impossible to recommend in its current state - especially in multiplayer. 

1. The biggest issue by FAR is that everyone in the game (except the host) gets disconnected every 15 minutes, and then in order to rejoin you have to completely close and restart the game. Your mileage may vary but if I wasn't playing this game with my significant other (they host the game so I am constantly DCed) I would have absolutely stopped playing after the first hour or so. This issue by itself completely ruins the game for me, and makes it impossible to just enjoy it for what it is. 

2. The pet system is buggy (pun intended), unreliable and frustrating. My partner was super excited about getting pets in-game, but soon after getting her first one, it kept getting stuck whenever they would go exploring. To get it back, she would have have to run all the way across the map to get it unstuck, only for it to get stuck AGAIN on the way back. Then, to make matters infinitely worse, it somehow got itself stuck INSIDE the terrain, making it totally unable to be rescued or killed. Now she cannot have another pet of that type at all, despite hours of walking around hoping it would teleport next to her and somehow unstuck itself. This issue was so unfun for us (especially in combination with the first issue) that we almost stopped playing entirely despite otherwise enjoying the game.

If these issues are fixed (or you dont experience them), the game is good. It is a real shame that our experience with this game was tarnished by such frustrating issues, as otherwise I think it would have been a great time. We will likely continue to play until we finish the story, as we have already invested significant time in this game, but given this knowledge I would not have chosen to play this game initially.

This is an excellent game. Here is why.

It is an open world sandbox that has a story that is intriguing and different. The Art style is immersive and for some reason gives off vibes of days when I was a kid and could sit down and play my N64 for hours. The only thing that I wish is that this game implemented seasons where the weather could change over a period of time spent in the game. I feel as though if that were somehow an option it could make the game better (some would even argue it could make it worse and I could see that as well)

The overall combat is simplistic and easy for anyone to grasp. The progression is easy to follow and you must be willing to understand that creatures have weaknesses just as much as they have strengths and weapons and armor will either work with you or against you depending on what you are up against. The quest (storyline) in the game don't seem monotonous. There is always something to do. The game challenges you appropriately as you continue through the more difficult areas of the yard. 

Although I sometimes question BURG.Ls quest on the side for collecting raw science. You need so much of the raw science if you want to buy everything from the shop. I feel as though there could have been a bit more on variety of tasks you can do to earn that extra raw science. Like what if they could opt in for more Base Defense with your OWN base at risk that would be cool instead of going out and fighting a ton of either gnats, wolf spiders, orb weavers, weavils, or ladybugs to get the extra raw science needed to buy the extra items from the shop. The game already does base defense, why not make it more rewarding. What if they could somehow detect that if they do not touch your base at all then you get extra raw science for warding them off? 

I won't spoil the bosses here, but yes they are very challenging. I do like that in a game. I like the fact that they are challenging and difficult to take on and that you need to rely on your armor strengths just as much as your weapon strength to get you through. Recipes, Foods, and Trinkets in the game make it more unique. 

I will still continue to play this game many times over just because every time you go into the backyard there is a really good sense that the game is going to be entertaining and fun. Very good survival game. I would definitely recommend this to anyone. 

Devs: I must say that compared to most developers, Obsidian actually follows through and updates their game. I played this when it was first dropped. Since then, this game has been released in finished form. Compared to other survival games that are still in early access that have been out well before Grounded, I have to tip my hat to them for updating and being incredibly consistent.

For an Early Access game this is a pretty good game, and I would have a lot of good to say about implementing existing ideas and QoL stuff.

But I'm going to give thumbs down for being an obvious Early Access game that is probably for some very amazing and good reason not in EA anymore.

The lack of polish is apparent. 
Here are some examples from my multiplayer experiences so far:

-There are some specific things that desync (maybe they are broken in singleplayer too, I dont know), like dew droplets and construction. Sometimes constructed building parts like foundations, floors and walls after construction stay in "building mode" for some players. The fix is to reconnect to the game. Sometimes it breaks for the host too so you need to restart the server. Similarly dew droplets that are desynced stay so until server reset.

-There is at least one almost game-breaking bug that causes enemies called "Gnats" to disappear on contact with water and sometimes with ground and leave no loot, that was found quite some time ago (earliest mention I found was in April of 2021), of which the devs are apparently aware of according to reddit and steam, and it's still not fixed. What makes this bug almost game-breaking is that these enemies are an early-game enemy for resources to progress in your game further, and this bug makes it exceedingly hard to gain resources from them, given that they are usually located close to water as well. 

-There is an Ant hive where the ants are all stacked at the entrance but there is basically 0 ants inside. What? Maybe if there is a lore reason I missed from one of those cassettes, this is a non-issue.

-Looting or the looting prompt is bugged. More often than not, it's a pain trying to pick up anything. Sometime things you break into pieces or stuff that drops require you to be in some "correct angle" or just keep tapping until the item is picked up. It's not very fluid looting when you're trying to pick up a piece of grass for 5 seconds.

-Construction needs a ton of polish. From desyncs to lack of variety in parts to better mix&match compatibility between parts.

-Information dumps. There are some NPC monologues (at least one), that last for quite many minutes unless skipped. It's good to have lore you can read and some immersive dialogue.  A huge plus for voice-acting. But really does the thing have to tell us 2 light novels worth of information on first contact? It gets jarring especially in multiplayer when most players just stop caring after the first 3 sentences. And also most people really forget the information from the beginning of the monologue by the time it's ended so you achieved nothing.

It's still an Early Access game and should be treated as such.

It's worth it on a sale and with friends, but I'm starting to really dislike publishers/devs that just depend solely on the fact that their half-baked "non-EA but actually EA" games are good with friends. Even a burnt baguette is good entertainment with friends.

On "low" it's subtle enough not to make me motion sick but it's still present enough to pull me out of my immersion as I look directly at my friend ingame and their face is just a blurry pixelated mess because the DOF isn't focusing on them correctly.

I know a lot of people don't notice DOF but as someone who is used to using their peripheral vision constantly IRL and likewise in games will analyze what is on screen based not just at what my reticule is pointed directly at, DOF is confusing at best (as it is in this game) and nauseating at worst (which it more often than not is and thus makes a game an instant refund).

If it wasn't subtle enough not to cause me motion sickness I would've refunded this game instantly. Ideally we should be able to turn it off entirely.

With over 400 hours in grounded i can say only one thing about this game. Masterpiece.

The amount of things you can do in this game pushes the limits of creativity. You can build giant towers, houses, castles, ziplines across the backyard and many many more. This game might be scary for the first time but after a few hours and bugs killed you will fear the insects less. I went into this expecting to find something somewhat charming that I play a bit and then forget about, I was totally blown away! This is one of my favorite games this year, and perhaps of all time. 

I'm actually not even 100% finished, I've still yet to face the Wasp Queen and Infected Brood mother optional bosses. At the start I played a shared world with my boyfriend. He wanted achievements so he had to put it down to mild to avoid friendly fire without making a custom game. He also found the spiders too difficult and while I wanted the difficulty to stay at normal at first, friendly fire really sucks on higher difficulties for non-custom games so we stuck with mild. 

It was a joy to explore this unique, hand crafted set of levels. There's incredible motivation to go out and explore. Your job is basically to unshrink and to do that you need to find and explore shrunken down labs which each have their own challenges, insect infestations, incredible deep water, toxic gas, etc. Furthermore you need to take care of your day to day needs as well, you need to build shelter, have systems for food and water, and build better and better equipment for yourself. All of these systems are tied seamlessly and enticingly with exploration and combat. Finding new bugs to fight grants you new parts to craft weapons and armor, they give you more cooking recipes and more convenient ways to eat and drink. 

The combat is somewhat unexpected for this, it requires some reflexes, especially for spider like enemies, if you're bad at timing blocks you might want to lower the difficulty or even make a custom game to help yourself out. I really enjoyed it, I started out with a larva dagger which is really a sword and then moved on to the spider dagger, a real sword and shield combo. It was incredibly fast and its poison melted enemies quickly who didn't resist it. Enemies have weaknesses, resistances, and elements like spicy, fresh, sour, and salty take the place of fire, ice, lightning, and earth. 

The characters and story are intriguing as well, I don't want to give even a bit of it away, but this game is just incredible. Everything you do ties together in a satisfying way so no matter what you choose to do you're always making some kind of exciting progress. Cleverly there are optional areas that motivate you to explore them not just from their visual interest but because you can always find something new there. Indeed, many of these optional areas have some of the best weapon and armor recipes available to you. 

While not as important, I have to mention how amazing the graphics are. I don't have the most powerful computer so it kind of chugs near my base once in a while but outside of tightly designed and object loaded player housing my 3050 (laptop, so like a 1660 really) and my i5 at 4.1 ghz with 32 gb of ram worked out perfectly fine at max settings in the yard. The yard itself is a sight to behold, plants show transparency to light, water looks perfect, lighting is breath taking. Character models and enemies are stylized but don't clash and work incredibly well with the style chosen. 

If you like Minecraft but wanted it to look like it's modded realistically, don't mind the building being more restrictive, but want more interesting combat and a more tailored experience for exploration with easier co-op, this is a fantastic choice. I will most likely go back with other friends and do a custom game. I'll probably go and finish the Wasp Queen and the Infected Broodmother at some point later. I couldn't get enough of this game and all I wanted to do in my free time is play it more and more and more. Get that next weapon, build that next part of my base!

All around solid game, Genuinely satisfying Survival elements, Well implemented building mechanics, and a surprisingly good combat system. it is however some what bogged down by a hand full of problems, the impact of which will likely depend on how you approach the game.

Firstly all but one of the mandatory boss fights feel unnecessarily difficult in ways which do not feel 'fair' Namely for the first boss [spoiler] the arena is much too small, and the flood of Adds make it difficult to deal with the Towers effects, in addition to this The laser tower can take you from full health to dead nearly instantly. [/spoiler]
secondly all flying insects are incredibly annoying to fight if you do not keep a ranged weapon with you, and all armor that gives a bonus to the ranged options provide the least defense
and finally the game Distinctly feels as though it is meant to be played in co op with at least one other person. there are numerous moments through out the game where so many bugs are thrown at you at once that I genuinely dont know if its possible to do solo within a reasonable time frame, and the only way i was able to get through some of these was by [i] both [/i] lowering the difficulty [i] and [/i] making 3 to 4 layer thick mushroom brick walls. 

Ultimately its easier to talk about a games Negatives than its positives, and i think that while my grievances are significant, it is not nearly enough to stop this game from being a great time. it is well worth its asking price, even with out a sale.

By far the best coop (survival) game I've played. Great gameplay, awesome UI, cool theme and only good bugs.

BEWARE!

If you are after this game EXCLUSIVELY for multiplayer coop with friends, take caution. There is a bug ongoing with this game where the invited player will be kicked after 10 minutes. Not everyone will have this bug occur at all but in a lot of cases the bug will appear suddenly after an update and there is no proper fix for it that the community have found. So if it's multiplayer exclusively, just be aware that you might not end up able to multiplay. 
Hoping that Obsidian Games will eventually fix this fault, but at present it's been at least a year since people have been having this trouble and no communication has been made by the developers about whether there will be an attempted fix in the future. It doesn't look hopeful at present.

However, if you are playing this as single player for the story only, then it works fine and is an enjoyable little wander through the world. 

I am one of those people where I could coop with friends for a few weeks and then immediately following the 2022 Xmas update, I couldn't play anymore. Still trying to find a fix but no success as of yet.

Honestly I believe this to be the greatest survival game of all time, I have hundreds of hours across other titles like Ark, The Forest & SOTF, Green hell, Rust, Project Zomboid, and even Spore. The style is amazing and the graphics do a very good job at complimenting it. The bugs/enemies are amazing and their designs are some of the best I've seen in any game. The story is great after full release and the frequent updates make the game fresh and keeps it from getting stale. The base building is the best in any game I have played as well. This is one of if not the greatest survival games to ever exist.

As a survival game enthusiast, this game is insanely fun to play, especially with friends. Highly recommend to anyone who has played games like Subnautica or The Forest if you want a more casual yet complex survival game experience.

Grounded is a fantastic game of survival with a theme done so well you'll fall in love. Have you ever seen "Honey, I shrunk the kids."? Well this game is basically that. You're small, like really small. You are close to the same size as a regular ant. It allows for some great immersion as the environments and enemies are so big but you can establish that you're just in someone's yard. The game does a great job at making you feel so small by being relentless with the enemies, especially spiders, but don't worry, if you're arachnophobic the game has a setting to make the spiders less real. 

The crafting is great and definitely will scratch that itch of survival for many. It absolutely did for me and still does. Also hunger and thirst is a constant part of the game and imo is done very well. At first you're struggling to find a steady supply of clean water, food not so much as there are plenty of mushrooms and smaller bugs that you can find to eat. As such you have to settle for dirty water that makes you sick and gains you a sick level. Depending on your sick level, after drinking such water your hunger meter will drain accordingly. So you have to be careful not to drink too much unclean water or you will be at risk of starving to death. But the sick levels do go away with rest. Eventually you will learn how to collect dew and make a canteen to hold clean water and life in the game will get easier. 

Fighting bugs is a challenge, but grounded does a good job of letting you know the weaknesses of the enemies via the peek system where you literally peek at the enemy type and press a button to load them in your database. But sometimes avoiding bugs is necessary as in the early part of the game you will not stand a chance. Grounded does a good job of showing you enemies that you need to work towards eventually being able to take on, which allows for a great rewarding feeling when you start to get the hang of things. 

9.5 out of 10
p.s. - be careful playing on the hardest difficulty like I did as the game does not pull any punches and can be pretty hard. I personally like it and recommend it to those who are hardcore survival fans. There is no perma-death though so don't worry.

Its a big call, but I might have to say that this game was one of, if not my most favourite game I've ever played.
I'm pretty notorious for getting lost in maps in games, never has a game been more rewarding to literally "get lost" and discover something new. 

I genuinely feel Grounded ticked and exceeded nearly all of the boxes.
I thoroughly enjoyed all of the crafting and building in the game.
The combat was challenging but equally, if not exceedingly rewarding.
Taking down our first wolf spider at the start of the game was one of the most terrifying experiences. 
You cant help but feel a little confident later in the game when you're taking them on by yourself with an axe but that confidence doesn't last too long as there's always the next challenge around the corner. 

I think the thing that I enjoyed the most about this game was that it was not only enjoyable for me as a player but my coop buddies who both have different play styles to me really enjoyed it too. We all got satisfaction out of the game in our own ways. Having fun together and over coming feats that initially seem impossible kept us in this game for many many hours with many tequila celebratory shots had.

My only small negative feedback is some de-syncing issues that cause some objects in the environment to be there (or not) for a joiner, but on the most part we were able to work around these issues because everything else was so enjoyable. 

In conclusion, Grounded isn't just a game. It's an insect-infused adventure that will make you question your phobias, marvel at the wonders of the miniature world, and create unforgettable memories with your friends <3.

You HAVE to MANUALLY save or you WILL LOSE PROGRESS. This is absolutely on par for Obsidian but at least New Vegas had a Quicksave button.

This game is beautiful, i love the concept of being shrunk down and having to fight insects. The biggest thing i complement the game on is the challenge of the grind, I have not reached a point where this game has become too easy. From the very beginning almost every insect will kick your ass, as you find new materials and bug parts you unlock new crafting options, as you upgrade your equipment you can branch out and explore more of the yard. The further you explore away from the starting area the more difficult the insects become constantly keeping you on your toes. Another aspect of the game i enjoy is the terror you feel when you are quietly roaming around and you hear this terrifying screech causing you to jump scare, especially if you're exploring during the night. As i am writing this review in June 2023, there is currently plenty of content to keep you entertained for quite some time, so no worries about finishing this game super quick or getting bored.

Very Fun. I jumped into this game at v1.24 (as a solo player) and only played it in a free weekend a year or two back. It's much easier to get into, inventory has a sort button now, and, in general, the game does an ok job at introducing you into the basics, and does a good job at stopping the hand holding pretty soon thereafter (which is preferable, afterall, the map is static, the point is to explore).  

If you like base building/exploration/crafting games, this is up your alley.

[b]Hardware/performance:[/b]
With a 5900x, RTX3080ti and 32gb ram at 3600mhzCL16, performance with QHD/"Epic quality" generally ranges between 100-144fps, often finding itself hovering near 120fps. The game looks [i]gorgeous[/i], and one of the few games where depth of field is actually desirable to help immerse yourself in the scale of the game (you're very small!). No RTX/raytracing here, it's pure raster. Sadly there's no built in benchmarking tool.

[b]Pricing and "worth feels":[/b]
Grabbed this at 29.99CAD in June 2023 (40%off sale). RRP right now is $49.99CAD. Hope this is helpful for folks who put this kind of information in deal alert sites.  

I'm about 12 hours in, and still very early in what I need to do/craft (just getting into tier 2 item crafting [out of 3 it seems], have 2 bases setup) - definitely worth the price so far in my opinion.

I have played this game since the launch day of the first beta, and now that I have nearly gotten through the full release of the game, I can say without a doubt that Obsidian has managed to craft a masterpiece by listening to their audience and giving us a game we can enjoy and connect with. Never before have I been so immersed in a video game's world before, even compared to Half-Life 2, Left 4 Dead 2, and Fallout 3. The story is incredibly deep, and tells a narrative of a man who has lost everything, a stark but well-deserved contrast to the rest of the game's world being somewhat happy. The soundtrack is memorable and gives a good backing to all the fights of the game, allowing you to vividly remember them by just listening to the songs on their own. The combat is excellent, the building potential is large, and the amount of general stuff that can be done is impressive for a map that feels admittedly small.

Overall, Grounded is a truly challenging, rewarding, and enthralling experience that I have poured hours into over and over again, and will continue to support in the future.

I want to like this game but it's very badly balanced; I'm not sure if the devs are sadistic or just wanted to pad the game length, but the result is a frustrating slog.

You'll spend a significant portion of each in-game day traveling and looking for food and water. Eventually, you can build things to generate and store water, but it's a slog to get there. There doesn't seem to be a great way to store food; meat expires quickly, even when cooked, so you can't stock up. Eventually you unlock jerky but it's crap. Mushrooms don't go bad but you have to eat a lot of them to fill up.

Combat is extremely frustrating. Most enemies are [i]extremely[/i] tanky; for example, expect to spend several minutes to kill one spider, and spiders are EVERYWHERE ALL OF THE TIME. You can't just 'kill all of the enemies in an area', because they seem to respawn as soon as you travel a short distance.

The game is full of maddening catch-22s. You need Gnat Fuzz to make a bow, but it's almost impossible to kill a gnat without a bow. You need Sunken Bones to make gear that lets you swim further and faster, but the only way to reach them is by swimming down a hole that's so deep that you'll drown right after gathering them. You can only make good weapons with the parts that you would get from minibosses that are practically impossible to kill without good weapons.

As with many games in this genre, the game mechanics are not explained well and it seems like you are expected to play with a wiki constantly open for reference... which slows down gameplay even more.

There are various stupid glitches with the enemies getting stuck, not animating, moving through the ground, or hovering off into the sky. There are also many synchronization issues in coop. Some of the items still have placeholder artwork taken from other items.

I was excited when we finally unlocked turrets - but they're shitty. They don't seem very accurate, they chew threw ammo very quickly, and they do piss for damage. Just another way that Obsidian gives us all the finger.

Hmm... bad balance, slog to pad game length, placeholder artwork, lots of glitches... it's almost like it's still in Early Access...

Here is my take if play valheim with the boys and you're wondering if this is a good one to pick up. Here is what I said to them:

"Like, it had way more complex gearing, way more complex upgrading your gear, the combat was just generally more fun due to your weapons having profound advantages vs certain enemies based on type -- it was also quite fucking challenging i had to turn the damn difficulty down solo.

All the mods we added to valheim for quality of life are baseline in grounded. Hot deposit near chests built in. Blueprint (ghost) building before hand built in. Storage and inventory sort built in. Armor dummy hot swapping for loadouts built in. Map markers with custom icons and custom text built in. Hell you can even move anything around without emptying it out, like if you want to move a chest around you can just do it without having to empty it out and put it in another one. 

If we all did a playthrough together, i swear we'd have just as much if not more fun than we did playing valheim."

A well made, entertaining game from what I've seen so far. Creative mechanics, interesting story, and it doesn't feel like the game gives you everything just by looking at the map. The map does give you the location of some important things, but there's always something needed before going there. You can't just walk in like you own the place, basically. The game keeps the progression slow, but it never necessarily stops in its tracks. (Minor spoiler) Some people act like the bugs you encounter in the late game are basically the shrunken equivalent of jaws, but the game keeps everything easy enough on the easy and regular mode. There's many setting that could help, and YES, there's and option to get rid of nasty motion blur. If you feel like playing the game differently, you can just set up a custom world and give yourself your own limits. Do remember that this is going to make your STEAM achievements get pissed off. Basically, the game is great. If the community mashes in your face that a weapon is too powerful or too weak, just remember that the people screaming about it probably play on the most difficult mode all the time and hate themselves. Also, every second you don't buy this, that's one more reason in your life to delete steam and get a job. :)

If you want to play this game multiplayer, as it's pitched as a multiplayer game I would strongly encourage you to read up on it first.  The game has been having disconnect issues since early access best I can tell from the posts online.  A friend and I spent nearly 4 hours troubleshooting, running through "try this" lists from the developers and other users on the forums only to still have a disconnect every 10-15 minutes and massive desync issues.

4 hours into troubleshooting and refund request declined, so I guess I'm stuck with it now.  Do yourself a favor, check online to see if they've fixed it before buying.  As of today they have not and it's totally unplayable (in multiplayer) as is.

There are very few games I have enjoyed enough to play all the way through, but this is definitely one of them. The graphics are outstanding, and allows full customization of play.

I started on regular storyline play, but found that it was causing a lot of anxiety, but I really wanted to see where the interesting story went, so I started a new game on this great feature they have where you can choose the way the whole game operates, like turning off whether the bugs attack you, and having all recipes unlocked and not having to have any of the ingredients. I love this feature so much, because the main reason I like to play any games is to reduce my anxiety, and this facilitates that very well.

Once I have finished and know where I need to be more careful, I am planning on playing through again on normal mode, because it is fun to unlock new things as you go. Thanks so much for such a fantastic game!

-Logs you out of the xbox live account randomly so if you forget your user name and password for the throwaway account you made, you have to make another.
-Game seems over priced for what it is. It's pretty much made for little kids.
-Medium difficulty settings are tedious, like annoying high rate of hunger and thirst increase, leaving you searching for food all the time, and melee friendly fire.
